Yes, it can be a bit overwhelming for the first 4 or 5 hours but playing this game makes time fly by. John Marston was cool in RDR but Arthur Morgan is a legend. I highly recommend this game.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Ripped Off By Online Game
content: RockStar charges a lot of money to buy upgrades to your character.  You can either either try to make the ~$500 you need to buy a pistol by taking 13 cents at a time off each bandit you kill or use gold which you can purchase for real money.  I paid 22 gold or approximately $10 for one gun.  The game cost me $55.  I decided that I would also purchase a saddle for my horse.  They have a panther saddle that opens up at level 91.  The game was showing the option to buy it at my level of 30 using "Rank Up gold" at a price of 18 gold bars.  I clicked BUY and the game transferred me to the Playstation Playstore to buy more gold.  I purchased $19.99 worth (55 gold bars) and then returned to the game where the saddle was no longer available to purchase.  I rebooted the game several times to no avail.  I contacted customer support and got an auto response.  They never bothered to make good on the purchase.  Now I am stuck with 55 gold bars and nothing I want to spend them on.  The online version has been very buggy.  I have been in countless competitions where I am doing well when I am suddenly disconnected from the server.  This is annoying enough but I really don't appreciate errors where I purchase gold to buy something and then I am told I can't buy it.

author: Jeff
title: Rockstar got a little overzealous.
content:
Game is painstakingly slow and boring! I loved the first Redemption but this game is NOT on that level. Graphics look good! There’s a ton of missions but most are boring. The characters are weak and don’t draw you in like Marstons story. I’m 35 hours in but I don’t know how much more of my life I can waste on this game.
Update: I completed the game and bumped my rating up. The game does get better but it takes a long while! Scenery is gorgeous and missions are plentiful. There is a lot of glitches and the horse is clunky at times. I’m glad I stuck with it, but glad it’s over. There was a lot of crafting/customizing/upgrading to do but I passed on a lot of it. It was either too complicated or just wouldn’t work. Honestly, they tried cramming too much into the game.

author: KAYEFFOMEGA
title: Immersive
content:
Truly immersive and cinematic gameplay. Gorgeous graphics and realistic actions ajd animations. This game however is very slow.

If you dont enjoy taking your time and taking it easy. Or simply havinga relaxing game experience then this is not the game for you. At Certain times, the story is very exicting with the shooting and what not. But i think this game is a more relaxing gameplay experience than anything. Almost like youre playing a movie. I like to put it in cinematic mode and let it auto travel for me while i text on my phone then wait till i get to the next location. Then i continue plsying. I thoroughly enjoy this game. And there is A LOT to do with so many hours of gameplay.

author: J. A. Lovell
title: Beauty is only skin deep
content:
I was really looking forward to this... the previous game was amazing, and seeing an improved next step was quite exciting. And though the visuals, environment & details are among the best I’ve ever experienced, the game itself is a disappointing exercise in futility, plagued with clunky controls, endless tedious chores, and a staggeringly slow pace. To top it off, the game feels hollow, and it’s difficult to care about the characters.

It’s an extremely beautiful game. It just isn’t fun.

author: AircrewUp
title: Buy in's $40 stranger.
content:
And buy in you must. If you're willing to buy into the simulation aspects of the game, and happen to love the Old West, you will forgive the game it's foibles here and there. I spent a lot of time just "out". Riding trail, breaking horses, hunting. The really "emergent" experience in the sense of interacting with the game's systems to find my entertainment. Not that the quests aren't good. The main story line is fine, though there's some cliche moments there where I deeply wanted to smack Arthur, but it all comes together well at the end. The side quests are where the really good stuff's hiding though. There's a couple quests where you hang out and hunt with an old Civil War vet that really stood out in my mind in particular. There's also some sillier stuff like you'd expect from Rock Star hiding out there.

For those of you who want to enjoy more about the West, or have found a new interest in gunslingers, I strongly suggest the book Triggernometry by Eugene Cunnigham, which is filled with first hand accounts of some of the larger than life legends, good and bad, that populated the real American West.

author: specialguest
title: Did they forget to make it fun?
content:
A must own. A technical masterpiece. A once in a console achievement. Beautiful. Impressive. But fun and addictive gameplay? Maybe not.

The cons:
Obtuse menus
Mediocre camera and controls
Slow pacing

Any AAA action adventure or RPG game today should have impactful character/weapon upgrades, some sort of meaningful skill progression, and an inticing loot system that grabs your interest. These essential elements are all shoved to the back seat in RDR2.

Far cry 5 has it
God of war has it
Horizon zero dawn has it
Fallout 4 has it
Witcher 3 has it

The list goes on and on...

Rdr2 does not really have it.

*update*
As an rpg fan, I have no qualm with 60-100 hour games, but I had to move on from rdr2.
I did get into the story despite the slogging gameplay. But i could just not bring myself to finish the game. By chapter 5, I was tired and done with the slog. I have other games to start. I read a story summary and watched ending vids on youtube. Moving on now. It's too bad. It was just 10-20 hours too long for no good reason.

author: Jasper Marion
title: Red Dead Redemption 2 = Far Cry 2 in all the worst ways
content:
Man, I was so stoked to get RDR2.  I loved the RDR when it came out and have been counting down the months for RDR2.  I was so excited, I actually went out and bought a PS4 just to play this game (I'm normally more of a PC gamer).

25 hours into it, I gotta say, I am incredibly disappointed.  Over and over again, I find myself recalling Far Cry 2.  That was a really incredible game with SO many positives qualities, but ultimately a flawed and disappointing production.  For those that don't know, Far Cry 2 created a vast open world, good story, great immersion, and quality game play...with annoyance after needless annoyance that just sucked the joy out of it.  In Far Cry 2, if you run for more than a few seconds you get out of breath and slow to a crawl.  You had to take malaria pills constantly or you'd get sick and stumble around.  You couldn't fast travel and had to drive literally everywhere in lousy cars that were slow and boring.  Bad guys attacked you constantly and respawned, making your constant treks across the wilderness feel like massive chores instead of fun action sequences.

With RDR2, it's like none of the developers paid any attention to all the failures of Fry Cry 2.  Indeed, it's like they went double-down on all the annoying aspects of that game, while tossing in a few more for good measure.  The most frustrating thing about this, is that--like Far Cry 2, there's actually an amazing game underneath the stupidity.  The soundtrack, graphical design, and character acting are all exceptional.  The story and characters seem pretty good so far and I really do enjoy exploring and doing all the things the game offers.  The sense of exploration is incredible and the detail and hard work put into making the world seem real and alive is really commendable.  On the other hand, the game team seems to have decided that more "realism" also meant the inclusion of boring chores and animations.

Video games are, in general, "simulations" (sims) of something.  RDR2 is a simulation of cowboy life.  All sims struggle with how far they want to go in simulating real life, but most seem to understand that the key is simulating the "fun" parts, while ignoring or vastly underplaying the "chore" or "boring" aspects.  The "fun" parts of being a cowboy include gunfights, racing around on a horse, hunting, fishing, robbing banks, quickdraws, etc.  Things that could be a novelty the first few times include realistic depictions of things, like skinning an animal, eating, brushing your horse.  The first few times you see it, you think, huh, it's cool how realistic they made that.  Then you realize you have to see them over and over and over again.  Worse, they are mandatory!  You have to eat in this game to survive.  You have to hunt to eat.  You have to skin the animals to get the meat to eat.  You have to brush and feed and compliment your horse to keep it happy.  You have to cut your hair, change your clothes, and bathe.  On and on, the game literally gives you ACTUAL VIRTUAL CHORES to do -- that you MUST do -- just to play the game.  Adding to this, they make all these things take FOREVER!  The animation for looting a dead bad guy takes 5 seconds.  If you have a shootout and kill 30 guys and want to loot them all, expect to spend about 3 minutes doing nothing but watching the same painfully slow animation over and over again.  5 seconds doesn't sound long until you play the game and realize what a stupid amount of time is literally wasted.  That is just one example.  In RDR, I thought the time spent depicting animal skinning was just about right.  It was long enough to convey the point and hint at being annoying, but not enough to actually be annoying.  With RDR2, they were like, nope!  Let's turn it into the most laborious activity possible and make sure our players know EXACTLY how real cowboys skinned animals! It's so painful it's just stupid.  You kill the animal, then find the animal, then walk around it trying to get the controls to notice it, then skin it.  That animation takes FOREVER.  Do I really need to see exactly how to skin an animal in real life?  Really?  Then after you skin the animal, you still have to carry the skin over to the back of your horse and drop it off.  After that, you have to go back to the now-skinned-animal, pick it up, and then stash it on your horse.  The whole process just feels agonizingly slow and pointless.  This is exacerbated by the painfully wonky controls and then multiplied even more by how SLOW everything in the game.  Horses run painfully slow and get exhausted way too fast, slowing you down even more.  The map is massive, but there is no fast travel so it means you just spend hours doing nothing but running back and forth trying not to killed in the process.  I literally find myself avoiding doing "fun" things like gunfights and stuff because I know I'll have to stop and set up camp and eat and rest just so I can continue on my way afterwards.  It makes everything just feel like a big painful chore.  The NEEDLESSNESS of it all is what annoys me the most.  Why are players forced to walk at a snail's pace through camp?  Why do we have to see the animation every single time the player loots someone in such laborious detail?  I know they emphasized realism and I do appreciate that...for the first few hours.  After that, I just want to have fun and enjoy a cowboy "sim".  That's what RDR was.

Why not just give the option to skip animations like other games?  Or show the animation the first few times and then make it an option?  Why not speed it up a bit?  They actually do this for things like eating, which goes pretty fast.  Why not for skinning animals or looting bad guys?  Why am I more concerned about how much food my underweight character is eating or how dirty he is instead of how I'm going to take down the next group of bad guys or what gun I get to carry?  It's not fun worrying about feeding, bathing, cleaning, grooming, dressing for the right weather, etc, or at least not constantly.  Make those things optional or at least much less important--even vital--for the game to be played.  Make bonding with your horse by brushing, feeding, and being nice to them an optional or occasional thing, not something you have to do constantly just to keep them alive and running!  I know it's realistic.  I get it.  That's not the point.  Clearly, the game makers were fine ditching realism for some things, like the insane amount of bottles and cans you can carry around, or not making us watch the character relieve himself.  So if they are fine breaking reality for some things, why insist on it for all these others?

RDR2 is just a shameful waste of an amazing opportunity.  Like Far Cry 2, this was a "should have been great" that killed itself with it's own stupid adherence to realism at the expense of fun.  That said, if they could patch the game and fix some of these things, I absolutely think the game would be a 5 star favorite of mine.  As is, I'm pretty much ready to sell it back to Amazon.

author: David J Young Jr

While playing the game, you totally feel like you’re immersed in that time period in US history. I play some multiplayer games but if you’re into solo gameplay more than multiplayer like me this game is absolutely perfect. I’m an avid sports fan that’s always going out to watch the “game” and often times I’m playing this game before going out and keep telling myself... ok, only 10 more minutes of gameplay. Just get this game for you or somebody that love video games

author: Robert G.Walden
title: Great game for playing and lose yourself in
content:
Original: 12.13.2018
Pro:  Graphics – Score: 5 out of 5
  Stunning graphics that really take you for a ride. When I have free time to play, I flip on the game and the first screen when you start is usually stunning visual. I'm 40 something and some of the views and locations bring me back when I was a kid, fishing or hunting with family. The graphic really takes you there.

 Story – Score: 5 out of 5
  OK. Some find this boring. I find it real. It's the turn of the century. Taking your horse places WAS what you had to do. There are stagecoaches and trains, but those are marked on your calendar AND it does cost money.  I believe this gives it a really good touch of the time.  Heck, I spent 2 weeks in Story 2 just because I liked hunting and fishing. I only went to Story 3 because I already had all the guns I was allowed to have and could only get some new ones in Story 3.  That being said, the story mode of the game is complex and quite long. At times, it can get tiring to ride your horse clear across the map to get somewhere, BUT, that is what makes it authentic. I really get the feeling that I'm investing a lot into Arthur Morgan and hearing him speak and interact is quite enjoyable. The unknown side missions that sort of come out of no where is a nice touch. I can say I'm in no rush to finish this game. In a way, after the wife and kids are asleep, I find this game very soothing AND allows me to think of where to take my kids camping next year.

Pro/Con Mix:
 Dead Eye – 4 out of 5
  As some have mentioned, there are cases in dead eye where you can mistakenly target NPC or a horse, but I've started following what some on youtube have been suggesting, which is target first, dead eye, and then shot. Otherwise, dead eye is still fun and sorta g-d like.

Con
 Controls – Score: 3 out of 5
  Man, this is my only gripe and it's not all that bad. They are working on it, but given the controls are sorta the core of the game, there are some challenges, but they aren't awful as some of said. It's not as great as....say.....The Witcher 3, but they aren't as worse as.......any number of games out there.  It takes a little to get used to, but once you get it, its ok. So middle of the road for me.

Overall: Score – 4 out of 5
 The controls are the only ding. Otherwise, I've caught my kids playing the game as well and their character just fishing or hunting. Not even playing the story. Just doing their own thing. There other games they are shooting and killing at will. Heck, I bought them Fallout 76 and they ditched that after the second day and went back to RDR2.  So in that, if I could give 4.5 stars, I would.  Bravo

author: Amazon Customer
title: Great game!
content:
This is a great open world game. The controls take a little bit get used to, but unless you are completely uncoordinated and have never played a video game they become second nature. The map is awesome, and the detail from the snow to the trees and the scenery makes riding the horse even more fun. The audio is really great from the sound effects and all the different dialogue from the characters makes it feel like the environment is really alive. The voice overs and writing are well done. The story is great and the variety of missions and different activities keeps it interesting.

You don’t have to do the different survival things like cooking, hunting, changing your clothes or do all the different crafting unless you really want to. I don’t notice it making a huge impact on me completing missions. The biggest thing you need is food for Health if it gets low in battle or tonics to boost dead eye.

Like all Rockstar games it’s the personality of the characters, the variety of the missions, the gameplay of those missions, and finding cool new things on the map that make this an amazing game. Even if they didn’t have all the side activities like hunting, playing poker, searching for cigarette cards, or just taking care of your camp it still has everything that has made Rockstar games awesome. It’s well worth the money and after you play it for a couple hours you will get used to the controls and the different screens. You might get annoyed that you keep losing your hat though LOL!

author: Clash Senser
title: World amazing. Gameplay lame!
content: As a fan of Rockstar games, I anticipated this one for a long time! And it seemed amazing at first, the world is both huge and really detailled. So far 5* for RDR2. So how can we go down to 3* from here?? Well, after a variety of impressions you start to focus on the game itself. And you realize that the style of missions hasn't really changed ever since GTA 3! Travel to the starting point. Cut scene. Travel somewhere (in this case horse riding, which is slow). Then usually shoot a few fellers. Alternatively, in case that's too exciting, catch a few fish or buy something from a store (really??). Then travel back. And if that doesn't sound boring enough, one has to know that most missions are really easy. Ok, fair enough you think. It's an open world game after all, so let's try some side missions or the hyped interactions with the world, which are supposed to have quite an influence on your further game. But well, most side missions are like all other missions. Except even more boring (catch a horse with your lasso) and usually even easier (calm down horse, walk horse back to owner, get a hint from its owner for ... well, another side mission). So then you try to interact with people in the open world. Hey, you can call out and greet. But well, almost everybody has a generic reply and there is nothing that you can do. Or you can set camp and maybe craft something. But again, the results are not very exciting or helpful for further gameplay, so I ignored that rather quickly. So what's you last resort in a Rockstar open world game? Well, you stir up some trouble. You can easily spot camps by their fire smoke, and roughly 50% you find a hostile gang there. And you want to find out how the AI got smarter here. 5 years after GTA5 and such a massive game, you'd expect something here, right? Well, once you shot at them or something, they seem to always see you. So hiding in the bushes and sneeking around them or so doesn't help, because they would always attack you no matter what. So you can just attack them straight forward, maybe seek some cover behind a rock. They are not smart enough to try to circle or flank you either, again it seems like almost nothing has been done since GTA3. Well, I'm about 35% through the story and I will continue and see how far I get. But I have to say I'm already quite bored. Then move on to the next game I guess. What a disappointment this game is!

author: Angela
title: Broken
content: I just not opened it for the first time and the disc was cracked.

author: Gabbyblue
title: The Day Has Finally Arrived...and it was well worth the wait.
content:
HI'm. Playing. It. Right. Now.

Surreal. As. All. Giddy. Up.

The actualization of playing this game is like finding a mythical creature. At this point----I've basically mythologized it. It almost felt as if this day would never come. But it has...and I feel like an 8 year old on Christmas morning. Why 8? Because that's how long I've been waiting. The amount of dopamine and epinephrine that was produced from seeing the home screen for the first time almost exceeds grabbing a hold of my first pair of ACTUAL ta ta's on an ACTUAL girl. Is that sad? Maybe. But it's the truth. I've never felt this way over a game (much less anything else really). Rock* has achieved so much. What we have here is something that's really special. It's something that needs to be treasured. When you play this game------you're having a brush with greatness. You'll always remember what was going on in your life when you played this game for the first time. Future playthroughs will send you back to the here and now. Treasure these moments. They will one day be fondly remembered as the good ole days. Right now...the here and NOW is the good ole days. Don't let it slip by without realizing that. It's not "just a game". It's so much more. It's an event.

I salute you Rock*.

Bravo.

Now, I must return to the old west. Brothels need to be visited, banks need robbing and horses need to relieve themselves at the most awkward of moments. Plus, that whisky ain't gonna drink itself.

PS: I'll add my technical thoughts (in regard to mechanics and graphics) at a later date. But, I can tell you this: on the Xbox One X it's the first game that looks and performs JUST like a PC game. I kid you not: this game is gorgeous. My wife is playing it on the PS4------don't get me wrong: the game still looks phenomenal-----but not to the degree that it does on the X. The One X was made for this game. This game was made to be experienced on the X. I'm not saying this to perpetuate the toxic tribalism of blind fanboyism----I'm saying this because it's a fact. I LOVE both Xbox and PlayStation. But, a fact is a fact.  Stay tuned for more.

November 28th update:

I've been playing it since the 26th. I have 300+ hours into it and it feels as if I've only played 20 hours. I'm not sick of ANY of the formulaic elements whatsoever. It STILL feels organic. That is a landmark achievement in gaming. It's uncanny. I've since purchased Hitman and Odyssey and just cannot bring myself to leave RDR2. I'm still playing as Arthur (but I think it's getting close to the end). This is the best game of all time. This is indisputable.

EDIT: I finished Arthur's story 20 min after writing my update. If you were able to hold back tears-----you're a stronger man than me (even if you're a woman). I'm glad I was alone. Dang you Rockstar. Dang you. Emotions were stirred that I didn't even know I had. 😢 But it was SO SO SO SO good.

With all sincerity and not a speck of melodramatic intent: Arthur Morgan inspired me to be a better man. I'm still in disbelief that a video game character has had this effect on me. It's truly surreal. This game was a bona fide morality tale that simply dripped with philosophical implications that has been translated into my day to day reality. RDR2 isn't something YOU play-----IT plays YOU. This wasn't just another game-----it was a spiritual experience.

author: Kelly Lynch
title: Ama
content: Dont listen to other reviewers saying the game is slow and a drag. Yes Atrhur doesnt control and move like Kassandra from Assasins Creed Odyssey or girl from Horizon Zero Dawn, but hes not an assassin either. Hes an outlaw who's in his late 30s or mid 40s. The entire point of this game is your trying to live and survive in this wild country where the world is becoming more civilized and you want to be free from all of that. The game itself is unbelievable in every category. I spent 5 hours hunting the other night. I tamed a wild horse (White Arabian). I've gone treasure hunting finding a few gold bars along the way.  Chapter 2 is essentially a tutorial in some parts teaching ypu how to traverse and succeed in this huge beautiful wild wild country. R* outdid themselves and somehow managed to blow my expectations out of the water. I love GTA games but Read Dead has always been my favorite. I prefer the slower pace and enjoying being an outlaw/cowboy. Voice acting and story is top notch. Arthur is by far my favorite R* character and maybe my favorite of all time. He has so much depth and feels grounded and real in that world. Do yourself a favor and buy this now. It takes a few hours to get going but the story really draws you in and before you know it its 4am and you've been playing for 8 hours straight.

author: He who refers to his gender as Batman
title: Pretty impressive
content: The game is great! a few bugs in it here or there but they fix themselves instead of having to restart the game. It's not overly complex and intimidating like a few big games out there and it pretty gorgeous. The environment is amazing. I can tell that the environment graphics were top focus, even to the smaller details. It's a lot of fun and not as hokey as some past rock star games. I didn't think that they could out-do themselves from their last GTA game but RDR2 is very subversive and  gritty. The only thing I wish they put more time into would be their weapon system. I would have loved to see more mechanical configuration capabilities since during those historical times weapons were big business and there were tons of modifications and prototypes back then. It just would have been a little more fun. It still doesn't take away though, I haven't played a great game like this in a long time.

author: Jon Claude
title: A well made game
content:
First off ill say I bought only the base game.  Its been a while since I've played a game that was so well put together,  honestly I wasn't even really planning on getting red dead redemption 2 also know as (RDR2).  What pulled me into getting it was how detailed they made everything, the weapon loading animations, crafting system, the animations with the animals extremely detailed and realistic, and a gripping plot; there are a few things that aren't as realistic such as the dead eye mechanism but thats pretty small compared to the rest of the game.  I've spent about a good 60+ hours playing the game, that includes main missions and side missions. and have finally completed the game and the epilogues but there still quite a bit for me to do though; a few more side missions, challenges, and compendium challenges left for me. I like to leave no stone unturned and complete the game 100%. I did only buy the regular edition of the game however; now I wished I would have gotten the deluxe edition since I enjoyed the game so much.
Con: You have to pay an extra $20 for a couple of extra missions and some costumes.  Missions that were already in the base game but the company decided to put up a paywall to block content for those who don't wanna fork over some more cash. Skins (costumes) are one thing I can understand but cutting missions from the base game is where I personally draw the line.

author: S Nack
title: I can't seem to stay awake..
content:
The graphics are amazing. The game is pretty to look at, for about 30 minutes. Unless you are really into sightseeing in video games, the pretty graphics just fade into background. It's 2018 after all, nearly every game is pretty to look at.

The characters are just ok, I find Dutch more of an interesting character than the main protagonist Arthur. The rest of the gang are just forgettable. Most of the time it's hard to even tell who is talking. The subtitles don't help either: They don't include names. BTW Arthur looks so pedestrian without his hat, which he loses every time he gets in a fight. Please put a hat on him at all times!

The combat feels like a copy and paste from GTA V. Auto aiming is on by default. Shooting doesn't feel satisfying. most of the time you just press aim and shoot, and the enemy dies, no aiming needed. But some times key friendly NPCs will get killed out of nowhere, making you restart the checkpoint. Annoying.

Other things: the game is... slow. The guy walks like a turtle. Seriously every video game character needs to be running by default. Why is every interactive option at the bot-right corner? It's distracting and hard to see! I still haven't figured out the Horse inventory system, seems unnecessarily complicated. The icons for inventory items, they all look the same. Getting on a horse and get going feels clunky, clunkier than Witcher 3. Horse keeps tripping over things if I take a shortcut.

I don't know much about the story yet and I will probably not find out. I only get to play about an hour or two per day, and I can't play this when the kids are awake (and I have to sleep too), Ultimately, there is so much in the game to do, but I find myself lack of interest of continuing after just chapter 2.

author: Miller Video Games
title: Bought Special Edition on release night and it was worth every penny.
content:
Huge fan of Rockstar games, especially Red Dead Redemption. Was not prepared for how spectacular this game is. I can't wrap my head around all the hate reviews this game has on amazon. I'll agree that the controls are a bit clunky and some of the animations get old but I feel like many of them will be nonexistent in multiplayer (such as skinning animals, searching bodies, etc.).

The world and the story crafted within are some of the most memorable things in gaming for me. I don't want to spoil anything but sh*t gets real around chapter 5. I haven't made it to the end yet but the story is definitely my favorite of all the Rockstar games, even surpassing the Witcher III in my opinion. Open world games have become so generic over time but R* really shed some blood, sweat, and tears over this game.

With all that said, I'm excited to finish the story and start a new game before Online beta starts. This game has convinced me to reinstate my Playstation+ membership and buy any DLC that comes out afterwards (excluding microtransactions).

But despite all of these apparent achievements, the game is ultimately boring. Even if you focus on the main story line, you have to trudge through huge gaps of redundancy. I am halfway through the main quest, so I feel like I've given this game a fair chance. But, it feels more like a chore than fun. I never give up on games, but I don't think I'll finish RDR2.

author: Anonymous67
title: Don't expect GTA V
content:
I'm a couple hours in and am pretty bored. It takes its sweet time to get going, holding your hand every step of the way.  The way it plays and controls is very lumbering, slow, clunky and sluggish.

Its like they wanted to just make some high art movie, taking itself so seriously. GTA IV had the same issue(making it more grounded and presenting its more realistic story), which they corrected with GTA V. Fun story, but also bombastic and over the top fun gameplay. Red Dead is sooo boring. Its not a lot of fun just trotting on a horse from Point A (mission giver) to point B (Mission location) and two characters ramble and chit chat. Its like I'm listening to some radio drama show instead of playing a game. Red Dead Redemption 1 cut to the chase and got things going much faster and was much more lean and mean. Sure there's a million things to do in Red dead 2, but the core gameplay itself is underwhelming, and no game can stand on a broken foundation.

If you are expecting the fun and wild ride of GTA V, you will be sorely disappointed with Red dead. Its totally different and I would recommend watching some long play videos before buying so that you get a better idea of what you are getting in to.

author: Andrew Barrett
title: “Oh, I didn’t know I was talkin to a LADEH”
content:
Pros
  - If you love taking your time and enjoying realism then this game is for you.
  - The story, characters, and overall environment is A+ material.
  - There's so much detail that I don't think I will ever be able to fully appreciate all the time it took to make this game
  - Arthur is my favorite protagonist because of how authentic of a personality he is.

Cons
  - I have to live in chapter 3 of the game and no further because I personally refuse to emotionally deal with how the game leaves you later on. ( this means you wont have access to a good bottom portion to the map but im ok with it )
  - The online isn't as engaging as single player and I can't quite figure out why. ( could be getting shot all the time by strangers )

Overall, I really like how when you decide to pick up an apple, Arthur reaches out, picks it up, and places it in his satchel. Same thing with getting off and on the horse or hitching it.. It makes me feel like I can actually role-play as a cowboy. The pace of the game is a very subjective topic and personally I think its perfect, but if I were a GIVE IT TO MEH NOW LETS BLOW SH** UP kind of guy then I think I would hate it.
It's worth a buy in my opinion and will be one of my favorite escapes for when I feel like I want to go Westworld for awhile.

author: Greg4408
title: Yawn
content:
*** Edit 2/2019.  Over time I softened my view of this game.  I eventually got better at, for example, fighting from horseback.  But what helped more was just reaching a critical mass of more options of what to do.  The main story takes a *long* time to pick up speed, and is prone to redundancy.  For example, Arthur is subjected to repeated, lengthy diatribes about his seeming lack of loyalty.  But it did reach a tipping point where I wanted to keep playing.
***

Like some of the other recent reviewers I have to categorize this game as almost impossibly boring.  Long hours riding your horse from place to place.  Just riding.  Get to where you're headed, watch some canned dialog, then mount up again and follow someone off on some mission.  For a real thrill, pick up someone from the side of the road and take them on your horse somewhere way off of your path.

Technically and creatively it's very well done.  The graphics, the voice acting, the attention to detail of things like the numerous weapons you can purchase are all very good.  Plus the game seems very stable.  I don't think it's locked up on me yet.

The combat is a bit frustrating.  On story missions it's usually fairly manageable, but the random encounters can go horribly wrong quickly.  If I'm on horseback I've learned to flee from the gunfights, dismount (horsed combat is brutal), then go back on foot to challenge your enemies.  If you're killed you re-spawn and can't find those same enemies.  So, you can't even get revenge or try that same fight again.  You simply missed your chance.  Plus, as others have noted you can accidentally do damage, assault someone, even steal something without meaning to.  Once you do you have a bounty and life gets annoying.  And expensive.

I'll probably keep playing, but unlike other games where I find myself putting hours and hours into it, it's all too easy to put this game down and do something else.

author: D. Discs
title: Boring gameplay, bad economy, poor design
content:
As many other reviewers have pointed out, the gameplay is dull.  There's a lot of traveling over a huge map to get from Point A to Point B, typically for a reward in game money that is worth far less than the time you spent on the mission.  Everything worth buying is too expensive.

The poor design of character interaction is what made me quit.  Brushing too close to another character, even in town, can cause them to attack you.  They can kill you without consequence.  If you attempt to defend yourself, however, the law will come for you quickly and other townspeople will even join in the attack against you.  There is no logic to this and it often requires a level of delicacy in moving your character around that one should not have to deal with in a town setting.

There's a lot to do in the game, but you'll often wind up asking yourself why you should do it, and what the point of doing it is.

author: AdamHD
title: PS4 Pro performance is EXTREMELY disappointing
content: I'll start this off by saying that I am sure the actual game is 5 stars.  I am about 10 hours in, and it has been a great game living up to the standard Rockstar quality.  The main issue is- on PS4 Pro, this is a total let down performance wise.  Extremely blurry, non-sharp graphics.  Weird depth of field issues, etc.  This is crazy to me, as PS4 was the "lead platform" for this game.  Most games use the fake 4K "checkerboarding" on the PS4 Pro to make the game look significantly better than the 900p-1080p performance you are going to get from the standard PS4.  Something went wrong in this game, and it looks pretty terrible.  Hopefully this will be patched by Rockstar somehow.  I will probably plow through the game and sell it, while the resale value is high, and maybe play it again if/when it comes out on PC.  Pretty disappointed, as I purchased the PS4 Pro bundle to play this game (and of course a handful of PlayStation exclusives), and the experience with Red Dead Redemption 2 has been far from the "4K experience" I was hoping for.

author: LasVegasLen
title: For only certain type of gamers.
content: O.K. I read all the reviews and bought the game knowing what to expect. If you’re a Fortnite, Call of Duty, online gamer type, this is not your game. I’m a forty year old gamer that enjoys a good story.  I just finished the train robbing scene and I realized, I’m hooked. Love the game. Yes, it’s slow. I’m warning you now if you think you’ll be running around like GTA or Far Cry (love those games BTW) you won’t. Listen to the dialog and take your time.  It kind of reminds of resident evil type of movement. Some people say clunky, I say I agree. I think I get that impression because of the slow pace. Yes, you open every drawer, and ride on your horse a lot. I’m only about 3 hours in and there is a lot to do. Maybe I’ll edit my review later, but for now 9/10 score.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Trouble sleeping?  By this game!
content: I was a HUGE fan of the last game.  It had the right mix of action, exploring, side quests, interesting story, and overall fun!  Hearing there would be a follow up I was pumped!  However after playing the game I keep wondering when it will get better?  Unfortunately it never does.  This game is just a tedious clunky snooze fest through and through.  Outside of the amazing graphics, none of it is memorable or fun.  When I found realized I was having to force myself to try and slug through it, I just uninstalled it and sold the game off.  Really disappointed and honestly shocked by all the positive reviews I see out there.

author: MJA
title: The best game since Skyrim.
content:
I think the people who are giving this a bad review got themselves hyped up for a new GTA and that’s just not what this is - it’s better.

This game is slow, but that’s on purpose. You quickly gain a fast travel map that lets you go to ever major place and, although it’s  not the instant teleport we’re used to, it cuts down on the monotonous traveling immensely. Other than that, it does take slightly long than I’d prefer to skin animals and loot items in the wild.

But aside from that, the world and graphics are the best I’ve ever seen. The setting is absolutely magical and the way the weather changes with the climate is incredible. I’m not even halfway through and I’m already devastated that it has to end at some point.

Online is coming but I don’t care; I could hunt and fish all day and lose track of time the way I did back in the PS1/PS2 days. This is everything the last 5-6 years of gaming have missed by overly investing in gimmicks and online play. I am so glad there’s still a market for the single player game because this is, overall, the best experience I’ve had since Skyrim.

Buy this game.

author: Jilly from philly
title: SEVEN YEARS FOR THIS?????
content:
I will start by saying, before I ever bought this game I watched many many reviews.  I read all kinds of tips and starter ideas that help the game not be so terribly boring at the beginning.  After completing the main story I am so sorry I ever wasted my time and money on this game.
Like I'm sure you've read from every good review, this game is massive and there's a lot you can do.  Graphics are amazing, and the environment is downright awesome.
Where the game really falls apart is simply in gameplay.  As many others have said it's very disjointed.  Things like trying to pick up an item and not the dead body next to it can be downright frustrating on a constant basis.  Running, riding your horse and the likes are about as far from smooth as it gets.
Unlike a lot of reviews have said, there is a method for fast travel.  Not just coaches and trains, you can unlock fast travel from your camp, BUT ONLY FROM YOUR OWN CAMP (and not back again).  This means you will spend hours and hours travelling from one place to another with nothing to do.  There is plenty if stuff in between but sometimes you just need to get somewhere with no interruptions, and you can't.  You can auto pilot from one place to another but you need to pay attention you can't just leave your controller while you go cook dinner or something.  Sometimes your horse goes the wrong way sometimes you get robbed and killed.  One time while in the cinematic auto pilot my horse ran into a prisoner stage coach so when I got back I was dead and had a bounty!  So you have to constantly pay attention even when auto piloting from one place to another.
Maybe my most hated of all things is the 'save feature' You can manually save games but it's not anywhere near up to date.  If you save right before a big fight or tracking a legendary animal and go back to the save feature, often it will be nowhere near where you saved the game.  Items you didn't use will have been used up, animals will be gone and items not accessible.  Absolutely awful.  The story could have been written by any moron.  It's completely linear with very little options for you to make you own choices.  Even without spoilers it's so easy to tell when you're going to be betrayed or robbed or do something dumb, but you can't do anything else!  The idea for stories with your own options has been around since before the first RDR and now seven years later they haven't fixed anything, great job rockstar!  I played games in the early 2000s where you could affect your own ending based on the decisions you make and somehow rockstar is almost 20 years behind in their gameplay design.  They only care about putting out a game people will buy, not a game people will love.

Overall the main problem is simply that the game is disjointed and slow.  It's meant to be an immersive experience but it's just not because of all the control problems and the MASSIVE amounts of downtime.  As my girlfriend put it so well, this is much more like a very boring movie than a video game.  Buy this game if you must, but even if you really like it you will quickly be made aware of it's very many flaws.

WARNING BELOW ARE GAME SPOILERS!!!!!!
I am only including these because if I had known about this stuff I never would have wasted my money in the first place.

On top of the very linear story line, you can't make any decisions at all.  That was fine for a game 20 years ago but this is 2018.  You have to kill tons of people and betray half the people in your group.  You have to go along with missions you know will get you betrayed and wanted by the law.  And the best part of all you have to get betrayed by the leader of your gang and die in the end no matter what choices you try to make.  There is only one ending to the game which is absurd in this day and age.  The *best* part of all this is that half the map doesn't even open up until you character dies.  The are a lot of missions and challenges you can't even access until the main story is done.  All that character customization you spent hours on and the challenges and the good vs evil decisions you make at every turn mean absolutely nothing since your character dies and you're forced to play the end of the game as the character from the first red dead.  I will never buy another rockstar game again as they've shown they're incapable of making progress and keeping up with the times.

author: Alphie 45
title: THE BEST GAME EVER!!!!!!
content:
Hello Everyone,
I had to write a review here even though my purchase was initially for XBOX ONE,
i have recently switched my gaming to PLAYSTATION 4 and i am loving it.
So i had to buy the game again from another shop as i brother carried the XBOX ONE S away
Now RED DEAD REDEMPTION 2 is a solid game easily one of the best i have ever played.
WOW!!!
The game starts slow obviously for such a big game they have to start somewhere and give you some background of all the characters involved.
So i played through that and it was very intersting like watching an old western movie just that you are part of the movie...
The negative reviews about this game i cannot understand, everything is realistic in the game,shoot someone in the leg and they will continue to limp away till you catch up to them(i mean you want to shoot someone in the leg for him to die??),run too fast for long you lose your breath,
weather tooo cold get inside or the cold can cause your stamina to drop
what were these goons expecting from this game?
its very realistic and you cannot go guns blazing around
Its not Call Of Duty
my goodness i cannot wait to go back to the Redemption world
really solid game
Get this game and get The Witcher 3 Game Of The Year Edition plus God Of War
Christmas toast to you all

author: Mad Max
title: Can you press the X-Button a lot???
content:
I am at 40% completion and there are some very cool moments in this game. The drunk mission with Lenny is un-expected, insane and funny as hell. The pig-couple was awesome as well.
The scenery is gorgeous but it gets a bit repetitive also.
BUT---
For most missions, you must ride your horse for a good 10 minutes to get to the "quest giver", (most of the time with a one-sided conversation about nothing the WHOLE freaking time) then your quest will invariably involve riding your horse half-way back across the map from where you just came, usually involve an ok cut-scene followed by a shootout, then you ALWAYS have to ride your horse back to a final location.
So to put it simply, 20 minutes of horse-riding through repetitive (but pretty) scenery, 3 minutes of cut-scenes, and 3 minutes of gun-fighting.
This wouldn't be as bad if there was something exciting about riding your horse, but you literally just pump the X-button, and try not to crash your horse (which he will do a lot if you hit a stump or tree).
The other major let-down is the music, RDR1 had some AWESOME western guitar music that could have come out of Clint Eastwood film, this doesn't have that very often.
The controls are a little clunky, and the menu crafting is also clunky.
Overall, not up to RDR1, worth a playthough though if you are a fan and have the time, but this is not the masterpiece I was hoping for.
(also if I want to boil coffee, wipe my gun for two minutes straight, and shave-- I already do that- it's called REAL life! ;)
And the BIGGEST problem maybe all the button hold downs required (instead of just selling something for instance you have the hold the x button down for about 1.5 seconds- which gets REAL OLD after awhile. This was poor choice for game mechanics.)

author: kfsass
title: Don't waste your money or time
content:
I was really excited for this one bc I really enjoyed the first RDR. However, this game is just... not fun. At all.

It's technically impressive - the world is a gorgeous depiction of American heartland, the mechanics are all very well-engineered. However, therein lies the issue. This game sacrifices any sense of fun for immersion. Actions take a long time to complete as your character goes through an entire, realistic animation of picking up a can of biscuits or pulling the cork out of a bottle of rum before drinking it. Traveling by horse takes an incredibly long time and takes up most of the hours you'll be putting in this game. For something you do incredibly often, horseback combat is miserable. You have to hold X to keep the horse running, you have to hold the aim button, you have to steer the horse while looking behind you, as they don't follow trails except in the "cinematic camera", and you have to fire and reload. Miserable.

This game could be accurately summed up as riding your horse a long distance from camp, shooting some people, and riding your horse back to camp. It should be titled "Cowboy Simulator 2018" because that's about the sum of it.

author: Ian B.
title: Disappointing Showing from Rockstar
content:
This game's only pros are its storyline, voice acting, and graphics. Oh yeah, and poker. Aside from that this game is just not what I wanted it to be. I've never played a game that just FELT so bad. The combat is not rewarding, becomes boring after a couple hours. You are not given many compelling reasons to use any methods other than shooting baddies in the head, and the more fun methods of combat are severely underpowered in comparison, leaving one logical choice for engagement with enemies. The save system is extremely wonky. The menus are SO SLOW to navigate through. Traveling (even on horseback) becomes so tedious and tiresome, which is not the feeling a good open world game's travel would cultivate. Truly, this game would be much better suited to an Uncharted/The Last of Us style that Naughty Dog has mastered, but, unfortunately, Rockstar insists on shoehorning great stories into bland open worlds that do not serve any narrative purpose.

Honestly, the best part of this game may very well be poker. But that is no credit to the game. Who doesn't already enjoy poker? Save yourself $60 and play poker on your phone for free.

If you really want to play a good open world game, try out Horizon Zero Dawn or Breath of the Wild.
And if you want to play a story-driven game that is actually cohesive, with good gameplay, and won't bore you to death, play the Uncharted series or The Last of Us.

I would only recommend buying this game on sale of at least 50% off, otherwise, spend your money elsewhere.

author: Brandon
title: Fun Western
content: Red Dead Redemption 2 is an open world western game where you play the role of an outlaw just trying to get by. The graphics are great and the character animations are wonderful. I could not stand Arthur Morgans voice as it was so stereo typical and ridiculous, almost funny to an extent. The gun play is decent and the constant swapping of weapons on your horse is annoying, but realistic. The worst part of the game is the real life stuff that I don't want to deal with in a video game. You have to feed, bathe, shave, and much more to keep your character in good standing. The biggest argument is that you will rarely have to do it, but that is simply not true and I think fans are just getting so captivated by the game they don't notice it. As someone who did not play the previous game- I definitely noticed. One a good note, the story is good and the characters have unique personalities, making communication enjoyable. I would say the open world is fun to explore, because it can be, but the constant horse riding and following people on a horse makes traveling extremely boring at time. Lat point- why is it when I'm attacked by someone and defend myself, I am now a wanted criminal? that's not how it should work. Overall this is a good game and I would recommend it to someone who has never played the series, but I am not ignorant and I understand it's flaws, which are still not that substantial to stop me from playing.

author: Hacksaw
title: Disappointing and not a whole lot of fun
content: Take time and read the other reviews 3 stars and under. They all say basically the same thing and they are all correct. Except for negatives regarding graphics because the graphics are superb. Im not entirely sure how its getting 5 stars ratings and the high praise from the mainstream review outlets. But anyway the controls are highly frustrating especially on the horse. Youre forced to walk (at a slow snails pace walk) in certain areas and then when you are allowed to run you have to hold or continually tap a button which really sucks because you cant enjoy looking around with the camera. Same with the horse. There are a lot of unnecessary button presses and controls to do basic actions. The controls and movements just feel wrong. They are odd and unnatural and do not allow for a smooth control flow as you would expect in a video game. The story I found to be good and it was enough to keep me going for several hours but I struggled so much with the controls that it really made the game not much fun at all. Also there are so many options and icons and things that look like you should be able to do and I just felt lost because the game doesn't give clear instructions on a lot of it. And for some reason they designed the pop up tutorial messages to occur when events or story stuff is happening on the screen. I missed notifications because of this and probable why I felt lost sometimes on what do. And then I would make sure to read a message and completely miss what the characters were saying. very frustrating. I spent so much time trying to tweak the options to get the controls more user friendly and fun but the options available just don't do it. The best control scheme was Standard FPS which helped with sprinting but why am I forced to walk! Id rather have the default as run and then push/hold a button to walk. If this game had the foot and horse controls of a game like Origins or Odyssey or any other modern recent decent game then this would be a near perfect game. The survival elements are pretty good but can be a bit much in some aspects making it more of a forced chore that is not always fun. Overall not really that great a game. Got on Thursday night release (gamestop). Had to install both discs (took a couple of hours) so couldn't play until Friday night after work. Played all weekend and discovered that it kinda sucked. Then sold it that Monday. Paid 60 plus tax sold it for 53. Im ok with a few dollar loss just for trying the game out. My advice if you don't like the game go ahead and sell it before the price starts to drop.

author: Steve
title: Not good
content:
Bad graphics can ruin an otherwise great game, great graphics can't make an otherwise bad game great.  This is a shooter for people who don't like shooters, an open world for people who don't like open worlds, and a story for people who don't like stories.
You can't progress in the game unless you kill hoards of bad guys, yet the shooter controls and cumbersome at best.  The delayed response with the controller, the broken cover engine, the animations that you're forced to go through when getting in and out of cover, while being shot at, completely took me out of the game.
The animations you have to sit through while looking through drawers and skinning animals, while they're only a couple of seconds each time, really add up.  When you have a field of 20 bodies and you want to loot, well, better prepare for about 5 minutes of looting animations.
This is not immersive, I do not feel any loyalty to the gang or the main character.  This looks like a movie, and it allows you to hit some buttons at specific times.  You spend 95% of your time riding on the trail to a mission where you talk, follow people slowly, shoot 20 bad guys, then ride to the next mission.
The graphics are great, but the fur and hair looks like garbage.  Maybe it's just my xbox and tv, but when hair mixes with the background graphics, it give a static effect like the old tube tv's.
This is a good game for the casual gamer.  But I've been waiting a long time for this one, and Rockstar delayed the release a couple of times, for what, I don't know.
Trying to draw your weapon works about 25% of the time, and it always seems to default to your pistol.  You can hunt with the bow and arrow, skin an animal, put the pelt and animal on the horse, draw your weapon, and you pistol comes out.  Even though I was just using the bow and arrow.
I have to assume all the great reviews from the game sites were lies, considering none of them were critical of any points in the game.
The release was delayed a couple of times, and we still don't have the multiplayer set up.
The game is a disappointment.  I have supported Rockstar since the first GTA's, this is the worst Rockstar game I've played.

author: Jeremy Dirr
title: Absolute Garbage (Really Boring and Bad)
content: The most over-hyped game of this generation. A complete failure following the epic design of Red Dead Redemption (the original) and GTA5.

author: Camille Lambert
title: Flight Simulator for cowboys
content:
I was a huge fan of the first game, on which I spent 80+ hours. Waited 2-3 years for this one. The reviews seemed like a no-brainer - best ranked PS4 game of all time. Number ONE.

I was so disappointed. Heartbroken. EVERYTHING is slow and finicky. Walking around is slow. Picking herbs. The progression. Rising a horse. So many systems are confusing. Bounty system. Saving never works properly. The cores are never explained. How to pay a bounty. How to commit crimes.

This game feels like WORK. Excel would be more exciting. It feels like that being an accountant.

Controls are so illogical. Talk is left trigger, shoot is right trigger. One minuscule mishap, and the whole town is shooting you down, and you end up with $100s in bounty - that's a lot of 50¢ animal pelts.  From now on, every one shoots you on sight, so good luck completing missions to get money.

Every single action has a long press. Why? Fishing has the same button to fish and to put away your gear. Means you always put your gear away when trying to fish.

Everything feels so slow and sluggish. There are so many things to do, but I don't want to do any of them.

Walking around in Rocky terrain is so stressful. The character howls in pain when falling off from a height of a foot or two.

Rising is soooo dull. Fetch this there. Talk to the person at the other end of the map. Fetch this letter at the other end. Catch that guy or another. These look like missions we have done a million times in other games, which is fine, but SO MUCH GALLOPING. Basically out of 60 hours of the game, are we expecting to gallop for 50?

I wouldn't be so mad if the horse wasn't so finicky. Every rock or wrong turn makes the horse collapse, red screen flashing, character ends up on the floor.

Overall, the story and main character is exactly the same as the first one. I cannot tell the difference between the protagonists of the two games. Outlaw with a big heart that redeems himself.

The Abigail missions on the main track are so dumb. Basically women are portrayed as harpies that make men run around to save the day. "Save my son" "buy this ranch for me or I leave you"

This is not a game, it's a cowboy simulator. Drab and boring and finicky like a flight simulator. If that's your idea of fun, go for it.

author: Mr. Maguire
title: A little over hyped
content:
If the critic reviews had been more balanced I would have given this a higher score. This game is overall very good but it has some major flaws that I wished had been mentioned in official reviews:

Pros:

The world is beautiful and detailed.
The world is massive.
It feels alive.
Story is good.

Cons:

The controls are horrible, looting becomes a chore because having to pause for everything while you hold X or O.
Slow and clunky movement, having to walk at a snails place in camp and on missions is frustrating.
In missions the game often feels like it's on rails. It forces you to play how it wants. It's more like watching a slow film.
The bounty/honor system is horrible. Bump into someone, instantly wanted and low honor. Shoot at a shooter? Low honor and bounty for you.
The Sadie character felt like it was added to placate the left. It's forced and takes away from the realism.
Overly complicated health/stamina/deadeye system.
Satchell/Weapons holding is stupid.

author: J. Ashley
title: What the H377?
content:
Ok so I figured..."hey its a Rockstar game, I love GTA, its been talked about for a long time, they had red dead 1 to fix all the problems and work out all the bugs....It has to be good right?" Wrong.  I am so disappointed in this game.  I feel like I was tricked and a victim of good marketing.  The only reason Im giving it 2 stars is because its clear they spent a lot of time on the world.  The graphics really arent any better than any other PS4 game out there, the controls are very frustrating and really I could go on and on, its just boring.  I waited until the weekend to buy this game expecting that I would have a hard time putting the controller down. that wasnt the case.

I have had free cheap PS plus games Ive downloaded for free that hooked me more than this game.  I was playing the other night and I literally feel asleep.  Its so bad Im going to be really hesitant to buy the next GTA when it comes out.
 Its like GTA without pretty much everything that made GTA fun. You will literally be riding around on a horse 90% of the time and the game makes it to where you have no choice but to go slow through a bunch a BS dialog. If you read through the reviews even the people that gave it 5 stars still have things to complain about...why are you giving it 5 stars haha? Have you not played any number of other games?  I was expecting it to be ranked up there with...Fallout 4...The Last of Us and so on.  Not even close.

Ive had the game for a total of a week and Im seriously thinking about going to game stop where I bought it and just returning it or something because its that bad and boring.

I was wondering why I didnt see anyone on my friends list ever playing it and now I know why.  Dont fall for the marketing.  Save yourself

author: Thomas
title: Tedious chore of a game livened up by an occasional quest and great graphics.
content:
I keep thinking when I play this game, "if it had crappy graphics, would I still be playing?" I'm not sure what my answer would be, but it isn't a resounding "yes!" It's not a bad game by any means and it's not as much of a letdown as SHADOW OF THE TOMB RAIDER, but damn it's a pain to play.
Mostly you spend time riding through mostly empty landscapes and I'm already tired of the painted vistas. I'm extremely tired of being punished for accidentally hitting or bumping the wrong button, going too fast, going too slow, not picking the right arbitrary option, etc.
The controls are terrible and if you accidentally bump into somebody in town, it'll turn into a fight which will stop everything while the law tries to take you in, puts a bounty on your head and you have to flee town. This also happens if you accidentally hit the wrong button and kill someone when you are trying to simply talk to them. Additionally, you have to be facing the exact pixel to interact with things, and will find yourself dead if you ride too fast and hit a rock or a tree or whatever. Sometimes you will get stuck for no reason other than you can't back up while riding any vehicles. So you FINALLY survived that big shootout and got the cart and then run into a fence from which you can't turn around. Get ready to do it over again. And again. And again.
Plus this game forces you to do an absurd number of menial tasks and do them as complicated as possible. Fishing is an unrewarding chore, but it's not as complicated as drinking a freaking cup of coffee. Every time you get on and off your horse you have to reassign your weapons. There's just way too much busywork that makes it draw out the game longer, so that it seems like it's a long game, when it would be really short if you didn't have to jump through hoops just to do simple things. There's not much to do aside from a handful of side quests that are few and far between and the minigames are just ways to pad-out the games some more. You certainly can't make any more than a couple of dollars playing poker, you get nothing by playing dominoes. If you are into super-slow hunting sims, you will enjoy taking an afternoon to find some prey track it, finally kill it, skin it and then either you can eat it which will give you a tiny, temporary bump to your stats, or sell it for a few dollars in a world where guns cost a couple hundred dollars (about 20x more than they would have in real life). Then again, there really isn't much to buy with your money anyway, so you'll end up spending $20 for an engraving on your rifle that you will never be able to see in game anyway, even with a giant UHD TV. I realize there are a lot of stanch defenders and if you can spend an entire day accomplishing almost nothing and enjoy it, more power to you. If you are thinking this is going to be an open world with lots of stuff to do like FALLOUT or ASSASSIN'S CREED, be warned, it's not.

There is a real sense of history.

author: Phob ISS
title: Bad story line and plot and REALLY slowww gameplay
content:
I thought that they would improve from RDR1 but this game got worse in a lot of ways.

The first thing you should know is that game is really slow.  In almost every way.  Getting from one location to another is slow.  Shoot outs are slow.  Every mission takes a really long time.  You have to stop and do maintenance on your equipment and care for your horse.  It is just a slow game with hours of mindless tasks to take care of before you can continue to advance the story.

The combat system is bad as well.  Zoom in for aiming does next to nothing.  You need to continually use dead eye or you miss nearly every shot.  Which takes more time purchasing the supplies to use dead eye.

The largest complaint is story plot.  In the first ten minutes you understand that the protagonist is making poor choices.  You have no option to change this throughout the entire game.  One poor choice leads to another poor choice to another.  You simply follow this list of poor options till the end.  You cannot improve the character's lot in life or future.  I never felt invested in the character because I didn't want to choose any option I was offered during the entire game.  It is like being offered the choice of becoming a thief or becoming a crook.  The illusion of choice that lead to the same result.  Another poorly planned game story with another terrible ending from Rockstar games.

I played it only because the game was free from a PS4 pro purchase and still was not worth the time I spent simply grooming my horse.
Skip this one.

You could literally spend days playing the side quests and just hunting or exploring without even doing the main story and be perfectly content.  If youre looking for a great game and a great story this is it. Your new favorite super hero will be Arthur Morgan.

author: Andrew Reece
title: Red Dead Redemption 2 Is My Favorite Game Of All Time.  Rockstar Knows Its Business.
content:
I purchased this game when the Red Dead Redemption II PS4 Pro Bundle was released, on the same day the game itself was released, and not off of Amazon. That being said, I want to give potential customers my honest impressions of Red Dead Redemption II, and I'm focusing entirely on the Single-Player Story/Campaign, as opposed to the Red Dead Online portion of it, because single player is what I experienced, and I won't give feedback on something I don't have an honest impression of. Because that would be, wrong. Wrong in this particular instance would be, more specifically, dishonest. I'll talk about the story and characters first, then move on to the technical aspects of the game, like the controls, graphics, & level of engagement RDR2 delivers, on an interactive level, as opposed to an artistic one.

So, where to begin? Red Dead Redemption 2 is a title whose storyline, characters, themes, and subject matter have made such an indelible and irrevocably profound impression on me, that I could go on for days about it and still wouldn't do the title the justice it deserves.

Rockstar doesn't exactly have a shoddy roster of games to serve as a foundation from which to demonstrate their talents in the field of Game Development and ability to write a good story, with compelling characters. RDR2 features a more serious storyline, with characters that, in my opinion, are not satirical in nature, nor are they laced with any form of innuendos. In case anyone is unaware, Red Dead Redemption 2 is a prequel to the first title, serving to chronicle the events leading up to what transpired in RDR1.

The main cast of characters consist of a gang of outlaws and renegades, led by a charismatic rogue by the name of Dutch Van der Linde. His group of outcasts consists of both men and women, which lends itself well to both creating a compelling and accessible storyline. Dutch has a few subordinates who he relies upon to help him run the gang, among them the main character, Arthur Morgan, whom you play as. Hosea, Micah, and Sadie Adler also play integral roles in the events that unfold.

This isn't a story about people living in some fantasy land where everyone gets what they want and they live happily ever after. It's a very somber, violent, and melancholy, chronicle of a band of outlaws with their backs to the wall. It doesn't glorify the life of a criminal, nor does it encourage, through words or deeds, the perpetration of any such acts.

But it is one heck of a great story. It kept me engaged for its duration, even though I had to sink my teeth into it for a good few hours before the characters and plot had me hooked. The attention to detail with regard to the plotline, as well as the voice acting (which is almost entirely bereft of high-profile celebrities, not that high-profile actors are bad. The lesser-known cast of actors did a fantastic job with their roles, however.) Personally, I was pleased to see that Graham Greene lends his skills to the cast. Dances with Wolves remains my favorite movie of all time, and having the guy who starred as Kicking Bird in the game made me smile. I won't go into detail and lace my personal views into how, and why, the game evoked such emotion in me, suffice it to say that it did, the ending in particular. You can create the best mechanics ever for your game and make everything as responsive and attractive as can be, but when you're playing through a single-player campaign, that's not going to keep the ship afloat if you enjoy an engaging storyline as much as I do. So the story, doesn't disappoint. And the soundtrack is absolutely amazing. It has songs that evoke pure, genuine, emotion, both for what's going on in the game, and, for me, what the game reminds me of in regard to my own life.

The graphics, controls, technical aspects of the aural experience (so, the gunshots, ambient noise, etc.), and accessibility of the overall experience all were things I pretty much fell in love with the first time I booted up RDR2. The game looks amazing, from the character models, the environments, particle effects; you name it, Rockstar paid attention to it. In my opinion, Rockstar set the bar for console game development as far as the single-player experience, with this title. Their other games are very, very well done, but as a general rule, I've noticed the level of quality trending upwards with every title they release. Storyline is a matter of conjecture and personal preference, but graphics and playability, while also somewhat debatable, as one particular aspect of the title, which I will elucidate upon shortly, are a bit more consistent in whether people find them to be to their liking.

As far as the controls go, at least, for me, a good part of the equation is boiled down to a single basic concept: does the character I'm controlling do what I want it to do when I'm holding the remote? And, if so, does it do what I want, reliably? This is a pretty cut-and-dry question, which begs a simple answer. And for this game, the answer is definitely yes.

While the controls of the game are mechanically, exactly to my liking, as well as to my preference, the overall pacing of the game is a bit slow. So, how this relates to the controls boils down to this basic idea: Arthur does what I intend him to do, but it doesn't happen quickly. While the level of precision is, in my opinion, very accurate, it happens at a pace that might be too slow for some players, especially those accustomed to frantic, fast-moving gameplay. But it's a game set in the Wild West, not a modern shooter with automatic weapons and grenade launchers.

I can recall someone leveling a remark at the game which called the action "slow, and deliberate," in a tone which was not intended to be complimentary. While neither the action you control, nor the events you witness, move at a breakneck pace, I tend to enjoy a story that unfolds over a protracted period of time, as well as a method of advancing that story (in this case, the control scheme, and level of input utilized to manipulate said control scheme), that requires me to do a little work to fully maximize! I don't say this to give the impression that I don't respect people's preferences, I guess I'm an excitable man by nature, so that bleeds into my writing as well.

I don't judge people based on how they express opinions, provided those opinions are direct and honest expressions, as opposed to being ulterior or deceptive in nature, or intent.

Overall, I found Red Dead Redemption 2 to be the best game I've ever had the pleasure of playing, on any medium, for any system. I loved everything about it, and while it has a pacing that's definitely not for everyone, it was most assuredly, for me. The story was so well-contrived I'd be hard-pressed to find a movie that evoked as much emotion in me. Hopefully you enjoyed reading this review, and were able to derive a positive from it, because I enjoyed writing about this game.

author: Matthew P. Firth
title: Really no fun at all
content:
I give it 2 stars because the graphics are amazing.

The game play just stinks in this game. I litterally can't stay awake long enough to play the game.

The combat is the most boring toned down level of combat I seen ever.

I spent over a hour looking at a horses behind to do a single mission that yielded a measly $60.

Seriously it takes over a hour of nothing but boring horse riding to get anywhere.

You can't shoot someone in the leg and have them limp crawl or even give up they just keep running.

Every kill is just the same old tired roll over in third side scene.

When you shoot someone they just get regenerated later.

If your horse just bumps into a character in the game the whole town will turn out to shoot at you and I post this bounty that is near impossible to pay.

The consequences for doing anything remotely bad are way to severe.

The characters in the game just aren't interesting or memorable at all.

I just found my self struggling to continue to play this game.

And what the heck is up with having to stop and eat, and groom your horse, and maintain weapons... It's such a chore, I think I'd rather clean my toilet or mow the lawn. I don't play video games to do chores maintenance and upkeep: who's terrible idea was that?

It is possible that the game will get better if I stick to it: but for the time being I have lost the will to continue with this bloated monolithic collection of not so fun game play.

For the time being I am personally declaring this game to be a huge dissapointing and am struggling to understand the rave reviews the game is currently getting

I tried to make it fun but it just isn't working for me

title: Starts Slow But is VERY GOOD after that.
content: Most people giving it negative reviews haven’t played for more than 5 hours, you know how i know? because the game is boring at the start, and it almost lost me at the beginning, but after the first 2 hours, it was truly amazing, you go to a town then an amazing soundtrack in the background. It makes you feel like ur advancing in the game. The story is a 9/10 grapics, 10/10. controls are sadly not very good but can be fixed, the combat is a bit boring, takes no skill but its a rockstar game, they are kinda known for that. Play a good 10 hours of this game, if you still dont like it after that then i dont think the western genre is for you. Go play your fortnite becuase i dont think you’ll like anything else like this masterpiece. Now the story is very emotional and you see overtime how the gang or the dutch van der linde gang crumbles over time in a world where the law is taking over. The wild west is waning and the world dont want people like arthur morgan (main character) and the rest of the gang. My tips for trying to like this game is that to play it for 10 hours, remember that no one liked the start. The game gets 100x better after that. fix your controls in the settings. Find other things to do than main quests. The side quests are fun but you dint have to do them. Buy stuff or reward yourself with new weapons and metals and engravings, also buy clothes. try to get attached to the characters early.
