author: Cody Carlson
title: Good, But Not as Much Fun as the First Red Dead Redemption
content:
Read Dead Redemption 2 is a lot of fun, and in many ways is superior to the first Red Dead Redemption.  The game is absolutely gorgeous to look at.  From desert plains to rocky mountains, to dingy swamps, to a New Orleans-like city, the game presents breathtaking vistas and an immersive, real-world feel.  The story sees a gang of outlaws led by Dutch, who continues to promise great things to come.  Arthur Morgan is the main playable character, who begins to slowly grow disillusioned with Dutch's promises and begins to look for his own brand of redemption in the Old West.

I generally like story-driven open world games like this.  Instead of a game it often feels more like an interactive movie.  Though the graphics and size of the game are superior to the original, the first Red Dead Redemption offered a much more intriguing story and more relatable characters.  Also, the control interface was much simpler and more straight forward in the first one.  In RDR2, it takes forever to cycle through your satchel to find what you are looking for.  Other control interface systems are likewise cumbersome.  This is a good game, and if you liked the first Red Dead Redemption you will enjoy it.  Just know that for all the improvements it has over the original, it is just not as fun a game overall.

author: Susan M.
title: Beautiful game to watch and play
content: I am sure it will take me months to get through the main story line but that's fine with me because I am appreciating every last detail that was put into the making of this game. Some scenes are so breathtakingly beautiful - it is exactly how I imagine the U.S. was before all of the industrialization and pollution emerged. I'm still getting used to the controls - there is a LOT going on in the menus but I am here to learn and have fun. This game is a wonderful escape for me; I love getting lost in the characters and story. No video game is perfect but RDR2 comes pretty close to perfection for me.

author: Michael Collins
title: Good Game
content:
I don't really understand the negative reviews for this game.  Yes Arthur controls a little clunky but not really an issue once you get used to it and i really don't think controls are  any clunkier this time around than the in the first.  Rated 4 stars because there are a few issues that make this game slightly tedious but not all what they seem to be made out to be.  Over all i find this game very enjoyable.  Arthur has to eat, has to help feed his camp with hunting but really hunting is part of the enjoyment.  Maintaining your stats by example stopping to smoke or chew during the fights to regain deadeye can be annoying but truthfully the only really annoying part of this game is the frequent dying and very real possibility of permanent death of your favorite steed.  So i find my self manually saving the game every five minutes to have a  roll back for things like unexpected crimes such as bumping into to someone while riding my horse.  Or horse permanent death. I also can't tell you how many skins i have lost from the back of my horse until i started doing this because when i died any skins i had on my horse previously did not return with the reload.. Death is waiting
 I had no sooner got my favorite horse to a high level of bonding when unexpectedly attacked my horse died and before i could revive him i died as well.  The game autosaves but when it reloads if your horse died for example it stays dead.  So feeling the necessity to manual save so i have a rollback every ten minutes can be tedious.  Death is waiting for you it is planned for you and I seriously doubt you can prevent it.  From accidentally riding your horse off a cliff or being kicked to death after accidentally punching a horse or to that bear waiting around the next bend, bandit traps etc.  So if you don't want to have serious setbacks or lose that favorite horse manual save often.  The scenery options and possibility of this game have 7 out of five stars take your time and enjoy it.  Two other tips i didnt realize at first that if i wanted to steal a horse for example to make money in the beginning i could ride the new horse to the stable and whistle for my main horse to follow.  The next biggest step is stealing wagons to sell to your fence.  Don't bother riding way down south to steal the fancier carriages they are not worth any more money and the chances of getting them to the fence in one piece are very low.  Found the game well worth my money still playing taking my time and enjoying .  Felt it was worth my money..enjoy

author: Amazon Customer
title: Good game overall, but predictible annoyances that are very long in the tooth
content:
Rockstar is known for creating immense worlds full of interesting characters and tons of things to do, and RDR2 is no exception to that.  R* is truly the master of that domain.  The game also looks fantastic, and you can find yourself just looking at the scenery on occasion.  Unfortunately, some of the negative things Rockstar is known for are prevalent here too - clumsy mechanics, archaic save options, glitches galore, plus occasional ultra rigid mission structure - and all of these are carryovers from all the way back to GTA3 circa 2001 (can’t say they haven’t had enough time to improve and refine).  Worth a buy, but I’m not sure why Rockstar is given a pass on so many things they could have and should have retooled -> keeps it from being a “5 out of 5” game or GOTY candidate in my humble opinion.

Sidebar:  I haven’t dabbled in the online MP, so I really can’t speak to that.  Might be brilliant, but I’ll defer to others there.

content:
Bought this game based on the hype is received but after playing it almost 40 hours, cannot take it any more. The need to do boring chores is just killing any desire to play and progress further.

The controls are very complicated and not intuitive to the point that in many cases the wrong controls can cause you to kill NPG or someone and later being hinted by the law enforcement. The whole horse and player inventory is so confusing that one can go to battle without their weapons.

Quests are pointless horse riding and so long that are boring as hell.

Gave away the game today to a friend as a birthday present, so don't get mad seeing it on my game shelf anymore. Such a waste of money and time to try it.

author: Mazon Customer
title: Ignore the haters this game is easily the Game of the Year.
content:
After reading pages and pages of negative reviews I felt compelled to address some of the criticisms.

- Graphics are absolutely amazing. Some of the best real world environments and lighting to date on a console.

- Controls are deliberately "mushy". For instance horse riding controls while awkward actually do feel like riding a real horse. A horse doesn't respond immediately to your commands, and a horse sometimes has a mind of its own. I mean it is not a motorcycle it's a living creature. Single action weapons require cocking.. etc. This is not an issue, this adds to realism. I would say the only real issues this game has as far as controls are concerned are minor annoyances and they in no way get in the way of enjoying the game. These annoyances are: slow walking in the camp, you really can't run in the camp which is a bit annoying, having to hold triangle to loot bodies is a bit annoying. But these things as I said are such minor issues that knocking the rating of the game because of them is nitpicking.

- The world is incredibly detailed and vast. It really does feel like a living breathing world out there. Also it is filled with random encounters and things to do.

- This is more of a wild west simulator than an arcade game. Which I guess is probably the reason why some people dislike it. The developer opted for realism over arcade instant gratification. This game make you work for progression, but none of it is tedious or repetitive. As far as the story is concerned, there is really zero grind required. You don't have to upgrade your camp if you don't want to. But even if you're not trying to upgrade the camp, you make so much money from the main mission that you can just easily upgrade the camp later in the game.

- Voice acting is simply top notch. Every single voice actor is perfectly cast. The main character Arthur Morgan in particular has a convincing performance and a great voice. But so do all the supporting cast.

- I have not finished the story yet. I am about 40 hours in, (60% of the story in). And so far the story has been very good. I've experienced a few high points already that felt really good. Writing is believable and it resembles a high quality film production. I feel quite attached to a few characters already.

- Production value in general is industry leading. From animation, facial expressions, lighting, pacing.. every thing feels high quality. Some of the best I've seen in general.

- Sound track while fitting of the theme Rockstar was going for, feels a bit dry. That's not to say that there aren't some absolutely perfect tracks (D'Angelo's - Unshaken is a particular highlight). The game could have used more scores to highlight the epic nature of the world Rockstar has built. Instead we get a more raw and slow soundtrack that has plenty of quiet periods. This was a deliberate choice by Rockstar, and I can't say it doesn't work. It's just I would like more of a movie theme feel to it than what has been delivered.

Any review which lists this game at less than 4 stars is intellectually dishonest. This game pushes boundaries of what's possible on multiple fronts in terms of entertainment in this medium. It is easily one of the Game of the Year candidates.

author: Zephyros
title: Massively over hyped game. I was bored out of my skull; story isn't engaging; controls are clunky
content:
I'm simultaneously glad to see many others having the same opinion of RDR2 as I did, that it's probably the most over hyped game of the past 5-10 years, but disheartened to see 99% of "critics" and game/entertainment related web sites gush embarrassingly over it and claim it's a "Masterpiece" and "the best RPG of this generation consoles."

Fist of all... NO, it's NOT a masterpiece. Not by a long shot. Yes the game is beautifully rendered and realistic but at the same time, it's bleak and barren; yes I suppose there's a lot of quests to do but so far they're VERY repetitive. I've played about 15 hours so far and it took forever to get through the intro and the main tutorials. The story so far is really a snooze fest and I'm having a hard time feeling any bonding with any characters and any drive to continue this story. There are way too many cut scenes and dialogues are way too long and just meaningless fluff.

I agree with many who say the map is just massive... but this is not a good thing like it is in Witcher 3: Wildhunt or God of War or Horizon: Zero Dawn. It literally takes forever to get from one main story interaction to another on your horse. In between is a beautiful landscape but completely void of anything interesting which makes it tedious. Yes there are some side quests to find and places to discover off the main route but from what I've experienced so far a LOT of the map is simply nothing... just pretty landscape.

Yes, I realize I've only played about 15 hours but that's more than enough time for a game to grab my attention, get me interested in the game, the story, the controls and gameplay and start to have emotional investment in it AND especially the characters. RDR2 does none of that and I frankly don't want to wait around to see if that happens.

I've decided there exists a massive disconnect with these so-called "critics" and actual, TRUE gamers definition of a "masterpiece" gaming experience. For critics it appears... especially with RDR2... all they seem to care about is a beautiful, realistic landscape, anticipation with waiting years for a previously fantastic game to come out with a sequel and more story and cut scenes than actual game play. This is more like an interactive movie, not a game. I've concluded either Rockstar paid off a LOT of reviewers to give RDR2 10/10 ratings or most of them simply aren't true gamers and don't fully understand what most gamers want and respect out of a game and what really constitutes a masterpiece. Sorry but a beautiful landscape that looks absolutely real isn't enough to give a game a great score. Games have been rendered amazingly realistic for years now and it's almost expected. This seems to be the main accolade for most of the reviews I've read online.

You know what an RPG Masterpiece is? God of War. Horizon: Zero Dawn. And what I consider to be the best game ever made: The Witcher 3, Wild Hunt. The Witcher has a massive map and sometimes takes you a while to get from one quest point to another but in between is not only the most realistic landscape you can imagine but stuff to explore and discover at every step of the way, under every rock and behind every bush. Not only that, CD Projekt Red was somehow able to create the most dynamic and LIVE world I've ever seen in a game. Cities are flowing with real side interactions, voices, sounds and animations. I sometimes think the sounds in the game are coming from outside my house. The towns, cities and open space in The Witcher 3 is ALIVE... more alive than any game I've ever played. RDR2 doesn't even come close. Hell, I liked Assassin's Creed: Origins way better than this borefest.

I'm giving this game one star because the review of it here on Amazon should reflect what the game is really like and because it is NOTHING like what so many critics are saying. It's honestly a 6/10 for me.  I doubt I'll even finish it. I'd rather get Assassin's Creed: Odyssey or Spiderman with my limited available gaming time. I'm just glad I didn't get the Special or Ultimate editions.

title: Frustrating, bug-ridden game that is very fun to play
content: This game was released with KILLER bugs that make entire important character completely disappear from the story if you do the wrong thing.  Three weeks after release and not a single patch to try to fix any of this.  Ridiculous.  Other competing games are released with bugs, but (for one example) AC: Odyssey received multiple patches in the first two weeks fixing various quest bugs.  For Rockstar to just leave their game in this state is ridiculous.  However, I can't bring myself to give just one star because the game is fun and immersive and good... it's just broken.  If Rockstar ever patches the darn thing this would be a five star game, but three weeks later I think it's time to speak my mind and dish out the 2 star review.

author: The Resident Gourmet
title: Looks like crap on my PS4 Pro!
content:
In addition to the flawed/fake HDR debacle... The game looks terribly blurry/soft focus compared to what I normally get with other PS4 games.

Also speaking as a PC gamer who puts a good chunk of their available gaming time into high performance PC games, I have a really hard time adjusting to the 30fps compared to the locked 60fps I much prefer and am comfortable with on all of my PC games.  The majority of those are played in Native 4k at 60fps.

If the visual quality had been sharper, I could more easily overlook the 30 fps aspects.  But the fact that the game can't maintain a locked 30fps with the Pro, there is really no redeeming qualities left to mention.  I could only tolerate the game up to the second mission, so at I think 2% in, I can't really comment on the actual game play much, except to say that I did see a lot of the control issues others have been focusing on.  I thought it was just me and being somewhat rusty with my DS4 controller and button layout memory.

(I normally use an Xbox One Elite Controller on my PC, so terms like SQUARE, TRIANGLE, CIRCLE, X and which one is R1 vs R2, L1 vs L2.  These are not as ingrained into memory much these days and hard to remember which one is which in the dark while playing the game.  But it appears that a lot of what I was blaming on myself, like the funky weapon wheel issues might be more related to some of these control issues everyone is talking about in their reviews)

I am waiting for the now long over due patch to see if all of these issues are resolved to an acceptable level of improvement.  I have till the 29th to return the PS4 Disc version, and if that patch hasn't arrived by my return deadline, then I am returning my PS4 copy and just waiting for the PC version. I would much prefer seeing the game in True Native 4k (3840x2160) on my Sony 65" XBR 4k HDR TV rendered by my overclocked 1080ti GPU and 7700k CPU.

I have been waiting for 7 years for this game, and so far I am extremely disappointed.  I wish I could have given this a 5 Star review, which the game may or may not deserve for other reasons besides just the horrible graphics fidelity. But for me personally...  I refuse to play it using a version that reduces the experience to a blurry, eye strain inducing mess!

P.S.  To any BLIND and delusional PS4 Pro fanboys who may take issue with my totally accurate assessment of the current state of the PS4 Pro version of RDR2...  You were obviously born without the "Attention to Detail" gene, or simply need glasses.  Either way... You can save your predictable negative commentaries about my frank and honest review of this version for someone who cares.  I will never be coming back on here to read them.

author: The Cool Monkey
title: Most realistic game to date !
content: Playing Red Dead 2 and almost completing it I must say this game is splendid the story is so crisp and easily making it my favorite games of all times. Now, this is a prequel meaning it’s the origin story to the very first RDR that follows John Marston and his epic journey. But let’s start off with gameplay my first  impressions was unsure but over time as the game progressed I actually grew on me it allow me to care even more for my horse and character which is completely different then most games these days to be honest I grew attached to Arthur Morgan making sure his appearance was the appropriate for some certain sceniros if you don’t the other characters around you and will noticed that you haven’t shaved or bathe which it’s extremely immersive even your horse needs to be taken care of and once that happens you’ll bond with that horse and your relationship will grow for an example if your in a gun fight where there’s no where to turn you can whistle and your horse will be there to escort you out super awesome even the hunting is pretty challenging too you can hunt just about anything and there’s territories of legendary animals like a grizzly which you’ll need to be prepare for if you don’t you’ll end up losing trace or eaten haha. When I heard this mechanic was going to be apart of this game I was worried it will get too repetitive and boring but actually I find it fun. Now other than that if you played the first it still has the iconic dead eye which is still epic and addicting but you have to buy things to keep that ability up. Now let’s talk about the icing on the cake the graphics.....Red Redemption is known for its graphics hell the first game still looks super impressive still considering it’s been 10yrs since it’s release. The details are just amazing when your horse moves you can see the back muscles working and can get a feel how powerful this animal is even the people who you encounter feel like actual human beings it’s pretty awesome. So that’s about it for my review I would definitely recommend this game hands down for the 1 star reviews I wouldn’t pay close to attention. I feel like the gaming community these days just want more blowing up, running and cursing than actually enjoy a game that’s telling a rich story and yeah when things spice up then enjoy it. RDR2 is a perfect balance with action and story which delivers in both aspects very well so again do yourself a favor try this game out if you’re hesitant then rent it from GameFly ! If you don’t then that’s perfectly fine everyone craves something different !

If you want a better Red Dead experience just play the first one. Everything about that 10 year old game is better.

author: Mr. Wheeler
title: Irreparably broken mechanics
content:
I don't know if i will show as a varified purchaser but i got this game off amazon.com in the ps4 pro bundle.

 Red Dead Redemption 1 was one of the best sandbox games of all time but it wasn't perfect. Mandatory skinning cut scenes, odd fast draw mechanics, random stuff getting in your way while on a mission and some repetitive tasks were annoying but not to a degree that was very bothersome. Well, in making Red Dead Redemption 2, rock star beefed up all those little things you disliked about RDR1 to a game breaking extreme. Apart from a somewhat bland and slow story with mostly unlikable characters, the problems with this game can be summed up in 2 words. Over complicated. For example. When uaing the lever action, you have to press the action button to fire and then again to cycle the action. And if you do any button mashing  (which you won't be avle to avoid as the timing is so fine) then you will automatically fire aa soon as you are done racking the gun. And sometimes you don't need to for some reason and i haven't figured out the ryhm and reason to it. That is one of the most basic examples. For something more normal. When you skin an animal, you have to go to the extra trouble of putting it on the back of your horse just like with criminals in rdr1 (except they made the process a little more complicated) except, some animals you do, some animals you don't and you have to be paying attention to all of this on the fly while dealing with other potential hazards. And even collecting and armung your weapons has now been turned in to a multiple stage process that you are once again forced to make sure you followed all the steps to while getting shot at and/or chased by a grizzly bear. I can literally go on all day about these little stumbling blocks the game has set in front of you to spend all your brain power worrying about. LITERALLY to the point that what SHOULD be the main theme (riding, shooting, exploring etc.) becomes an after thought. And what's worse, a huge portion of these problems are hard wired in to the game and the game mechanics would be thrown way out of whack to fix them. In short, this is an irreparably bad game. One of the few that is so bad that i can honestly say that playing it was a negative experience.

author: Joel
title: Good
content: Good game

author: Draggon
title: Great Single Player Story, Horrible Multiplayer, Wonky Controls
content:
I bought this game at the local brick and mortar to play with a friend in the online mode.

10 hours so far.

Single player:
+Storyline mode is really good
+Great graphics
-complicated controls.
I will play the single player mode through to the end for sure.

Online is horrible:
-You are forced to play through two missions at the start to learn the controls...even if you have played multiple  chapters of the single player storyline.
-The multiplayer economy is a hyper inflated grind fest. One 30 minute mission in the game paid me $2...a new low end rifle is $180...so it would take 90 hours of missions just to buy one low end item...uh no thanks.
-There is gold you can trade for game cash...it is earned 5c at a time. Of course it can be bought, so every kid with their parents credit card tied to their PS4/Xbox account can rack up lots of charges for marginal gains in multiplayer.

If you are like me and just want to play online with a friend or two, dont waste your money.
If you want to experience a genuinely good Single player game then wait until the game goes on sale.

author: tward
title: Great Game
content: Great game

author: Mark
title: Ages like a fine wine
content:
I actually don't know anything about wine... but Red Dead Redemption 2 gets better the more you play it and the further you advance in the storyline. You MUST be a patient gamer and you really need to allow yourself the time for longer play sessions to get the most enjoyment in my opinion. I could write a 3,000 word review on this game, diving into all aspects of the experience. But you have plenty of professional reviews out there to read. My take is simple: if you enjoyed the original Red Dead but found some frustration and fault in the storytelling (akin to most other Rockstar games) then you will enjoy this game much more. I found this to be the most mature and thoughtful storytelling of any Rockstar game to date. By the time the credits roll I would expect you to feel genuine complex emotions about many of these characters. Highly recommended.

*Note, I have not played Red Dead Online beyond the tutorial so I can't comment on that aspect of the game.

But I literally deleted it, packaged it up, and will trade it for something I like better. First game I’ve ever done that with. Just tedious and waste of time.

author: ClawMan
title: way too tedious character development and maintenance
content:
Whether you like this or not will depend on what you like to do in a game.  My favorite game of all time is Ghost Recon Wildlands.  I can play that game exactly as I choose to - stealthy or full force loud.  I guess I was hoping this would be a game that I could figure a way to play similarly to GRW - set in the beautiful West geography and in an an era which I love.  Instead I find it to be totally ruined by the necessity of extreme, constant continuous character maintenance.

You can't do anything exciting without immediately having to go back to the menus to find what is necessary to repair your character or determine what to do with your loot.  I am spending way more time in the menus than I am in gameplay.  This ruins any feeling of immersion in the game world itself.  Constant crafting, eating, sleeping, bathing, etc is necessary just to survive.  You can't really enjoy the world because you're constantly having to exit it to go to the menus to research what tonic or food you need or clothes you should be wearing.  The health component to the game is overly complicated and figuring out how to keep it tweaked feels more like work than fun. Analyzing which tonic or food works best to develop a certain aspect of your health or stamina is just boring and tedious.  It is way more complicated than it needs to be.  And then you've got to do the same thing with your horse's well-being as well as worrying about keeping all your gang members happy.  This is drudgery that sucks any enjoyment out of the game.  This is really a shame because the scenery in the game is breathtakingly beautiful.  The detail in everything is amazing but I find myself so frustrated most of the time that I can't enjoy it. Any time I find myself in an enjoyable gunfight I know it will be followed by boring time in the menus figuring out how to repair damage done.  I just discovered that there are cheat codes available that might alleviate some of this tediousness, but if you use them - you can't save or even play through the story-line.  Apparently they are only useful in a free roam mode.  If anyone knows a way around this, please share your technique.

As it is, I can't imagine continuing playing this game.  I want to enjoy the game - not read menus, look through inventory, and do research constantly trying to figure out how to maintain and develop my character.  Give us an option to just enjoy the gameplay and environment without spending most of our time just figuring out how to keep our character in surviving shape.  It's just not fun.  I want to stay immersed in the world - not constantly exit to make choices in the menus.

author: DragonOfThynHeart
title: Love this game!
content: Love this game! Arrived undamaged. And was the correct region disc.

author: Christian
title: Worth Every Penny
content:
Honestly, I don’t normally write product reviews, but after beating this game I felt I owed leaving my feedback. There’s countless hours of fun to be had with an amazing story, fantastic graphics, and ridiculously well written dialogue. The world is enormous and beautifully done. The characters are fantastic and you really grow attached to a lot of them. I highly reccomend playing the first game, but even if you haven’t, you can still thoroughly enjoy this one. I haven’t experienced many games with the level of detail and enjoyable moments that this game provides. This is one of those games that would be the equivalent of an Oscar-winning movie.

Edit: After reading a lot of recent negative reviews, I have to insist that everyone should give the game a chance. I bought the game on release day, and surprisingly never encountered any game breaking bugs or glitches. The story does start off slow, but the story and gameplay really blossoms into something special. It’s so easy to get lost in all the random side missions, mini games, crafting, and hunting. Despite a TON of optional side activities, the game never once felt like a grind or a chore. If you’re able to avoid all the spoilers out there, the ending of the story is so well done and emotion evoking. Not to mention after finishing the game, there is an entire Epilogue that only makes it better and creates a sense of added value. I highly reccomend giving this game a shot.

author: Brandon
title: Believe the hype- this game surpasses the lofty expectations.
content: I've been playing games since 1987 and I can say with all confidence- this is the greatest game of all time. It takes the best portions of previous Rockstar games (which were themselves some of the greatest games of all time) and expands/improves/adds to them. It's the first truly revolutionary game in more than 3 years (the last one was Witcher 3). This game shows what a REAL sequel should look like and puts to shame the glorified expansion packs that companies like EA and Ubisoft market as "sequels" every year. Red Dead Online still needs some work, but its still only a beta and the potential is there.

content:
The headline should say it all. This isn't a game you'll knock out in one sitting. Buy it, set aside all other games, enjoy the experience. The developers worked really hard (Some say too hard) to create it and it deserves every bit of praise it receives. It's a story-driven game, set in an open-world, that will have you laughing, crying, and coming into work/school the next day sleepy because you stayed up all night playing it.

This is a prequel to Red Dead Redemption 1, so you don't even need to play RDR1 to fully understand and appreciate this game. In fact, chronologically, you should start with this one before playing RDR1.

author: DM
title: Lots of potential, but incredibly frustrating
content:
Count me as one of the suckers who believed all of the hype and the near perfect scores from the gaming sites.  After playing for a week, the controls are beyond frustrating.  They are just waaay too complicated, because the game tries to do waaay too much.  Going through the overly complex and convoluted menus has to be the worst part, and you have to struggle with it constantly because the game frequently unequips your weapons loadout, and requires you to perform tons of menial chores and tasks to maintain your health, clothes, weapons, horse, status, etc.

I found the main story somewhat interesting, but it's broken up by boring chores like cooking, shaving, hunting, or you have very long stretches of riding your horse (tapping X button) over this massive map with no real fast travel options when youre outside of your main camp.  Also, I HATE that they force you to walk when youre in your main camp...its sooo slooooow.  They force you to walk in many other places also...there are lots of things make the game painfully slow.  Im interested to get through the story, but it feels like a chore just to play the game.  And there are so many other questionable design choices that will confuse you and frustrate you.

And despite being about a group of bandits, the game punishes you severely for playing as a bad guy.  They put huge bounties on you and generate police if you even bump into someone by accident (I'm not joking here).  Fun should take priority over realism.

As far as graphics, it's very obvious that they use the same engine as GTA5, so the visuals are good, but they are nothing revolutionary.  There are tons of little details that went into creating the game world...it impresses you initially, but then the other frustrating aspects of the game will then spoil that very quickly.

So yah, all stuff you probably heard already, but I want to validate that people's complaints are 100% correct

author: J. Smithe
title: What a letdown
content:
This game was a huge letdown. The gameplay is slow, the story is slow, all the mechanics are clunky and tedious. I really dont see how this is supposed to be a good game. Almost every quest is a fetch quest or a escort quest (the two least popular quest types in every RPG). And underlying everything is just this slow tedium for everything. You have to watch a loot animation for every body, watch every skinning (oh and you can only carry a tiny amount of animal parts at a time so hunting is insanely tedious), watch every single drawer and cabinet open when you're looking a house then watch Arthur slowly grab each item individually. It's just painful to play this. I've tried to like it. I've sunk 15 hours into it but it's just so dull that I'm giving up in it.

It might be a good fit for someone who wants a 100% realistic cowboy simulator complete with having to worry about eating properly and bathing while having some of the most abysmal gun play in a current AAA game.

It's a bad game. It really is.

author: Jordan Ridenour
title: Cowboy Simulator
content:
A lot of the negative reviews I see here have criticized the things that I love about RDR2. I like that there are consequences for your actions. It's not difficult to stay away from the law; e.g. make sure there are no witnesses when you rob someone, wear your bandana to remain anonymous, move dead bodies off of the road. And when you do make a mistake in town (I accidentally fired my shotgun into the ground) a lawman will run you out of town, but you can return a few minutes later, no big deal.

For those complaining about the lack of cash flow, you'll have to discover a fence who will buy your stolen items. That's how I make a lot of money, but not too much, which is another thing I like about RDR2. So far, I haven't felt too rich like I do in most games. It's made the game feel much more realistic.

Yes, you do have to do some tasks to keep yourself going. However, I enjoy cleaning my guns, brushing my horse, finding a good spot to camp, and cooking up some meat I just hunted. Which brings me to my favorite part of the game: the wildlife. The varied animals and activity is amazing. I recently came across two bucks fighting to the death. I watched through my binoculars as they rammed antlers for a few moments before one buck fell and the other sauntered off victorious (I of course harvested the dead deer for parts and food). There are so many different animals to hunt or take pictures of.

You will be spending a lot of time riding on your horse, but I don't see that as a bad thing! You'll come across so many unique encounters as you ride. Whether it's strangers, enemy camps, KKK meetings, or things much more nefarious, I've enjoyed it all.

All-in-all, RDR2 is one of the best games I've played. It does have some negatives however. It can be a little clunky, talk and aim are on the same trigger, and I had a legendary animal's carcass disappear from my horse. But the positives far outweigh the negatives for me. There have been several moments where I thought, "Man, I wish I could do this" and then the game showed me how to do it. Kind of eerie, really.

Definitely pick up this game if you're interested in something you can really dive into that requires mindfulness. This isn't a game where you can turn your brain off and play it. 10/10

author: James D Crawford

author: John Doe
title: More Like the Sims than Red Dead - So Disappointed
content: Ugh.  I was SO excited for this game ... I LOVED Red Dead Redemption and waited years for this.  What were the developers thinking???  You have to make yourself sleep, you have to make yourself eat, you have to bond with your horse (brushing it and talking to it), you have to feed your horse, you have to make money and donations to your camp (in multiple versions of resources), you have to manage what you carry on your horse, on your person, and at your camp, you have to have three different outfits (hot, cold, and moderate), you have to change clothes to match the climate.  You can't "run" or fast travel anywhere ... your three modes of travel are, ride your horse, walk at an incredibly slow pace, or walk EVEN SLOWER (sneak).  There are way too many options (multiple scroll wheels during battle to make choices) and at least a dozen versions of "health" enhancers for 4 different kinds of health you have to micro-manage.  You have to micro manage every aspect of your character, but yet ... you can't do basic things like jump on a rock or run, or lasso a person and get off your horse without setting them free.  The endless cut screens are the WORST.  Typical engagement:  watch 15 minutes of cut-scenes so the game makers can demonstrate just how sweeping and grandiose this game is and then engage in a combat sequence.  Try to save ... oops - manual save is turned off every time you might actually want it (like RIGHT before a battle).  Engage in a battle ... oops, because the controls are the opposite of intuitive, and you have had no opportunity to learn them or practice, you flub the battle and die (or your partner dies), so game over.  Load your last check point.  Re-live the 15 minutes of cut-scenes AGAIN ... rinse and repeat.  Very little fun ... loads of tedium.  This is game is so boring.  I don't want to spend dozens of hours doing electronic versions of chores.  So sad and disappointing.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Feel like I'm playing Tombstone!
content:
It seems from some of the reviews that people have gotten too used to games like CoD, that they need that quick hitting fix or a game is 'boring'...

I'm not very far into this game and let me tell you... It's a f'ing masterpiece!

Visually, on my PS4 Pro in 4K HDR, this is the most gorgeous game I've ever laid my eyes on! The lighting, contrast, HDR, details, weather...it's a f'ing movie! I find myself all the time literally stopping on my horse to just appreciate the lighting and unprecedented level of detail in the world that Rockstar made!

And the detail! Holy sh*t the detail! It's what we've come to expect from Rockstar... People may complain about slow movements but, EVERYTHING has detail to it! Picking something up, getting on your horse, holstering weapons, getting behind cover, eating, everything was meticulously thought out! That's called TIME PUT IN and it's to be appreciated especially with how some games are launching these days!

Story wise, so far, it keeps you engaged... Riding with people to a destination. Hiccups along the way bullt in to the story for action. The stories are good and seem to be building up as you progress and unlock more along the way. Very cool how they've tied everything in! Love it!

The most tedious thing is traveling but, IT'S THE WILD WEST! Horse and carriage! What do you expect?! It took DAYS to travel back then! Having to ride a horse for 10-20 minutes honestly gives you a realistic sense of travel and there are things along the way to keep you busy that pop up at random.

Gun fights are awesome! The animations are so cool it's like playing a movie! Combat isn't bad either as the character seems to be environmentally aware. I don't see how smashing someone's head into a bar or wall is boring?! It's how things happened back then! People weren't trained, they just scraped!

Also, weapons and weapon customization are badass! A bunch you can do! Also customize your horse, wardrobe and others things. There's a bunch to do in this game!

I'm probably not even 10% into the game and it just gets better as I progress! It's obvious Rockstar put YEARS into this game and I seriously have to pry the controller out of my hands most times to stop playing and actually be productive lmao...

F'ing masterpiece!!

author: Heyace
title: Rockstar is the Kubrick of video games
content:
I played RDR a lot in 2010-2011, complete play-throughs of the main story and all the side quests, as well as the online version. I found the immersion incredible and after a while, I realized that playing the game was more about being in the environment than just executing the next goal; the environment was so rich, I often found myself avoiding the next main story objective, wanting instead to explore and enjoy the little things.

I think this is one of the reasons I find RDR2 so good. After about 10 hours in, that feeling came back – I just wanted to be in the environment. The missions are fun, and the story is the best story I’ve found in a game, and so, consequently, I’m not in a rush to see it finish; it’s like when you realize you’re watching a really fantastic movie, and you don’t want it to end. A game offers the opportunity to immerse yourself in an environment more fully than a movie, and a correctly constructed open-world game allows you to do it at a leisurely pace rather than race from task to task, and still enjoy the time as it passes. If not, why bother making it open world? The world itself has to be the star of the show, as much as the missions, story, or anything else.

I’ve played most open world games. Character movement is better in other franchises. Gunplay is better elsewhere, inventory management has better implementation examples in any number of other titles. However, as much as I love the other open worlds out there, none is quite as impressive to me as RDR2. The thought put into it is evident. The scale of the accomplishment is impressive. Dialogue between characters is exceptional, and when I compare it to many recent titles it makes them look lazy and amateur. Though it has bugs, I’ve encountered very few, which is a nice, refreshing change compared to the normal bug set I usually get from Bethesda or Ubisoft. This game not only feels polished, it contains all kinds of extra things that have exceeded my expectations in delightful ways. I’m not yet finished with the main story, though I feel like I’m close to the end – and I’m ready to give it the award for best story in a video game. The writing is superb.

I acknowledge that some of this has to do with a fondness and sentimentality for RDR. To their credit, Rockstar seamlessly knitted RDR2’s prequel story into the beginning of RDR, and they knew exactly how to hit all the right emotional buttons for anyone who loved the 2010 title.

There are always negative reviews of things. Some of the negative reviews I’ve read are, of course, not at all my experience. I’m 50+ hours into RDR2 and I’ve loved every minute of it; I don’t want it to end. A lot of it comes down to personal preference. In the seven years between RDR and RDR2 I played a lot of other open world games, and I realized very quickly into RDR2 that the pace of those games was not what the environment of West Elizabeth was all about. I remembered thinking to myself halfway through the game that someone who wasn’t patient was probably going to hate RDR2. Patience has its rewards, and sure enough, it made for an extremely rich, emotional experience story-wise, something I rarely – if ever – get from the other titles I’ve played. There’s plenty of action in this game if you want to engage action, but there’s also the slow pleasure of a casual poker game or a horse ride just to see the sights (as opposed to a ride to get to the start of a mission). Since I find the environment so enjoyable, the game works for me whereas it might not for someone who just wants to execute the main story as quickly as possible.

I’m not unfamiliar with that desire; there are some games where I just want to get to the end because the world isn’t rich enough to hold my attention. With RDR2, as much as I want to complete the full story, I never want it to end…probably because it’ll be another seven years for a sequel.

It’ll be worth waiting for if it’s this well made and executed. Hat’s off, Rockstar. You’re like the Kubrick of video gaming. Not a lot of output, but when you do…wow. Thanks for the good work.

author: A. Hsiao
title: Lots of Options In The Game
content:
I preordered this game from my local store and was really excited Red Dead Redemption 2 (RDR2) finally got released. The delays that pushed the release dates are well worth the wait. My preorder came with the war horse which you could finally use after you start chapter 2.

Let's start with the graphics:
Amazing. Absolutely Stunning. The details put into it is why I love this game. I have a regular Playstation 4 and the game runs just fine. Theres no visible lag or graphic issues. The fan may run a little loud because of the graphic intensity but not a big problem. This game puts in details in every aspect - horses, trees, wild animals. You name it and it'll be okay.

Control:
I see a lot of people complaining about the controls. I personally wasn't too bothered by it. The game teaches you what to do and you'll eventually get used to it. I didn't like the controls at first but then it grew on me. You can also customize the controls if needed. The challenge when learning controls, I would say is that the popup is pretty quick and usually when you do a mission. Hard to focus on both things on the screen.

Gameplay:
The beginning of the game may seem kind of slow because of all the horseback riding and talking but be patient and then you'll finally be able to explore. I like how a lot of things matter in this game. From the clothes you wear, your hygiene, beard, the amount you sleep, etc. What really made me love this game are customizations. I can customize anything from my outfit, horse, beard. The things you can think of, you can probably do in the game. With that said, I recommend trying to do the missions more to unlock things such as guns and horses. If you just free roam, you'll have a lot of fun but not everything will be unlocked. There's lots of challenges in this game, from hunting animals for food and collection to planning a heist without being discovered. Rockstar makes it as realistic as possible. Overall, I really enjoy this game and can see myself playing this game for months.

My advice would be, be patient, the story and game gets better. There's a lot of horseback riding, but later on you can unlock things such as stagecoach rides or train rides. Overall, an excellent game.

author: Dennifer
title: Extremely Average & Overrated
content:
Read the title. The hype wagons have been circling for sometime now and man have they paid off. Rockstar has smashed the record for opening sales, but does this equate to the best game ever made? If you are one of the very few (and smart) who didn't pre-order this game, this is for you.

2. The controls are so poorly implemented and immersion breaking. This is my biggest gripe. You feel this from the second you pick up the remote. Its like playing a character with two left hands and two left feet (it literally feels like Assassin's Creed 1 - you heard me). Truly how they managed to mess this up in 2018 is somewhat of a mystery to me. Auto aiming was a big mistake, but absolutely AND obviously necessary due to this failed system. It's anything but smooth. There are so many ways to do things and you have to remember them all. As a cherry on top, there are invisible walls everywhere to break the illusion that you can go anywhere you want.

2. The first thing you will hear about this game is how good the graphics are. Sorry, but the graphics are sub-par. Having just come from Odyssey, it's truly jarring what a blurry mess this game is by today's standards. The level of detail gets a solid YES, but actual graphics, no way. The character models, especially the faces, are the worst offenders here. Clearly the detail level in the world forced corners to be cut elsewhere. At times it feels like 720p on my PS4 Pro/4k TV.

3. SLOOOOOOW and boring. The story is just so slow paced. I can't emphasize this enough. There just nothing that really draws you in. This is further exasperated by how large the world is, yet how little there is to do on the way. At first you marvel at the beauty and level of detail... Which gets very old very quickly when you realize there's nothing to do. It just becomes a chore - You are working and not getting paid.

4. Lastly, the game just isn't that fun. I can't say it any plainer than that. I've played games with all the aforementioned problems and yet they still managed to be fun. This one just isn't.

Overall, I bought into the hype and regret it now. In 2018 it's just not acceptable for a AAA studio to produce sub-par game design like this. The fact that they will make hundreds of millions from all the pre-orders is a slap in gamers' faces. This is the first game I've pre-ordered since the Diablo 3 debacle and once again have been reminded why never to do that. Shame on me.

Rockstar had a lot riding on this one (especially with all the bad publicity from 100 hour work weeks) and I've never been more suspicious of a AAA studio paying for fake reviews. The best way I can describe this game - its like watching a slow-paced blurry movie that allows you to push buttons sometimes. Could've been so much more.

author: Vincent
title: Day In A Life Of An Outlaw
content:
The game has high emphasis on characters, story and world building. If you're looking for an open world game filled with non-stop fluid action this game may not be for you.

-Story.
This game is a prequel to the original Red Dead Redemption, but is a self contained story. There are some references for those who played the previous game, but not required to play to get immersed into the story.

Plot: The world is no longer a lawless land. You and your outlaw community is on the run from the government and try to survive day-to-day life while in-fighting with a rival outlaw community.

Game is a very slow burn. In fact the first few hours is basically a walking simulator (if you keep auto aim on by default). For those who just want to run-and-gun and watch consistent over-the-top action cinematic, you will be disappointed. There's a lot of in-game dialogue between characters flushing out the world and relationships between them, so a lot of causal banters between action sequences. There could be large stretch of traversal land and fetch quests before a large shoot out action sequence occurs.

Gameplay.
Can be played in first or third person. The latter is preferred as the game is optimized for it (random frame rate dips in first person)

You have to keep track of stamina and health of yourself and your horse. But it's very passive and won't we using up resources constantly. You also have to keep your weapons maintained and cleaned for optimal performance/accuracy during shoot outs.

Game also has an RPG element; as upgrades are based on how much you use of an ability, weapon or stat. There are also in-game purchasable upgrades

Aiming and shooting is similar to other Rockstar games like GTA series, Red Dead Redemption, and LA Niore where there's a small dot  reticle you have to aim through.

Guns/shooting has a nice weighted re-coil to them making it feel realistic every time you take a shot. Running/walking animations are a bit stiff, but you get accustomed to it overtime

Melee combat is bad and result in blocking and punching at opportune times based on enemies' televised attacks

There's an eagle eye special that's on a cool down. When used, you go into slow motion and can aim at multiple enemies by moving the cursor over them before shooting them all at once.

Game is very mission based. Most especially in the beginning fells like fetch quests given by your outlaw community members who do recon missions, but need muscle or a gunslinger to finish the job.

There's a moral system where majority of the choices results in to kill or spare a rival outlaw member or a witness to the crime you committed. This at times the choices are difficult as you know from the outset that you're part of an outlaw community hated by the government. There is pay off though as if you choose to kill they'll be less random enemy encounters, conversely if you spare the right people prices of items may cost less or you may get more side missions with rewards. Depending on your morality level at the end of the game, you will get different endings

You also have to upgrade your camp for weapon/resource upgrades and fast travel.

The amount you can carry is limited, so some inventory is equipped on your horse. So when going on missions or hunting you have to swap/manage the character's inventory and the horses'

Clothing you wear, if you plan to shave impact the world in terms of climate (how fast stamina drains in cold weather for example) and wanted level of how you look like when you're first caught doing the bad deed. For the latter, if you change clothes or shave/grow out beard some people may not recognize you from the wanted posters.

The game is very massive with a 2 disc set on PS4 (most of it probably from numerous in-game dialogue/cut scene). The map will slowly open up as complete more missions from your camp are completed. Main campaign can take upwards to 50 hours to complete especially if you explore and do side activities.

-Graphics
Very good. Love the draw distance, weather, and light/shadow effects. At times the graphics can be a mixed bag, but overall very good for a large open world game. Very nice attention to detail from the tracks left in the snow/mud, to your horse randomly taking a#2 as you're walking around talking to NPCs

Overall, very good game for those who are into old Westerns with character relationships/banters, and don't mind the slow pace. Very enjoyable game if you put in the time investment

author: David Scicutella

author: Jon
title: Huge world, great detail, time economy for an open world game
content:
Missions run about 15 minutes each, making plug-and-play very easy. The game world is amazing and expansive, and there's dozens of activities which have layers in themselves. For the first 30 hours, I was easily getting lost (if you want, the game has a very convenient compass and map to avoid this in case you don't like getting lost) and spending hours enjoying just the scenery of the world and randomly generated scenarios that pop up.

This is the perfect game for an adult gamer with a life, who wants to plug and play something either relaxing or focused and hectic at will. So far, I think I've gotten 45 hours of content out of it, and it says I'm not even half-way done yet.

Great value, and easily one of the better video games ever made.

author: James C.
title: Great game, tons to do, awesome graphics
content: Love this game - the open world is fun to explore and there are seemingly infinite things to do to stay entertained for a long time. I've been casually playing for a few weeks now and I feel like I'm just getting started.

content: I have been playing for past 3 hours. I literally feel like I am in west world. Even when I am not playing, those thoughts are lingering in my mind. Excellent narrative and excellent graphic. Folks just get it and go into that world.

author: Monsieur Valentine
title: So 2008
content:
When a few gamespot employees were caught describing the pre-release demo of RDR2, boring and slow, they quickly retracted their statements on twitter.

Unanimously applauded as one of the best games of all time, RDR2 has gone on to be rated 10/10 by most of the mainstream gaming publications. I had to purchase a copy and try this game on day of release. Apparently this was going to change gaming forever?!

After 20+ hours of gaming. I can confirm to you, that RDR 2 is not going to change gaming forever. It is nothing more, nothing less, a Rockstar game. And it plays like it has always played. Any other claim is rubbish and I am suspicious of the legitimacy of many gaming publications that declared this game to be much more.

RDR 2 will go down in history as having one of the most underwhelming introductions of all time. At least the first few hours, your excitement deflates while you painstakingly run though the tutorial. Its slow, sluggish, tedious.

And although RDR 2 gets better, its still slow, sluggish and tedious to some extent at all times. And thats what hurts this game the most. Want to play poker... its slow, sluggish and tedious. Want to raid a room, its slow, sluggish and tedious. Want to fish, you guessed it, slow, sluggish and tedious. It zaps the fun out of the whole experience.

The controls in this game never feel right. At times having to tap tap tap to get your character to face the right direction to LOOT. Constantly mashing 'X' to get him to run faster. Its frustrating. The swapping of weapons, scrolling through items, the interface is never quite seamless and mostly still cumbersome after so many hours.

In true Rockstar fashion the game never really gains any traction with the story, most of the dialogue is laborious. You meet characters and you share a few words. Rinse repeat. Your actions never truly effect your world, except for Rockstars "Wanted" system. Which nowadays, basically means, if you run too hot, the law will kill or arrest you and you lose a few bucks and then everything goes back to normal.

The skins you are rewarded in this game for hunting perfect pelts is incredibly annoying. Specially when for most of us, thats a big part of the gaming experience. What do I get for this?.. silly items like a rams head on my tent post, or an upgraded rug next to my camp. A visual upgrade at best, but what the heck do I care for it.

The game needed to explore way more RPG elements. By end of Chapter 2, I was pretty much finished with upgrading my character and his skills. Thats insane.

I have complained for a while now. Rockstar has an incredible production department. The graphics and scope of the environment is beautiful. But the innards of the game, the RPG element, the story, the ideas and the interaction is letting it down in 2018. Playing mini games like dominos and poker is not a fulfilling endeavour. Its not good enough anymore. That is so 2008. And, holding R2 to chop some wood...bah... its just a monkeys game.

author: Jen
title: Spoiler free review
content:
Red Dead Redemption 1 was and is still among my favorite games, if not at the top of my list. The gameplay, the story--I have played through the game more times than I can count and each time is just as enjoyable as before. I waited eight years for another game, and, at first glance, Rockstar provided a prequel that was worth the wait, though still cannot touch the charm of its predecessor. However, after hours of gameplay, I find myself struggling to finish the game.

The controls are basically the same, though more complicated. RDR2 focuses more on realism, immersing you into the world. Dead eye mostly works the same, though it does not recharge as it did before, which makes it worthless half the time unless you are constantly using tonics to recharge it. Keeping them on hand isn't the issue, but the hassle of going into your inventory in the middle of a fight multiple times is just tedious and not worth it. Still, gun fights are about the same as they were in RDR1, so you can get by without dead eye most of the time, it just makes it less fun.

The new horse system is one thing that has greatly improved since RDR1. I loved my horse in RDR1 and would get upset if anything happened to him. Shoot my horse? I'm going to be more pissed then ever. RDR2 improves on your relationship with your horse. You bond with it, which opens up more options for you, such as telling your horse to follow or stay, and increases your horse's stamina and health. Your horse will trust you more the stronger your bond. Personally, I prefer to catch horses in the wild over buying them--it feels more like it's MY horse that way since I'm the only person he/she has ever known. Aside from a few special ones, wild horses do not have the speed of the most expensive ones in the stable, but speed doesn't matter that much in the game. I feel that breaking in a wild horse is much more satisfying than simply purchasing one in a stable. But the horses seem much slower in RDR2 and you are constantly hitting X to keep at a good speed.

Your horse's saddle is where your gun inventory is stored. It takes time to remember to grab your guns off the horse before walking away. This sometimes becomes a pain, especially when the game randomly replaces the gun you want to use with another one and your horse is no where around. I had an incident during a story mission where my bolt action rifle was suddenly replaced by my Lancaster repeater. It wasn't the end of the world, but disappointing since I love my bolt action rifle. The inventory system makes the game more realistic, however it is still a video game, so it is a system I could have done without. That said, it is sort of satisfying to watch Arthur swap out guns on the saddle for some reason.

The wanted system in the game is one thing that needs improving. Just defending yourself from robbery can get you a bounty for murder. Riding too fast through town can get you wanted, especially when a person changes directions and you collide with them. I had a guy on horseback run into me one my horse, which made my horse tumble, landing on top of me, and I was wanted for unarmed assault due to this collision, forcing me to flee the area and return later. I don't know if Rockstar intended it that way or if it will be patched later on, but it makes being around people and in towns more of a hassle than anything.

The story is a long one that starts off slow so you can get used to the controls. Arthur is a very likeable character. He's no John Marston, but he has his own charming personality that you grow to love within a few hours. Anyone who played RDR1 could probably guess going into this game that things are going to go bad, and they do. Without giving away any spoilers, you start off right after the Blackwater job where John was shot (mentioned in RDR1) and things get worse from there. In chapter five the story starts to become extremely depressing, and only gets worse in chapter six, so much so that I am struggling to finish it. This is my main gripe with the game. I knew going into the game that people would die, I just did not expect some of the events that make the story so depressing that you wonder if you even want to finish it. Rather than have it quick and done, it is drawn out over HOURS of game play. Some of the story feels repetitive, too, and is reminiscent of GTA V. You continue the story hoping that something will get better, except it keeps getting worse. Rockstar does everything to immerse you into the world and then reaches into your chest, pulls out your heart, and stomps on it.

The game is definitely an impressive one. Years of perfecting it show and everyone who worked on the game should be proud of what they created (and I certainly sympathize with the ridiculous hours they worked to finish it). Nature feels alive and is a joy to watch. I once even saw a fox chasing a rabbit, accidentally killed the fox with my horse, then skinned it while the rabbit ran off. I saw a grizzly bear fending off a pack of wolves--that one I avoided and continued on my way. I've seen a hawk dive down and fly away with a rattlesnake in his talons. If it were not for the depressing story and broken wanted system, I wouldn't even hesitate to give the game a perfect review. Every game is going to have minor flaws--nothing can be perfect, but RDR2 comes close. If you didn't like RDR1, you're not going to like this one. It isn't a fast-paced GTA with horses: it's a lengthy western with depth and many, many side activities. Hunting alone can entertain a person for hours. It will never take the place of RDR1, but I don't think anything will ever compare. As it's own game, it is enjoyable...up until the story puts you in tears for days.

author: Gordon
title: That's a nice horse, oh! that's your beard.
content: I bought it through PS4 store. Through chapter 1 & 2 you will learn all the mechanics and everything from fishing to poker will be opened up to you. Game feels slow and can drag sometimes with long horse rides, but that makes the game feel big. Sometimes I didn't enjoy it (riding) and others I did, leading my horse on a high mountain trail and seeing some of the nooks and crannies was nice. Speaking of nooks and crannies there are a lot. Hunting legendary animals and taking on bounties to treasure maps and a serial killer to track down to name a few of the better ones. Others like finding all 10 dinosaur bones sites might not appeal to everyone. One thing I like is if you commit crimes and it can be tied to you, the bounty will stay on you until you pay it off. Bounty hunters will keep tracking you down if you linger in one place too long. Voice acting is good and story works well also. Arthur can grow his beard, hair, get dirty or keep himself clean cut, all up to you.  On top of that don't forget to refill your health and stamina by eating or sleeping. He can also be an honorable man or a rotten one. One the best games of the year for me. Go find those banjo playing freeks (hills have eyes) and couples that lure you into their home to rob you. Hope you somehow come out on top or you'll be gator meat.

author: mark
title: Boring
content: Way too much ground to cover on a horse...spend hours riding to complete goals....controls are clunky and jerky...this game was overthought

author: VIPER22HUSKY
title: Game of the year
content: Don’t listen to these stupid low reviews. They are from people that play nonstop call of duty and are used to non-stop action in little spurts. This game is an interactive, cinematic masterpiece. If you’ve never played red dead before, go in with that mindset and you’ll fall in love with this game. For those that played the first red dead, like myself, you should love this game even more because you get to find out the history of the gang that John marston was part of and what led to the events of the first red dead. Word of warning, again, to those that expect a first person shooter, quick in and out experience. This is not that game. This game is meant for you to get lost in and explore for hours, and I mean hours. I’ve played over fourty hours, exploring, fishing, hunting, helping strangers, looking for treasure and I’m not even half way through the main story line missions. It’ll be hard to dethrone this video game masterpiece!

author: William Masten
title: All that hype for a terrible game!!
content:
Maybe it is just me, but I play video games to escape my daily life and routine. I want to be transported to an amazing world and experience a wonderful story. There is none of that in Red Dead Redemption 2!
I get that people enjoy the reality that is now achievable in modern gaming systems, but not at the cost of fun. I had no fun playing this game because you don't play it, you just take care of the main character. It's like a more advanced (and less fun) Tamagotchi. You have to feed, bathe, dress appropriately, and maintain a sleep cycle for the main character. Same goes for your horse. Almost all of which in real time.
Speaking of real time, your travel is also in real time, *although I didn't play long enough to find any sort of fast travel. You end up spending an hour riding to a single mission (not too fast or your horse dies and is gone forever) where you beat some guy up to collect $10 and then spend another hour riding back to camp to spend that $10 on food for you and your horse. I'll admit that the graphics are amazing, so that 2 hour long ride is beautiful, but that is the only thing this game has going for it, in my opinion.
I had read similar reviews complaining about the daily maintenance of the character/horses, but I decided to give the game a shot because of the hype. Complete waste of money. I tried powering through until the story got better, but I honestly despised every single character, hated the terrible controls that change at random with no warning, and loathed having to make sure I wiped the main characters a$$ just right so they wouldn't chafe and lose stamina more rapidly.
Long story short, if you enjoy the open world of The Witcher or Horizon Zero Dawn, RDR2 is nothing like those games. Save your time, money, and frustrations with this game and just buy a Tamagotchi instead. You'll thank me in the end.

author: peacemaker

I will look at the amazing scenery if I want to.  Seriously, the travel scenes are way too long.  And everything just seems like mashing a lot of buttons instead of grab and go.  I don't know... there are a lot of RDR fans here who are happy right now. I am a first timer of this game.  I've been playing for 2 hours waiting for something good to start.  Now I just think I will go to bed.  I'm sick of watching their movie clips, I want to PLAY.

author: Michael S Roark
title: Immersive

But in these days of instant gratification in games and life in general, it’s refreshing. Just get comfy, grab a drink and “stay awhile a listen”

author: Rob the Toolman
title: The FINEST game EVER produced
content:
I don't normally write video game reviews because there's an entire profession of people who do that for a living.  I make an exception for RDR2 because I've seen more than a couple of these professional reviews complaining about various aspects of the game - and as someone who has played through 80% of the story after about 70 hours I can tell you that all the criticism is ridiculous; this is the finest game produced for any platform to date.

Have you ever read a book, or watched a movie that made you feel something other than entertained?  Genuine emotions of excitement, humor, joy, or sadness?  This is where RDR2 shines - it fully immerses you in the world and its characters with never before seen realism, graphics and acting.  This is the book that you start reading again as soon as you finish the last page- the movie you stay seated for in the theater to watch multiple times.

Rockstar has created a masterpiece.

author: Briana Underwood
title: Love it!
content: Love this game!

author: Scarlet Jester
title: Best Game Ever
content: It's a great game, definitely must own. I've beaten it and have little to no interest in 100 percent completion, as you know is usually a big downside to games with a reward given upon a super lengthy completion. As my general game experience is naturally changed with the storyline, I have restarted my game from the beginning. It would have been useful to be aware that in chapter 5 you must manually save your game if you want to just have fun and explore the game with the same original setup. The german character at the camp is a big failure to me because he is cold-hearted and nazi-like and generally a horrible person everyone wants to be rid of which is somewhat disturbing, but not really. I am not displeased with the writing and storyline but rather amazingly pleased with the storyline of GTA V in comparison. I don't think cinemas should be the focal point of game design, but they are great for people who some reason want to have a game/film combination. Technical problems are few, which are the camera having Depth Of Field Effects, an option that you can turn off in GTA V and now is permanently stuck to on. Also any weapons you have in your loadout go from your loadout at random times to out of your loadout and stored on your horse which flees hastily from you when enemies attack. Like when you set up camp, you have 2 large weapons in your inventory and you get up and continue playing, unaware your weapons are now stored back on your horse until you are in combat. These problems are widely known and talked about so I assume they will be patched. Plus, the game is too amazingly well done to look at these as major problems. The same goes for the Motion Blur which is not able to turn off, there is a problem not only on my regular HD TV, which seems to be this model of tv's weak point, but also hardcore gamers with their Playstation 4 new version and 4K tvs, which I assume will be patched in an update as well at some point.

author: sparks
title: Miserable scripted monotony
content: Rockstar has burned its last bridge with me. I'll never buy another one of their games. I put about 100 hours into this game and it's the same crappy experience as GTA, where no matter what you innovate or accomplish, the script dominates everything. I worked very hard to save up $8000, including finding several of the hidden treasures, but then by following the story missions, I ended up shipwrecked in Cuba and lost everything. Now I'm back where I started, no money, no horse, none of my purchased weapons. Starting all over from scratch. I'm royally pissed. This game is huge waste of time. You can do exactly what the script says. Not more, not less. Do anything at all innovative or independent, and it will be taken from you. If you take the machine gun nest at Hanging Dog Ranch (with considerable difficulty), guess what your reward is? Yep. It disappears forever and you never get to use it again. Even in the simplest things, like if the mission says you have to get to Shady Bell from Van Horn, and you are smart and think to take the train... Nope. A big middle finger from Rockstar. You can't take the train. Why? Because they say so. I hate this game. They corner you into being a sad little button pushing drone, doing exactly what you're told, walking as fast as they say you can, to stand exactly where they say to stand, etc. It's all kinds of fancy in appearance, but it isn't fun. I have more autonomy and interesting options for a dynamic experience when I'm wiping my hairy a*. Graphics don't make up for a terrible player experience. One more customer lost forever. I watched these ratings during the release. A huge number of 5 star ratings were posted in mere hours. My guess is employees and stock holders driving sales. If it's a shallow review, take that into consideration. The detailed experience is miserable scripted monotony.

author: Lnx
title: Beautiful, but slow and frustrating and tedious.
content:
It sure is beautiful, but progress is slow, tasks are frustrating and often tedious. It's not that it's difficult, but a lot of the game is needlessly complex, like gun maintenance, perfect hide collecting (required for progress) and horse cleaning - if you only have an hour or two a night to play, you're gonna forget it and be lost.

The cover in combat was particularly frustrating, deaths sometimes feel unfair.

 If you value realism over all else, you might appreciate it but I got bored and frustrated quickly.

author: kathy
title: Great
content: Daughter loves it

author: John
title: Considering the praise, its frustratingly boring.
content: Considering all the praise being heaped on this game. I was very suprised at how unenjoyable an experince it has been. It has a lot of problems. The biggest is just being flat out boring. I've played 5 hours and there has been nothing to hook me in. Just boring, slow, emptiness. Now I thought that Octopath Traveler had a boring story (which it does) but there are other redemptive parts of that game like the combat. The gun play here is trash. Considering uncharted is 3rd person coverbased they should have just copied that and saved on the 100hr work weeks. This is being hailed as the next step forward. With that in mind I have to compare it to a game that was the next step forward The Witcher 3. Within 5 hours of starting The Witcher I was having a blast from the combat to a compelling story and world. Red Dead 2 has none of this and while there are many technically inferior games they have some redemptive quality. Red Dead has no redemption. I feel jipped by not only Rockstar but also by all the mainstream reviewers who have done nothing but heap praise on this heap of boring hyperbole.

author: Unbiased67
title: a really good game, but to be frank it was a lot for me.
content:
Rockstar games has always kept me entertained. I never get downloads unless it was a game from the last decade. I always buy disks to reduce the number of bugs. Which by the way comes with two CD's for the download. This is a huge map and in this game one racks up a large body count. So looting bodies takes awhile, the historical aspect and reality of the game catch you off guard. For example after ambushing a camp the police will come to investigate and unless you are in the middle of nowhere yes if you create havoc especially in town the sheriff will be after you.

The game could of taken more time to explain how to play but I suppose that will come with more time on the platform. Bear attacks actually scared the hell out of me. I have seen legit bear attacks and I was not having that. Again it's a game that took a long time to develop but frankly its such a huge map, and I 'm growing up so video games dont really appeal to me as much. I'm glad I got it, you decide to get it enjoy!

author: Jeff
title: Awesome game but worried about this cough

author: Amazon Customer
title: RIDE WITH ME!
content:
This game is certainly not perfect, but the negatives are so vastly outweighed by the positives, the game still deserves five stars.

Other games have better graphics, but RDR2 is undeniably beautiful. Especially the landscapes.
Other games have better controls, but most of my frustration came from trying to rush through something too fast and crashing into someone or something.

Where this game truly shines is in immersion and storytelling. With the combination of music, voice acting and cinematography, this game delivers so many amazing sequences.

My advice is to take your time. Enjoy the world. It's alive in so many ways.

content: Takes a bit to get used to the controls.  Takes a lot longer to finish, because you'll wander off in search of perfect pelts, or trinkets, or rumors, or what have you.  What a story.
