author: Amazon Customer
title: Absolute Gem! Negative reviews are completely unwarranted (todays gaming youth rant)
content: First and foremost WOW, just wow. Rockstar has gone above and beyond with this one. This game is an absolute masterpiece, from gameplay to visuals and the music. I haven't been this engulfed/consumed by a game in a very long time and man does it feel good. I haven't woke up wanting to play a game in ages. I was honestly starting to lose hope. I read through a lot of the reviews and was questioning buying this game. That is until I dug a little deeper. With so many negative reviews about I had to understand why. The truth of it is, today's gaming youth has no clue how to appreciate the mind-blowing experience this game delivers. They are stuck on instant gratification, receiving everything for nothing, pleading for all the glory within a 20 min window of gameplay IE Fortnite. No depth, no meaning, no adventure, I've never seen a more lifeless game in my 30 years of gaming. I played 2 matches and never touched it again because there was nothing there, ok so I beat out 99 players and win, and for what..... Absolutely nothing. Nothing of any meaning anyway. Red Dead (if you are not apart of the group above) Grabs you right from the start. It's above and beyond the game that I expected and I still have so much more to do. Had to write this review because I see far too many kids writing reviews without a shred of intellect and they are just plain wrong, not a matter of opinion here I am stating facts. This game may not be for everyone, that is understandable. However, if you could think on your own like most of us adults do, you would know such a thing before buying it and not waste your money while leaving a crap review in the process. I do not buy games that do not interest me, say dragon ball z not that they are bad games, I just know what I am into and that is not it. That's what I feel like is happening here, kids "I love fortnite, whats read dead, oh this game sucks" they just have no clue how to appreciate something so intellectually above them, So for all those that get butthurt by this stick to your sweet skins and zero depth games, while I sit back, immerse myself in an unforgettable story, with memorable characters, stunning dialog, on point music and experience all the glory that is RDR2.

author: CGMaine
title: The Wait Was Worth It!
content:
However, please don't make us wait that long again!

I didn't think I could like anyone better than John Marston and I actually did not like Arthur Morgan in the beginning. However, his sense of humor quickly appealed and his character arc was one that, even if you knew how it was going to end when you began playing the game, you hated to see unfold. Arthur has easily, for me, taken over John's spot (John in his younger - more immature - days was still very likeable...but an idiotic douche at times ha ha).

The gameplay is amazing and even when you're just running around the countryside very entertaining. Sooooooo many side missions and stuff to do aside from the main storyline, fantastic! Tons of animals to study and hunt, I loved that there were so many. There are some annoyances, mostly revolving around transportation abilities, but then I just tell myself I get to spend extra time with my horse and who knows what I might run into along the way. However, I still wish there were better ways to travel to anywhere when you're not at camp rather than the "cinematic button."

author: JShirley
title: Next Gen Open World
content:
This is one of those games that has so much to do in its world, you are almost overwhelmed. I need money to buy new equipment. I need to go hunt. You could spend many hours playing this game strictly as a hunter. Maybe you want to hint people? Bounties are posted in towns and provide decent income. Maybe now you’ll do a few story missions. Maybe you want to hunt for treasure? Maybe you want to take down legendary animals to craft rare gear? Maybe you want to hunt for bandit camps so you can rid the world of their filth? Maybe next you want to donate money to your camp fund for upgrades to the camp, which in turn will benefit you? So much to do in this open world. At one point, I found a severed torso hung up under a bridge with a cryptic message written next to it... looks like a murder mystery.

The first two or three hours of the game are designed as a tutorial/establishment of story and characters. Judging from some of these reviews, there is a generation of people that can’t remember a time when it was okay to slowly build up a story, and not immediately throw explosions and action in your face. I guess the battle royale games have created a faced paced, almost crack head like need for instant action. I read one review where they were complaining about having to ride horses a lot. It’s a cowboy/outlaw Wild West game... what did you expect? That’s like complaining that there is too much driving in GTA. Bottom line, this is a great game. The attention to detail is second to none. When you shoot your guns, they will eventually get dirty, requiring a cleaning. When you are walking up or down a steep hill, small rocks and pebbles start to roll down the hill behind you. The animal A.I. Feels very authentic. Hunting is fun and immersive. Random encounters are well thought out and numerous. Upgrading guns is interesting and fun. The way people interact with each other and your character is realistic. You ever walk around in real life bumping into people... they are gonna get pissed. They get pissed in this game. Be careful not to stand in front of someone and stare at them, they will get mad.

To sum it all up. I can understand someone not enjoying a game, and giving it less than 5 stars, or whatever. But to give this game a 1/5 is just completely wrong and lacking reason. I am having a blast with this game.

author: tdskirst
title: Slow-burn, but TOTALLY worth the early drag
content:
OK, I get it, the game has a very slow start. It's hard to appreciate the deliberate pace coming from God of War, Spider-Man and Assassin's Creed. In fact, by the end of Chapter 1 and the beginning of Chapter 2 I came very close to returning the game altogether. I came within minutes of dozing off, controller in hand.

HOWEVER, I am SO glad I stuck with it. When the world became overwhelming I did a bit of research (Google lol) and got through soem not well-explained aspects of the game, but the main and side quests are exciting, suspenseful and so diverse. I never felt like it was too repetitive.

I also found myself enjoying doing things outside of the main missions like riding around on my trusty steed, hunting, robbing random folks sitting next to campfires, throwing people off carriages and holding trains hostage. The world is your oyster here!

Moral of the story? Throw your morals out the window :) Have some fun, don't get too overwhelmed, don't be afraid to explore and break some in-game "rules" and see what's waiting for you!

I am glad I did because this game is a complete and utter disappointment from gameplay to storyline I have no love for it. There was so much potential for this game to be great but it flopped. For one, if I wanted to do chores I wouldn't be playing a video game. This almost feels more like a book when I have to watch the cut scenes for around 5 minutes. Just overall I don't recommend this game and wish I could get my money back.

author: J.B. Wish
title: Positive Reviews are Bought and Paid For
content: Anyone who says "Rockstar did it right" is crazy.  Rockstar has been using the same clumsy game mechanics (movement, shooting, fighting, etc) since the early GTA games, and nothing has changed.  Now instead of a silly satirical games like GTA, they tried to get all serious and authentic, without making their game mechanics serious or authentic.  This game is infuriatingly mismanaged.  Movement is slow and clunky, shooting is clumsy, and EVERYTHING is tedious and achingly slow.  And don't bother spending time to upgrade and bond with your horse because the game will just kill it and waste all of your time and money.  Total disappointment.  Note to Rockstar...play a good game like God of War, Horizon Zero Dawn, or Last of Us.  Once you know how it's done, THEN you can try to make a "serious" game.  Until then, stick to dumb mayhem games like GTA.  And that's the most frustrating thing about this game actually.  The main character is an outlaw, but if you do anything even remotely criminal, every player in the game tries to kill you.  No exxageration--I rode past some and kicked them, and all of a sudden every policeman in the city was shooting at me.  Good job Rockstar...SUPER realistic.  Cuz that would happen in real life for sure.

author: Andrew Z.
title: I hope it gets better...
content:
***UPDATE*** I have now beaten the game and to cut to the chase and answer my own headline, does the game get better or not? Yes, it does get better. Chapter 4 is when the game finally flips the switch and really kicks the missions into a higher gear. There's enough action happening in the missions now that it balances the slower parts out better and kept me more engaged through to the end. The initial ending, without spoiling it, was not really a surprise unlike RDR1 where the ending really catches you off guard completely and didn't quite see coming a mile off like this game does. The epilogue portion was nice though (again, I'm not going to spoil any of it). But now that I've finished the game I will say my feelings on it haven't changed much. The story did get better as it went on but many of my criticisms I go into detail below still remain the same so to put it simply, I'm not going to change a word of this review. However, I think I will bump up my rating to a 7.5/10 having now completed it (potentially an 8/10 once I do a lot of the extra content this game offers). That may seem low but that's my honest opinion. I'd round the star rating up to 4/5 stars but I'm not giving Rockstar the benefit of the doubt on this one. They dropped the ball on some crucial components (controls mostly) and sacrificed its fun factor for realism and attention to detail to the point where it became too much. Both of these things I noticed within the first couple of hours of playing and it never changed now 40+ hours in and after having completed it. That's that.***

I'll preface by saying I'm only 10 hours in and none of these early reviews are much further either so I don't feel so bad for posting impressions of a game I haven't finished yet since nobody else has yet either.

Similar to most, I was very much anticipating this game the moment it was announced they were working on it years ago. I enjoyed the first one enough to know I'll be getting the sequel no matter what so I didn't watch any trailers for it, didn't look at any news or screenshots of the game beforehand, didn't watch any gameplay videos... I went in with a clean slate and open-mind.

So after I waited about an hour and half for this beast to finally finish installing, I could finally sit down and play RDR2. And not long after I finished the first mission did most of my initial excitement leave completely as the game immediately establishes it's going to move at an extremely slow pace as you go from Point A to Point B performing menial tasks as you sit through cutscene after cutscene with nothing much happening gameplay-wise. The entire first chapter is a 3 hour long tutorial level, a refresher course of many of the same mechanics and controls as the previous Red Dead. There's a couple of shootouts in there but for the most part you'll be spending the majority of your first 3 hours in this game watching cutscenes, listening to dialogue and traveling around a pretty much empty snow-blanketed map. Fun, right? Not really... I just about fell asleep during this time.

In this time, you'll also quickly realize Rockstar still has not updated their god-awful controls and mechanics. Your character still feels as stiff as a rock, every action you do feels like a chore to do because you're fighting these archaic controls. Time to stop being so stubborn Rockstar and start taking some notes from other developers who have really tight controls and mechanics. The way games should play, not this nonsense. No input you put in feels fluid, everything feels clunky and unnatural. In fact, it still feels like you're playing those old PS2 era GTA's since Rockstar really hasn't updated their mechanics or controls much since. Unforgivable especially coming off playing games with really good controls like Horizon Zero Dawn and Spider-Man. Hell, even AC: Odyssey has better and more fluid controls than this mess.

Then, once you get to Chapter 2 the game really starts. You now have free reign of the entire map so alright, now it's going to start getting good, right? WRONG. I started Chapter 2 by jumping right into some missions. One of the missions is essentially a tour through the first town in the game, Valentine. You somehow get into a scuffle with some dudes so you knock them out and the missions over. So alright, not very exciting still, but whatever. So I start doing some other missions. You've got your typical bounty missions (go here, usually someplace really far away and will take you forever to get to, and kill some guy, come back and rinse and repeat), debt collecting missions (same as bounty missions except you don't have to kill them, you just rob them, rinse and repeat). As you're riding through the landscape doing these menial, boring tasks, you get to observe the world. Which, much like the previous Red Dead, is really quite empty and there's nothing much going on especially when you're in between towns. It's a whole lotta trees, animals, mountains and rivers and nothing much else. Every now and then you'll get that random event like in all Rockstar games. One I ran into in the middle of the nowhere, some NPC was stuck on the side of the path with his horse who was agitated for some reason. So, the NPC is trying to calm the thing down and the horse ends up kicking him in the face and knocking him out as he ragdolls down a hill. Pretty funny. Rockstar still has a great feel for randomness, but for the most part, their worlds are pretty stagnant and dead and RDR2 is no exception.

Now, the good. Graphics are beautiful, story seems like it's ramping up to something good even though it's moving too slowly. The script is great, the voice acting is phenomenal, great attention to detail almost to a fault. All these things are exceptionally good as is expected from Rockstar. BUT, the downside is it seems they focused so much on script and the story and getting the graphics to look really good that they treated the gameplay as an afterthought and it suffers greatly. They just expect you to be totally engaged in all these dialogue sequences and cutscenes that you're to forget that you're not really doing much of anything gameplay-wise. You're just going from Point A to Point B, repeating many of the same kind of missions and tasks you've already done in the previous one. And with the controls and mechanics being so poor, it takes you away even further from the experience this game wants to give. It wants to be that big, epic game but it just drawls on and takes your attention span for granted.

I'm assuming it ramps up as you go along, but the stiff character and stiff controls is a real game breaker for me. They should have refined this 10 years ago with GTA IV. That was great opportunity to upgrade it being a new system at the time (PS3) but yet they were like nope, it's totally fine even though many other developers were really starting to make really fluid controls mechanics. And here we are, PS4 era and Rockstar Games are still making games with PS2 era controls and mechanics. I forgave it 10 years ago, I can't forgive it any longer. They need to do something with the clunky controls, it hampers the experience immensely of all their games.

In conclusion, I'm going to keep on chugging along with this game in hope it gets better as it goes along. I'll update this review if anything changes my mind but 10 hours in and it's not looking too good for this supposed GOTY that many people keep claiming it is. Not when it was released in the same year as a game like God Of War. A game with actual good controls and extremely varied and addictive gameplay, not to mention a great story and graphics to boot. Sorry Rockstar fans, but RDR never stood a chance.

UPDATE: Well, I've made it to Chapter 3 somehow and still nothing has happened in this game that changes any of my above views. Still an extremely slow drag. There's one mission near the end of Chapter 2 that really proves how bad the controls are. It's the mission where you're under attack in Valentine and there's a portion where you have to use a stage coach as cover... as it's moving... as about a dozen guys are shooting at you from all angles. The controls are just infuriatingly bad here. You have to walk (key word there is 'walk', you can't run), stay in cover and shoot in all directions... at the same time. You're literally in a scramble on the controller in this part and it highlights everything wrong with the controls. By some luck, you'll spray enough bullets everywhere to kill enough guys to get through it. It was obviously intended to be a difficult part but the difficulty mostly stems from you fighting with the controls, not from just a difficulty spike in a mission. I've died only 3-4 times so far and the one I will take responsibility for because I was being stupid and trying to run and gun early in the game (you gotta at least try it in the beginning and see if you can get away with it, every game is different) and I failed miserably. The other 3 or so happened directly in effect of the bad controls. I died only once at the aforementioned stage coach mission and my 2nd run felt like pure luck. There was nothing real satisfactory about beating it either. I quite literally just stumbled through it. After you get through that stage coach part, you have to book it on your horse as you're still getting shot at and because the horse handles however it wants when it's near other objects, it's so unpredictable (ie. say there's a decent size rock in the road; sometimes your horse will just side step it and keep going, sometimes he'll hit it and you'll fly off and you're horse dies, and sometimes he'll get stuck on it). Well, I got stuck on a rock right when I needed to book it and I just barely got away within one hit of death. Pure stroke of luck I got through that whole mission. This game is not a test of any skill, it's a test of patience and fighting with controls that decide to work against you at every opportunity.

I've failed a couple missions just based on pure randomness happening but that's consistent with all Rockstar Games. There's one mission where you have to rob a stage coach with money in it. It has a bunch of enemies surrounding it, so you're chasing the stage coach, picking off these guys one by one and I got it down to just the driver of the stage coach left. Right when I'm about to take the final kill shot, the dude just drives the thing off a cliff for no reason, destroying the stage coach and making me fail the mission. What is that all about? Stuff like that just happens in this game and you never know when the game is going to decide when to screw you over. It just happens and most cases at the worst times. Probably will be more updates as I continue through this game. But yeah, long story short, nothing has changed so far and I'm well into Chapter 3 now.

author: Tim Dutton
title: Almost perfect, developers purposely shot them selves in the foot
content:
Credit where credit is do first, if you liked the original Red Dead Redemption or you are even mediocre fan of westerns, this game is a must have. The original Red dead redemption is the only game I ever got 100% completion on, in fact I did it several times or more, this prequel will likely be the same, but there are some tasks that could have been reasons why you play, instead they become in-spite ofs.
Some reviewers has accused this game of being boring. It is slow, but that is intentional, it’s a game designed to be emersive, on that fact is where the flaws start. Instead of going at your own pace and completing missions you want, when you want, it feels like the game pushes and rushes you to get to the next mission. Only to slow the pace back down during the mission. It becomes a hurry up and wait situation. I accidentally started two missions in chapter three alone back to back while trying to do other things.
I was a real life bounty hunter for twenty years and have many times been accused of being born 100 years to late, so I was so looking forward to this and even the new tasks. Lets take a look.
Bonding with your horse. Absolutely loved the idea, but then realized you can’t get the horse you want until the game is almost over.
Eating. Could have been an immersive experience, but you can only eat at camp every two days. Unless you just rest and eat you get underwiegit. I ate after and sometimes during each mission, i always kept supplies stocked and handy, yet I remain underweight the whole time.
Customizing and maintaining weapons again loved the idea, was disappointed by execution. I earned the nickname the Wolf as a bounty hunter, so before I even bought the game had it planned out, cattleman revolver with wolf carved in handle. Get the game and nope there is only like seven animals you can put on the grip the wolf is not one of them. To me this just seems rushed or lazy, why not at least have the legendary animals be part of customization?
Bathing. Again could have been immersive, but you can’t bathe in camp. The time period this takes place even makeshift showers were available in camps like this.
The camp could have been a major hub, come back to, eat, bath, tend to horse, sleep, fast travel, etc. but when you come back several times and can’t eat or bathe, it gets to the point where you say why am I coming here, theres no point.
Here is what it seems the people at Rockstar were discussing.
1. Lets make this realistic by having them bond with their horse, yea, but lets make it unrealistic by saying certain breeds don’t exist until later and force people to bond with horses they don’t want.
2. Lets make it realistic by having them to bathe to stay clean, but lets make it unrealistic and They just can’t figure out how to have basic necessities at camp, so force them to go to town to bathe.
3. Lets make it realistic and have players maintain and customize weapons, but lets not let them have the weapons they want and lets not put very many customize options in, just enough to let them know how great this could have been.
4. Hey lets allow players to fast travel from a map at Aurthors tent, but lets pretend he can’t pull out a map when he camps.
This is a game that could have been almost perfect and so much fun, but because of a lack of thought or rushing it becomes a game you trudge through tedious tasks because you know you’ll get to do something cool later. That’s the most irritating thing, these task could have been purposeful, meaningful and even had more impact at certain points in the game, but because Rockstar decided to have an open world that wasn’t quite oen until later or because of no follow through they become tedious. None of these tasks had to be tedious, everyone of them could have added to the quality and the immersive play of this game. They lost out on some of the game of the year awards, I think for these exact reasons. Even some of these could have been corrected, you want me to play through the first time with limited resources fine, give us a game+ mode that lets us play through the next sessions starting with our own load out.  It would increase replay value. Is that to much for players to ask for, for a game that broke sales records. Without the players, you would not have broke those records. Throw us a bone and lets us play these tasks like they could have been unbogged down by meaningless make them mean something.
Thank you Rockstar for giving me. Western when very few will, a game I’ Play for months and even years, but shame on you for dropping the ball and making things that could have been awesome feel tedious.

author: D. G.
title: Read This Before You Buy!
content:
Update Jan 17 to 1 Star: I'm selling this game immediately on eBay. The controls are infuriatingly horrible. I tried a few hours of mundane things like tracking & hunting and control/movement is even worse than combat. First-person POV is if you are 2' tall. Can't see squat unless on horse and horse scares every animal from 100' into running away. The most beautiful and absolutely pathetic motion design of an overhyped NEW game I've had the misfortune of wasting my money on. Don't waste yours!

From a life long fps gamer who 95% completed the first RDR. Playing sequel on a 60" 4G concave tv w/ headphones. I'll keep it short as I can w/ no spoilers:
PROS:
- The visual details of this game are without equal for the PS4 platform. Absolutely stunning. Perfect detail, ranging from pond scum floating on marsh water to a horse taking a steamy dump. I've sent hours on horseback just logging birds and found it actually relaxing.

- Area of play/map is very big/diverse. It's hard to put in perspective b/c you can't traverse in a straight line due to topography. From the highest elevation/furthest area North, heavily clothed, freezing and in deep snow to the Tropical South, with mosquitos, gators and stripped down to essentials. I love that.

- The story line is a good one. Better than the first game, in my opinion. A few totally hilarious adventures and encounters. Challenges and collectibles are vast and HARD. I am sort of glad for that (see Cons).

**My 2 star review is for these CONS:
- The character controls (Oh Rockstar...smdh), yet again, are abysmally bad for all the hard work that went into this game. In my opinion, it's as bad as the first version. Maybe it's my ignorance about coding & processing but with TWO discs worth of data, I'd think they could've done so much better. Moving Arthur around is like being an 80yr old, 9 month pregnant, mentally limited, couch potato. Can't run, climb, jump, fight or shoot to save his life 75% of the time. Literally. You'll see, it's pathetic. He even plays cards slow!

- Combat. The almost too realistic mechanics is a big negative for this. It's just unecessarily complicated and not fun until you're hours/days into game to better equip and even after wasting ALL your time, it sucks. Big problem: you're character reacts to being shot at by NPCs. They ALL shoot at you. ALL the time. They ALWAYS know where you are. Meaning, every-single-time a NPC shoots at you, your character moves, making your reticle (when you can find it) move around. Also, I've adjusted controls, video and my TV 5 dif times and can still barely see the aiming reticle. One thing that paticularly annoyed me about this, when firing a repeater rifle, one has to pull the trigger to fire AND TO LOAD THE NEXT BULLET!! Half the time I press R2, it's to load another friggin bullet! Sucks when you have a headshot needed to gold medal a challenge and pull trigger - only to load a round... C'mon! *Remember how poorly the character moves - on top of all this....

- Very limited fast travel. Not kidding, they didn't address this, again. Have to go to a terminal, in a town, and pay for either train or stagecoach and only with limited destinations. Again. Travel is SOOO SLOW and you do that more than anything else in this game.

- **This alone almost made me return the game** DO NOT BUY A, NOR PAY TO UPGRADE, A HORSE! I bought, fully upgraded and completely bonded with a horse that cost me ~$800 of the very first monies I made. It took hours to do so. Hours. I go on a mission to interview a gunslinger, have to chase him on top of a train and when the mission completes, I go to jump back on my horse and it's the $8 horse I started the game with....WTF. Looked everywhere (including stable I purchased from and that gave me "papers" for horse) and the upgraded horse was erased from time & space. Poof. I could've punched a kitten. (I've read that Rockstar lied to another customer about this, saying it wasn't an issue and that they were imagining things). A huge F-U Rockstar, for this one.

To sum up:
What's the point of all that detail if you can barely move within it? Same problems as the first game. Rockstar never learns.

author: khuddle
title: Fantastic, though not Rockstar's best
content:
On the plus side, this is the most beautiful games on the PS4, period. The graphics are unbelievable,
giving the game tremendous atmosphere and the feeling of truly being there. I also loved the various
characters in the game (my favorite being gorgeous tomboy bounty hunter Sadie Adler), and how there is
a mix of the old (John Marston from RDR1) and the new (charismatic protagonist Arthur Morgan). However,
what I found lacking in the game was the freshness that we've seen in Rockstar's previous outings,
namely Red Dead Redemption 1 and Grand Theft Auto Five. Those two games presented us with things
 we had never seen before. Here, while the set pieces are fun, they were very similar to what we've seen
in previous Rockstar games. Its almost as if the company has at last exhausted all its ideas.

True, it might be a bit of the same old same old, but holy smokes what a beautiful package. Play the game
just to marvel at the beauty of this fully realized Old West world, if nothing else.

author: Culture Vulture
title: First impressions from a casual gamer
content:
I don't have as much time for games as I used to anymore and was debating this purchase heavily because I've already played a lot of Rockstar games including Red Dead Revolver and Red Dead Redemption. I decided to give Red Dead Redemption 2 a try though and am enjoying it quite a bit. I think a newer player who enjoys westerns will get more out of this game, but it is a great looking and great playing game for veterans to get something out of as well.
It's not without flaws and minor things to gripe about though. Still feel like I am in tutorial mode even after the second train heist using the oil wagon, but it appears to be that deep and big of a game. I think players of the previous games will find some of this annoying, but I forgot a lot of RDR gameplay mechanics so it is good to get some refreshers. I didn't understand why it doesn't explain the dead eye mechanics very well from the start since it's such a big part of RDR gameplay, or I missed it somewhere (hold L3 and R3 down). Felt like knowing it early on would help with the wolves and checking off some accomplishments without replaying missions. Mission briefings beforehand explaining objectives like time requirements would be nice, but would spoil things too I suppose. Looks like you can go back and replay some things but it is sketchy because you don't want to mess up a save file. The save system seems a little complex as well because with autosave on you always get those "are you sure you want to save over such and such save file?" messages. Probably best to switch to manual save only, but early on you don't want to risk redoing the long intro as the recent South Park joked about. I'd say the first chunk of the game is a little too punishing with how much you have to ride around before fast travel becomes available. The improved graphics help, but I'm already growing weary of the environment and travel and can't wait for fast travel to become available. Also, early on before you make any money the game isn't as fun because you have to be really careful not to cross anybody or do the wrong thing because getting a bounty removed is expensive and can all but lock off areas you can go safely. Also found that early on non-mission stuff is kind of boring and more of the same kind of thing you get in GTA or the old RDR games like going to the theaters and whatnot. Went into Lemoyne early on and found it dull without a mission available. I think the game will open up quite a bit once I do some serious hunting and finally get in on some big heists and poker games. Like I said, not much money early on with camp upgrades and not having funds to enter big poker games yet.
But there are some surprises depending on how you play the game, for instance someone I helped once put an item on his tab for me after a second encounter that I quickly upgraded and got a trophy on right away and there is something cool about the small skirmishes and random encounters you can get involved in and the different moral consequences both you and your character experience.
That said, looking forward to pressing on because no matter how it goes from here it is certainly an improved RDR game and I'm not looking forward to too many games other than Death Stranding at this point.

author: Chase Snarr
title: Cowboy chores - the game.
content:
This game is amazing. It's got great graphics, great attention to detail, it's an achievement in video game creation.

Unfortunately, it is tedious, it is boring and it is not very fun. I get that a lot of people love this game and I see why, but I don't like it. It's like a chore simulator with occasional gun play.

A real shame because I really want to love the game and I just don't.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Possibly the greatest game I’ve played in years
content: This game is a true masterpiece, in every way. The graphics, the story, the characters, the writing, it’s all spectacular. The level of detail is mind-blowing, I’m almost 50 hours in and I still smile every time I play because I keep finding something new. I see some people saying, “it’s slow omg it’s so slow and boring,” and to those people I say, “stick with call of duty.” Sure, there are slow moments, but it’s in these moments where you can truly experience the game’s beauty. Rockstar really made something special with this game. The amount of detail is just absolutely insane. Each character is interesting and unique and nobody feels like an empty shell, even the random npc’s you’ll run in to. I’ve been gaming for about 25 years and this is easily the best open world game I’ve ever played and I’ve played all of the good ones. Just buy it.

I was late in purchasing this game as I had other games I needed to finish. Looking back, I shouldve dropped everything and started this game as soon as it came out! Amazing graphics, visuals, and story. I was only in Chapter 3 and already sunk a ton of hours into it already, what a great value as replay ability is definitely not an issue.

author: Jessica d.
title: Such an Amazing Game. Have not felt bored for even a second.
content:
I had to chime in based on all of these reviews I am seeing that call this game "boring", "ZZZ-fest", "snore", etc.

I couldn't disagree more. Now...if you are looking for a high octane, intense, fast-paced, banger of a game..I could see how this may not be for you. So if that is the case, don't buy it.

The crowning achievement of this game is its ability to immerse you. More than any other I have ever played, I get absolutely lost in the world of RDR2. It is a slower paced game but that is what I love about it. It's slow, but never boring.

Those complaining about the lack of fast traveling- once you hit chapter 2, paying for a train ticket shouldn't be an issue and that's easy enough of a way to get around quickly. However, so much of the fun in this game is riding from point A to point B and taking part in the experiences that unfold. Running into some rando with a snake bite or a guy whose arm is hanging off and needs a ride to the doctor...or spotting that perfect whitetail deer and veering off to chase it for the pelt you've been dreaming of. These are things you would miss if you fast traveled all over the place and you'd be losing out on such a huge part of the game.

Sure, the controls take some getting used to. Nothing pisses me off more than pulling a gun on a dude when I meant to just greet him. Also, the bounty system is frustrating. But these are all things you grow accustomed to with practice  and become much easier to avoid as the game progresses.

The graphics are incredible. The characters grasp you. The voice-acting...just OMG. The missions and side quests and hunting and fishing and  weapons and loot and extras are all SO GOOD.

So, ask yourself this- are you willing to sacrifice hard, fast, intense game play for something slower, smarter, and more immersive? Then buy this game. If not, stick with the new Black Ops.  I'll be over here in my buckskin chaps fishing for a legendary bass with my friend Lenny.

author: TV's Jay
title: Online is a Griefer Fest  --UPDATED Jun 2019
content:
Story mode is great.

Online, the camping system is bad, very different from story.

The posse system only means you now have gangs of people griefing you rather than just one person.
I had 3 people go way out of their way to kill me while I was hunting, then go off and kill other people.  You can kind of watch this all play out on the map...  and since they can't rob the people they are killing there really is no reason to do it except to ruin your time.

Shot in the back 5 times on the way to a quest...  very sad.

Updated JUN 19'

Camping still horrible, but they have essentially fixed the griefer problems.  Very Nice.  I can log in and play the game.
There is still PLENTY of pvp opportunity, but if I just want to hunt or fish I can do that.

author: jacob
title: Amazing! Truly a masterpiece! Rockstar you nailed it!
content:
This game is a masterpiece. Rockstar did not disappoint! I haven't felt this respected by a developer since The Witcher 3. This is how developers should treat their fans. Rockstar delivered greater than I expected! In a world with most AAA developers seemingly alienating their fanbases ie. Bethesda, Bungie, EA. Disney in the movie scene. Take a moment to appreciate that Rockstar got it right. Enough flowers. Now to the game. The attention to detail is painstaking. The visuals are hands down the best I've ever seen. The story is compelling and the characters are relatable. The AI for NPCs is great not real but best I've seen. The guns/weapons and combat are a challenge to master. The whole game is bass ackwards when compared to the status quo. This game is not a race to the finish line! This game begs you to get lost in it's systems. Kick off your shoes and stay a while. Every single time I log on I learn something new! Exploration is king. In a world that feels alive! So many sandboxes reach for but cannot attain the level of immersion this game offers. The works that has gone into this game is literally bonkers. I'm not doing cons. They're neglible and I can totally forgive them.

Listen don't play this like a challenge to be conquered. Play this like you're stepping into a Masterpiece. Breathe it in and appreciate the time you use. I'm at 45% completion in the storyline. I'm in no rush to finish. Thanks Rockstar and associated, truly appreciate the game. Thanks for reading guys! I would recommend you buy. Easily worth the money.

content: Controls are a disaster ("shoot a random stranger" button right next to horse brake), autosave works against you (and wants to kill your horse), no save file management, everything is poorly explained and directionless, everything UI is clumsy. The GTAs of the past were far more intuitive. Very pretty though I guess.

author: Kdh
title: Oh Arthur GET THE LEAD OUT
content:
To be honest I’m not far into the game yet, so this isn’t a fair review. I will update it once I finish the game. But a few things are Killing Me so far!!

* Is Arthur made of lead? He walks so slow! Like the Witcher trying to carry 600 lbs.
* Arthur’s voice. I may be in the minority, but his voice doesn’t match his looks. If I had to draw a guy to match this voice, he would be a fat, chain smoking inmate with a bad accent. It’s like he’s straining trying to make his voice sound raspy and southern. It doesn’t feel authentic.
* Hope you like traveling A LOT via horseback.
* I don’t like holding down buttons for extended periods of time every time I want to pick something up, search someone, walk at a faster pace, etc. Why can’t I just push is once and be done? Taking time to loot anything is insufferable.

However
* The graphics are stellar. The scenery is amazing.
* Most of the voice acting is very good. Although Sadi Adler, and Author are over the top. Give Ruby from “Cold Mountain” a hoarse voice and you’ve got Sadi Adler. This is what happens when city clickers to to talk southern.
* This game is sure to keep you busy if you can get into it.

Update:
I finally completed they game. I changed it from a 3 star to a 5 star because the game deserves it. When I first started the game, I though it may not be for me even though I am a diverse gamer. There isn’t a specific genre I like the most and I learned to like, even love, games I never thought I would. This game is no exception. I’m not really into the western thing, but I’m glad I stuck it out with this game because by chapter 3 I found myself not wanting to quite playing. There is so much to love about this game. The story is very good. It gets better the more you play. You care about the main characters. It matters how you develop your characters. The graphics are beautiful. Some of the stuff I said in my earlier review still hold true.
1. Arthur in normal walking mode is intolerable.
2. I loved Sadie. She is a great character, but her voice tries to hard to be redneck.
3. Having to walk at a snails pace through camp is also intolerable.

But....

Authors voice finally grew on me. It took awhile though.

I have played so many PS4 games over the years. This one is going in my top 10 for sure.  The Witcher 3 still remains my #1.

Be good to your horse. Morals matter. Fast travel via map, stage coach, or train.

author: NTred
content: This game is awesome!

author: AV
title: Very pleased
content: Enjoy the game

author: James Davis
title: Amazing game!
content: Amazing game! Definitely worth the wait.

author: The Exacting Consumer
title: You will hate at first, stick with it
content:
Adding another star. The attention to detail and in-game conversations are phenomenal. Rockstar really has done an amazing job this building on previous successes. They just keep getting better. The Saint Denis stuff in Ch 4 is particularly impressive. You can definitely play as a bad guy, but it's harder to do so. While I no longer feel the bounty system ruins the game, it is still a pain, many hours in.

I could have quit the game after a few hours but didn't. I really did not like it at all in the beginning. But then I started to figure things out. The long horse rides don't bother me as much. The bounty system is still a pain but there's ways to work around it. The easiest is to empty your wallet by donating to the camp and turning yourself in. I'm into chapter 3 right now and am enjoying the experience more. Arthur is warming up to me and there are a ton of interesting interactions in this crazy world. Adding 2 stars. If you are like me and hated this game just a few hours in, I recommend you stick it out and keep playing. It does get better!

**Original 1 star review**
"Play how you want" they said. "Be a good guy or a bad guy" they said. Uh huh, until you slightly bump someone on foot or while on horse resulting in an assault charge followed by a bounty that does not expire forcing you to pay it. Shoot back? Watch it double, then triple. Run? Go for it, then you will have bounty hunters waiting for you after every mission you do anywhere in the map, in addition to losing access to the town where the charge is.

I absolutely LOVED the first Red Dead so this is a massive disappointment and makes the game zero fun to play. Yes the visuals are great, especially on 4K, yes the dialog can be interesting, no, Arthur Morgan is not John Marston, not even close. There are a ton of other problems around movement, long travel and general mechanics but the punishing bounty system ruins the game. I suggest you wait for a patch before buying, assuming they ever actually fix this. There is no difficulty or game play level adjustment so you are stuck with Rockstar's default "real world" level. The good old days of GTA-esque do-whatever-you-want are over...

author: Rachel Camp
title: Top Notch Service!
content: Son loves this!!

author: maroond
title: Don't listen to any of these Jabronis
content:
This game is by far one of the most detailed games I have ever played. From the story line, dialogue, graphics and game play it will take you on a journey of at least 60 hours of gamer heaven. Now, just to get this out of the way I am not a fan of GTA. They have made RDR2 controls better and more realistic in this game. Anyways, for some reason it feels better to be an outlaw killing people rather than some gang banger. Weird morals, right? For all those who don't like the controls you can manually adjust them to feel more like a regular FPS shooter. I have done this and the controls feel even more smoother.

As for travel time... Rockstar has painstakingly taken the time to make this incredible game. It is realistic not to dash around everywhere ESPECIALLY IN THE WILD WEST. Holy people come on are you serious? If you feel so inclined not to ride your horse around you have other options. Later in the story you have the option to purchase fast travel from the camp. If not you can purchase a train or coach ticket and you will "dash" to any town you want. If you take the train you can stay on it and rob it like a Bad..... If you want. Not only is it more realistic but I also believe Rockstar wants you to appreciate the detail and scenery they've put into the game while traveling.

If you're a fan of side missions. There is plenty to be had. Bounties, helping random strangers, meeting people... Also with this you can choose to help them or kill them. Helping them gives you good reputation and killing them... Well... Contrary to belief it will give you bad reputation which will determine how people treat you. One cool trick is if you greet random strangers you will get good reputation. Some of the other activities you can accomplish in the game are camping, crafting your own supplies, hunting, fishing, search for treasure maps and sell all your stolen goods to your local Fence. Oh, did I tell you that you can make off with someone's else's coach and sell it? Yes you can!!!

Do I dare say it? Yes, I will. This game is better than God of War. GoW lacks depth, the gameplay is slow and boring. If I hear him say BOY one more time.... RDR2 makes for a game with fantastic depth and playability. You have so many options in this open world. Get it. You won't regret it!!!

author: Joseph Joseph Joseph
content: Great game, awesome graphics and amazing voice acting. Red Dead 2 could definitely win game of the year.

author: Janer
title: Good game - zero replay
content: Game is wonderful but once it is over I haven't had a desire to play it again.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Perfect
content: Perfect

author: Crux
title: Ultimately disappointing.
content:
The ending was awful. The controls are inexcusably clunky. There's a constant, nagging tedium present managing their "core system". Infinite enemies are a poor substitute for actual difficulty. Most things are unlocked too late in the story for anyone to actually have fun with them. The game pretends to give you same agency, but all your decisions just lead to the same place anyway. The story, overall, is just so-so. The world is beautiful, but the game itself has a million ugly little things about it.
Rockstar should leave the faux western simulator nonsense for Oregon Trail.

This game is worth 20, maybe 30 dollars. Don't buy it for a cent more.

author: jay
title: Great game
content: Grandson loves it

author: Bloodpuddleohio
title: Sigh.....Trying to keep faith
content: Well, im about 20% through the main story and feel like I know enough to write an honest review. First off, i give the game 4.5 solid stars. The amount of detail rockstar put into this game is mind blowing. You'll never run out of new things to see and do. The scenery is absolutly breath taking and one thing i dont hear a lot of people reviewing this game talk about is the music. It just perfectly sets the mood for whereever you go and what your doing. The graphics are very very very good, although I do feel they were a bit over exaggerated  compared to what we seen in previews and trailors before the game came out. There are the standard goofy bugs and glitches that rockstar is known for so do not be surprised if you run into some issues here and there. The story keeps the player engaged and interested. But does have some slow spots inbetween. This is a very story driven game so you have to keep in mind this is game where you have to just slow down, enjoy your surroundings, and take everything in a little at a time. I feel like soo many games are just pumped out quickly, beaten quickly, then companies just force DLC down your throat. This isnt that game. SLOW DOWN AND ENJOY IT!!! My major critique and flaw with this game is hands down the controls and combat. I loved the first RDR but i absolutely hated the combat and aiming and this game hardly improved on that at all. Im finally getting used to the controls as far as switching weapons and eating rations to regain health, stamina, and dead eye, but the combat system is just feels soooo outdated and clunky and honestly is just not fun, especially in 3rd person. In 1st person i feel like the combat is more controllable, but a far strech from even being good. Im a huge fan of first person shooters, because the combat, aiming, switching weapons is smooth and fluid. Im also a huge fan of rpg's in the 3rd person because of the amount of extra detail you get in your surrounds. If they polished these issues, which i have high hopes they will/can rdr2 has potential to be a near perfect game, but will never be completely perfect.

author: Jacob Dinsmore
title: Fantastic Video Game and Delivered on Time!
content:
Rockstar truly hit it out of the park again with this amazing video game! The game was delivered to me on time and I've been playing it ever since.

If you're on the fence about this game, I highly recommend getting it as it will lead to hours and hours of entertainment!

author: Mr.P
title: Boring and tedious
content:
The "realism" is over the top and makes for a tedious boring game. I'll give it that the graphics are okay and I see what they're attempting with the horse maintenance, getting cold in the rain, and all the other little things they want you to have to take care of in order for it to feel real and immersive but let me get to some action already.

I hate that when you walk through town if you brush up against someone it can turn into you getting killed. I shot a guy in a saloon on accident and was promptly killed myself because the controls are soooo screwy.  I hate that I have to clean my horse every time I get off it. I hate that I have to clean my guns all the time. I hate that you can't pick up a hooker. I hate that spending 30 minutes at a poker table yields a whopping $10. I hate that it takes forever to get from place to place. I hate that your horse gets tired unless you're walking all the time. I hate that....I think you get it....I loved Red Dead 1 but #2 is #2...

author: J.S.
title: Enough with the My Little Pony Simulator
content:
As others have stated, the game is beautiful. The story is good, and the story threads are all throughout the game. Voice overs are great! And the game is filled with plenty of activities. If only they had stopped there...

Want to know why the main storyline takes 50-60 hours, two words: TIME SINK

There are WAY too many time sinks in this game. I really don't want to do horse maintenance, by brushing its coat or feeding it carrots. In GTA, I didn't have to stop at the gas station or have the oil changed. R* stop with the Nintendogs crap!

Bathing by itself wouldn't be that bad, but we have to push a button and watch an animation for EVERY LIMB - head, left arm, right arm, left leg, left arm. And having someone come in to wash you is just as tedious.

Not once have I purchased a game specifically for it's personal hygiene mechanics, and there is a reason. It's even less fun to do these things in the virtual world than the real one.

More time sinks. Can't run in the camp and the NPCs are spaced far apart.

Biggest time sink of all. Damn SLOW as molasses horses! You'll be staring at the butt of that horse 90% of your gameplay. A saving grace here is the cinematic auto-ride feature which will automatically follow the path you've specified, but wait. You can't walk away, because you still have to hold down the 'x' button. I'm going to get a chip clip and have it hold down the 'x' button.

Pick-up or interact with an item control sucks. You have to hold down the button for 1.5 seconds to interact with the object. How about this R*, just have us press the button and not hold it! It's actually worse than that, because sometimes they mix it up by having you just press and not hold the button. Come on sub-systems guys, get on the same UI controls playbook.

Gun play controls are rubbish. They are OK at a distance, but have something like a dog or wolf on you with melee and the controls are wonky to say the least.

Oh wait, was that an item with which to interact? Who the hell knows because the interact menu selection doesn't always show up when you get near the item. OK, so now we do a little dance that I like to call, the "item detection sidestep". Grab your joystick whirl a round, now up and down, and up and down, and step to the left, step to the right, and there she is! Now press the button, hold it down. dose-e-doe...

Fishing! Sounds great. But reeling in the fish goes way too slow for the amount of times the player has to circle the joystick.

Conclusion

There are so many great games out there as other reviewers have mentioned, GoW, Horizon ZD, Witcher 3. Those games do all of this so much better. R* come out of that basement where you're working your people 100 hour weeks, and look around. You've squeezed your last $60 pre-order out of me. Next time I'll wait for reviews instead of simply buying it because it has R* on the cover.

author: Peter Harpending
title: Rockstar's adaptation of The Phantom Menace
content:
Extremely disappointing. It's the video game equivalent of The Phantom Menace.

Red Dead 1 is an amazing game. I expected the sequel to be at least as good as the original. Instead we have this heap of trash. If I knew the game would be this, I wouldnt have bought it.

The first thing you'll notice is the confusing and frustrating controls. For instance if one is on a horse, and spots prey, or gets into a fight, you'll instinctively pull the left trigger to aim whatever weapon you selected. Except now that's not what happens. Now you have to aim, then elect to draw your weapon, then fire. And most of the time it won't pick out weapons you want.  Way too many steps when you're panicking because someone's shooting at you.

They also took away essential features, such as fast travel. You also have to remember to grab your weapons off your horse before stopping. It's difficult to predict what a control input is going to end up doing. The whole game is extremely frustrating. I've played it for several days, and I'm still waiting for it to be fun.

The magic of Red Dead 1 is gone. There are some improvements here, but really it's just the same game with a different setting, more drudgery, less fun, lazier plot, and frustrating controls.

IT has been explained that it is realistic in 1880 dollars yet an apple or pear costs 50 to 75 cents. 4.00 for a revive tonic - which you need after a mission takes all the profit for the hours of play.  I find the game to be really frustrating and the pricing make no sense except that fact that soon you can go to IGN and purchase gold bars which then DOES make sense - its less about the game being realistic as it is putting REAL gold bars in the developers bank account.  If you make it impossible to make money in the game then by all means give the option to take real money from the players. Im at the point of filing this dog of a game in the circular filing cabinet and play something with a better payoff ( in game results online ) because just buying gold bars because its impossible to afford any items in the games online stores is a joke.

author: VolFan
title: Negative Reviews?
content:
This review is in response to all the negative reviews.  I had the same feeling after I played this game for about 10 hours.  I went to Gamestop to trade it in,but the clerk there said I should finish the game.  I did,and I am SO glad I did.  This game is powerful.  Sure,the mechanics didn't really improve from RDR 1,but the graphics and story more than make up for that.  There are some gut-wrenching cut scenes you rarely see in video games.  One of these is when Arthur is speaking with the nun at the train station,and he tells her he is dying and afraid.  She tells him to do something good with the time he has left.

If you don't finish this game then you are missing out on one of the best games ever developed.

Everything is epic - the story-line, the characters, the map, the graphics, etc.  It draws you in and keeps you there.  I never felt there was a dull moment in the game.  Whether you are a casual gamer or hardcore, I think you'll find this game to be for you.

author: Daniel S.
title: Great expectations, but dissapointed!!!
content: First of all wanted to say that i've preordered the game and waited to play it. I was really excited and everything, but once I've started playing it, it did not feel at all as a game that I would enjoy. After playing Horizon: Zero Dawn and God of War,  I can tell that this game cannot come even close to these two games, despite the fact that one of the game is almost 2 years old (Horizon). The game looks sooo bleak and lifeless, controls are very sluggish and you have a feeling like you are walking in a swimming pool the whole time. At some point my fingers start hurting for pressing the buttons too hard. The controls are too complicated and there are like 50 different controls for all the actions you can make in the game. I almost always press the wrong button and most of the time kill someone and then i have to run. The story is not bad, but nothing interesting and it's really slow paced, and the dialog is constant so after few hours into the game you are like anoyed when two characters start chatting. I'm playing games from 1997 and I can tell that this is by far one of the biggest dissapointments. Even the graphics are not on the level it should be with all that hours spent in production and the 100GB of data. Probably I was expecting to much and I can say too much realism in the games it's not fun.  We have our lifes for realism, games should be little bit more fun.

author: David L. Dick
title: After the hype dies!
content:
I played a considerable amount of RDR1 and I thought this would be a no-brainer. Well, I can't give it an "A". I'm not going to go in to some of the details the other reviews have, but for me the game just didn't evolve into a modern game. It's mostly like RDR1 with horse bonding.
Value = B+ I paid for the $80 version. I wouldn't say this game is a ripoff, I just have a hard time justifying the extra dollars for what I got compared to other games at $60.
Game play/Fun to Play = B+  It's mostly like RDR1. It's possible to fast travel at a point in the game but you never really feel like you should. In addition, you can take the train or ride the coach but the incentive is to ride your horse, bond and address any side missions that pop-up. There's lots of riding your horse just like in the first game. The game is big too.
Graphics = B  I almost gave graphics a C+. My game looks a bit fuzzy on PS4 Pro. I thought it might be my Sony 4k 55" television so I moved the game to my gaming monitor to test it. The game just doesn't pop for me. It's fuzzy looking with very few details. It's also not utilizing any HDR for contrast to help the game pop. Meh!
Cinematics = A- There's some good facial animations here & cut scenes. I wouldn't say this is ground breaking or industry leading, but it's good enough for an A- in my book. It feels disconnected more than it should to cut scenes.
Music/Soundtrack = B  I play on 7.1 surround sound usually and I think the soundtrack would actually be pretty good if they could just integrate a few more dynamics. When I play with headphones on I get more of those nuances but I just can't give it an A.
Story = B  I guess I was hoping for a bit more zest in the characters. Most of the characters including Arthur Morgan are a bit unmemorable. I can't say it's an altogether bad story. I just think there should have been more interesting characters.
Controls = B+ This game plays very similarly to the first one. I thought the controls were wonky in the first game and this one feels about the same. Everything works pretty well from the horse. Dead Eye is nearly the same as the first game IMO. The gun play just never feels smooth on foot. After many, many hours of play, I still don't feel like it's a much of a fun shooter. In addition, I think more thought should have gone into menu access and how it interferes with game play.
In my weighted average spreadsheet the game scored just over 87. I weighted value and game play heavier at 25% than the other categories. I could perhaps bump this game up to an A- on PC if it looks and sounds better.

author: Dodge J.
title: Another sequel that disappoints.....
content: It's a beautiful looking game, but that's it. What a huge disappointment for me and us gamers that this is all games have to offer anymore. The controls are very very sluggish, and frustrating. Nothing fluid about it. A terribly cliche story line that has been told in any western movie ever made. Having such a large map is actually a draw back here as the lack of a quick travel option makes it well.....not fun. It's just a hassle to be forced to run around for 20 min to get my perfect pelt back to sell....that is if my horse doesn't fall over for no reason and ruin the pelt. Repeat as necessary. Who has the time to spend 5 hrs trying to hunt a perfect pelt to craft a pouch so I can hold 3 more carrots?! WTF? Not fun guys. As you can only craft with "perfect pelts" it just becomes a hunting game. If i wanted that, I'd by hunting game. Side missions are horrendous....doing favours for ppl you don't care about for no reward. Just not fun. Do I care if my horses scrotum shrink in cold weather? Why would that matter!! Who cares! How bout some playability for a change!? Replay value!? Actual content?! None here folks. What a sad decade for gamers. Don't believe the hype, it's a poorly made game that will leave you frustrated and disappointed.

author: Kelsea Willoughby
title: Stunning Cinematic Masterpiece
content: I purchased this game for my husband for his birthday- being a huge fan of RDR, he was excited to get his hands on this gem, albeit a little hesitant due to the high standards he had set. This game not only met all of those standards, but the ending leaves a lasting effect on you, standing as one of the best video games he has had the pleasure to play (and I have had the pleasure to watch unfold) to date. While the game does have a slower pace at times, the ending is cinematic and absolutely beautiful, especially when you think about how far the character has grown. If you are looking for a game where story isn't everything but game play is and you do not appreciate character development, look elsewhere- this game is a fantastic story that surpasses RDR and touches every one of your feelings.

author: D. Rose
title: Incredible technical masterpiece, but a little bit of a slog
content:
Graphics: Unbelievable. Shocking what they can get a PS4 or Xbox to do. The art direction and world they've created is a marvel. Tiny details everywhere really make the world immersive and a joy to be in.

Music: Incredible. The music always fits the time, the situation that's going on at the moment, etc. There's a couple original songs with lyrics during important parts in the story.

Voice acting: Unmatched. Every character is voiced very well. Though all of the "gruff old cowboy" voices can sound the same at times.

Story: Really well-done. I don't recall many games that have such a strong character arc. The characters really grow and develop over time, for good and bad.

Amount of stuff to do: Overwhelming. You could play this game for hundreds of hours if you wanted to explore everything and collect all the things.

Gameplay: Kind of a slog honestly. At times I'd wonder to myself. Why am I even playing this? The game loop boils down to:

1. Find and start mission by talking to someone or going somewhere.
2. Watch cutscene.
3. Spend 5 - 10 minutes traveling to the mission.
4. Watch cutscene.
5. Something happens and the area turns into a shooting gallery.
6. Use lock-on targeting on bad guy, then move cursor up very slightly for a headshot.
7. Kill 30 people.
8. Travel back to mission start for 5 - 10 minutes.
9. Watch cutscene.
10. Repeat.

Sometimes it felt like I should just watch a highlight summary of the story on YouTube instead of actually playing the game. Or that it would have made a good TV show or movie, rather than game.

I get that they want you to explore their incredible world while traversing between missions, but it just didn't feel compelling to me. I would usually turn on the cinematic camera mode (which has auto-pathing) then watch YouTube or read a web site until I arrived at the mission. Fast travel exists, but is very limited.

Most of the gameplay in the game boils down to riding your horse and mashing the X button (on PS4), or the afore-mentioned lock-on targeting and headshots.

There are tons of unlockables, hidden items, legendary animal hunts, trinkets and talismans to craft for bonuses, but none of it felt necessary or that compelling. It unlocked cosmetic items, or passive stat boosts that weren't in any way needed to complete the game anyway.

Summary:

The game is a technical and artistic masterpiece. But the gameplay is pretty dull. If you are young with tons of time on your hands or just love immersing yourself with a game world and exploring and completing things, you can spend hundreds of hours here. If you're a busy parent that is just in it for the story and some diversion, it's still worth it for the story and experience, but power through the main story and then call it quits.

author: Daniel
title: My opinion amongst many I disagree with
content: I was eager to voice my opinion when I saw a lot of the user reviews for this game. I do a lot of shopping on amazon and I rely on it for good reviews also. Many are aware of the high praise this game has received from most critics. It is one of the best reviewed games of all time. Critics are not always right. However, just because it has been hailed by critics does not mean it deserves to be dissected in a way that another game that had not been as critically acclaimed. Red Dead Redmeption 2 is not perfect. However, it is a great game and a staggering technical achievement. It’s size and scope are unmatched. The closest case would be GTA 5, but I still would not say that even it’s world or level of detail was the same as RDR2. To me, there is no denying the fact that this is one of the most impressive interactive worlds ever. The story is good. It is a longer, slow burn story that is more similair to GTA 4. In turn, it’s aspects of realism are more familiar to GTA 4 as well which is going to please some and disappoint others. Grand Theft Auto 4 is another hugely acclaimed game that was called boring, and too dull, too realistic. I strongly disagree with those opinions and I felt that before this game, that was Rockstar’s greatest achievement. It was grounded in reality, told a great dramatic story in an incredibly realistic world and served as a reimagining for the franchise. I had never felt more involved with a Rockstar game. This game has not only met that criteria for me but perhaps exceeded it. While I loved GTA 5 for other reasons, it’s humor, and the fun factor it had, I always liked 4 better. I feel that this game leans more towards GTA 4’s style but doesn’t forget those that loved 5, as it includes humor and ridiculousness. This game has not forgotten Red Dead Redmeption either, honoring it, and improving it in all the right ways to become a great prequel story that honors its fantastic roots. Sure, this game is a little clunky control wise and it can feel slow, and deliberately focused. Play it, beat it, and if you’re like me you’ll keep playing long after because there is so much to explore after the adventure, after you’re reminded why it had to take so long to establish its purpose characters and story. When I’m appreciating this game, the negatives that exist are so small in comparison to its accomplishments that I could never say they take away from it being a masterpiece in my eyes, as someone who has beaten it, and played and loved Rockstar games for a long time

author: Ben
title: Do not leave your horse on the train tracks. I repeat, do not leave your horse on the train tracks.
content:
I liked pretty much everything about this game. I still haven't beaten it, but I've got probably 40 hours on it. It is a wonderful way to live out your childhood dreams of being a cowboy/bandit, but with better dental hygiene and none of the dysentery. From the very beginning, this game is a masterpiece. From the footprints and impacts you and other creatures/people leave in the snow, to the mechanics involving cold and horse extremities, everything is super realistic. If you shoot someone, the entry wound and exit wound are based on real ballistics, and juicy as reality. Walk-around with a shotgun is very much like a Gallagher performance, and satisfying when someone punches your horse and you turn them into dust coated paste.
10/10 would recommend if you enjoy some good ol' rootin' tootin' cowboy shootin'.

author: Fernando Dominguez
title: Great production values but...really boring
content:
Great graphics, voice acting, OK writing, unfortunately it's just a pretty boring game.  There's a million things this game lets you do, but I don't really feel like doing any of them, it's all very tedious.  They seemed so focus on making a great Wild West Simulator that they forgot to add the video game part...it's just not fun.

The action parts are good, but it doesn't do anything other games haven't already done in that regard.  I'm not saying it's a bad game, I'm just saying it's not for everyone.  I loved the first one, but I really couldn't care less for this one.  Enjoyed Spider-Man and Horizon Zero Dawn much, much more.

author: J B
title: Amazing on PS4 Pro
content:
This may be the best game I've ever played in a lot of ways. Let me start with a couple of caveats though.

 I've seen a few youtube videos of some pretty glaring glitches (draw errors, clipping, etc). I have seen NONE of these issues on the pro. The only issue I've had with the game so far in technical terms is once (just once) I found a boulder with a collision box larger than its in-game model. That's it. Once.

Also, if you're not into narratives and crafted story where your character is legit held to a social standard and there are consequences for being a sociopath, then I not sure why you would even play red dead in the first place, but this is not your game. The NPCs in this game aren't placeholders, and this isnt GTA. Yeah, if you're barreling through town and smack a townie with your horse and just keep going you're gonna get in trouble.

That being said, this is easily one of the best, if not the best designed game for a single player experience I've played.

 It is spectacularly gorgeous, turning in some amazing textures on a broad scale. Snow and mud and rain have realistic deformation effects on terrain and character models and landscapes look atmospheric and authentic.
Camp management is easy and well worth it if you want to mine the total experience, though if you have an issue with seeing a fairly graphic if simplified representation of animal field dressing you might get a little triggly while hunting.

Interacting with society is layered between your wanted status, your bounty, and your honor. Yeah, it can be easy to do wrong if you aren't paying attention, especially if the onerous chore of watching where you're going is too much for you, and you can rack up a hefty bounty in different territories, but if you have been doing good by the locals they actually dont seem to care. I've pulled bounty hunting missions from the sherrif while I had an active bounty of about 300 bucks and they never batted an eyelash because I didn't go around murdering the townsfolk. Fast forward to a few hours later after I HAVE been a complete murderous rectal chapeau, and my dishonorable self could NOT step into valentine without the classic six gun welcome. Bounty hunters will, however, plague you from time to time and especially if you sit still, be careful when hunting because it's easy to get distracted and a whole posse might go heels on you.

The control system is ANYTHING but clunky.  I think there is a fair amount of conflation between the concept of complex and complicated. This is the former, not the latter. It is a context-based system of presses, holds, and trigger modifiers. For moments of confusion, or stacks of bodies and loot, there is always a list of command options in the lower right corner that literally tell you, in simple, unambiguous terms, what button to press. If this is too much to deal with, I might suggest a hobby or pastime less demanding than video gaming, like staring at the sun, or a wall if the sun isn't your thing.
So I could probably go on and on, but in the end this game is amazing and it will win awards sweetened by the tears of haters who, I guarantee, are NOT taking their copies back.

I cant wait for multiplayer.

10/10 would wait years for a sequel this good again.

author: Gunner
title: I don't play Online so ....

I trim my beard, cut my hair and Feed Myself and my Animals at home in my REAL LIFE. Why the HELL would I want to do my CHORES for FUN !?!
This game was WAY, WAY, WAY Over-Hyped !
If someone would have let me borrow their disk for a couple hours, I NEVER would have bought one.
Two stars was being generous. I tried to play it a second time but I just cant be that Bored for that Long again.

author: Nima
title: Rockstar Games Never Disappoints!
content:
Got a PS4 Pro and a QLED TV to play this game at its finest.

RDR2 is a nice combination of Rockstar's previous titles: The open world experience is a bigger and more detailed version of GTA. The core shooting mechanics is similar to what we have seen in Max Payne 3. The level of interaction with the environment is inherited from L.A. Noire.

The story telling is rich, and reminds me of titles like Witcher 3 and Fallout 4. Almost all the main and side quests are fun and entertaining. I sometimes find myself riding my horse around to do hunting and explore the world, or meet new people, and acquire new my weapons.

My girlfriend loves the game too and we had plenty of fun playing it together or individually. I highly recommend this game to whoever is interested in experiencing a true next-gen game (unlike the mediocre experience that some other titles like Assassins Creed have to offer)!

author: buescher@jhu.edu
title: Boring!
content:
Great Wild West simulator, terrible game.  Excellent voice acting, but the story is meh.  HDR mode caused my tv to display a lot of rendering artifacts.  The mini games and activities are awful.

Within 5 minutes I went from being a respected lawman to accidentally shooting a dog I really just wanted to pet.  Since it was in town, there were witnesses.  I was hoping to convince them to not report me, but they got shot too and in a THAT-ESCALATED-QUICKLY situation, it wasn’t long before I was in a shootout with the law and had a big bounty on my head.  Well, I guess I will just be a bad guy.  Except the controls are too clunky for me to kill all the lawmen after me.  Good thing there isn’t really a save system to undo this-  not that I want to repeat another minute spent chopping wood anyway.

author: Rory
title: A brilliant world to explore, bogged down by its story
content: RDR 2 in some ways is one of the greatest games I've ever played. Tons of customization and upgrades, interesting and bountiful side quests and random events, an absolutely beautiful world to explore, great music, and compelling characters. However, the main story overstays its welcome by 40 or so hours, and only a handful of those extra hours are fun. For the first half of the game, the story is captivating and interesting, but it eventually buckles and collapsed under its own weight. If Rockstar had shown restraint they could've had a masterpiece on their hands, instead, it's just a great game and an unmatched technical marvel. The game became much more enjoyable after I completed the story, but I simply can't justify 5/5 for that slog.

author: Thomas & Jessii
title: One of the top 5 games I've played! Great value for the money!
content:
You have to experience this game. The story, gameplay, and experience for not to missed.

The game will take most people 60-80 hours to get through, as long as don't plow right through the main story line and miss all the side quests.

Tip: play this game like you were actually LIVING in the shoes of Arthur. Take your time. Explore. Go fishing and hunting. Find the MANY hidden side quests, and oddities hidden in the massive world. There's far more than the very long and wonderful story. If you play only the main story quests, you're missing the core bit of this game.

It's rare for a game to get you captivated by the environments, and activities. Find yourself playing poker, or fishing for several hours. It's a joy and something that is priced FAR too low for the amount of playtime and enjoyment you'll get out of it.
