author: Adam
title: The reviewers have deceived us
content:
I bought this game digitally through PSN, and man! what was that ?!
one piece of an advice to my fellows gamers "DON'T BELIEVE THE HYPE"

Pros :
High Production values .

Cons : (I will only mention a few of many here )
1- Very very bad controls
2-shooting is not fun (I enjoyed shootings in some games like Uncharted and TLOUS and Battlefield but maan!
isn't this game suppose to be a cowboy game when shooting is the main focus thing and most polished element in the game ?!!
shooting is not fun and the aim assistant is just ridiculous (I know I can remove it but still controls sucks any time you try to shoot without it )
the red eye is just too powerful and ridiculous .

They should have copied uncharted shooting mechanism if they cant invent a proper one for the 3rd person view
and copied battlefield or call of duty shooting mechanics for the 1st person view.

3- camera ffff... camera transition between 3rd person to 1st person is not smooth and it sucks and the 1st person view is just too clunky. (the transition made the screen disappeared for like milliseconds which killed it for me to switch during shootouts ) and the first person is just the worst

their are many other cons I will not mention here because the above were enough to make me stop playing the game,

I don't understand the 10s that the game have got its 6 at best..
Reviewers either st*pid and just follow the hype, or they are just greedy bast%ds who just got paid...

it make no sense and no excuse for rockstar to not develop a proper shooting mechanism with all the billions of dollars they make)

and one last thing; RAGE engine is just S*CKS!! while the landscapes looks beatiful, the character models and character skin is just BAD... with all the billions they made they should by now developed and engine like EA's forstbite engine or even better !!!!!!!!!!!!!!

$60 wasted.

Disregard all the negative reviews because they do not agree on one thing or another. Take it for what ot is and enjoy the beauty of this game!!!

content:
Very high expectations for this games turned out to be a big disappointment.

The game looks beautiful and there is a lot of contents.

But it's just painful to play. Everything takes forever, with a lot of unnecessary interactions. The controls are infuriating. Every button is overloaded with tons on meanings. For example L2 is to interact with characters but it also means to aim your gun if not "near" a character. This leads to dumb situations pointing your gun at random characters and pissing them off. This usually means screwing a mission or getting a bounty on your head. Very frustrating.

The game is just not so much fun to play.

author: Gloudas
title: VR Chat Reviews Red Dead 2
content:
All comments below are provided from VR Chat players:

**STORY SCORE: 5**
Well, I mean the character development so far in like in the story, like, we learned like the backstory of everyone. And that’s, I like that about the story, cause you learn everyone, about everyone.
But I like how they develop the characters though. I’ve watched some gameplay. I don’t know. I just like that, I just like some of the characters in the story. That’s it.

**BATHING SCORE: 8**
It sounds great that you can take a bath and get clean.
But it sounds like an 8. It’s a great 8.

**FACIAL HAIR SCORE: 10**
Facial hair for the game would be great, because as you said you can change your look in the game just by shaving so
say you have a giant beard, you do something illegal, they're gonna find you and then just run away shave off your beard and then you (sorry for the background noise) and then you can just like avoid the police.
So yeah. Facial hair in the game is amazing.

**XBOX vs PS4**
(shakes head)

** GRAPHICS SCORE: **
(no response)

**COMBAT SCORE: 7**
Based on what I’ve seen because and what I’ve played of GTA 5, I’d give GTA 5’s gunplay a 5. I’d give this maybe a 7.
There’s like small things you can do like, an extra trigger, like fire of the trigger, will like cock the gun, or something like that.
Gunplay’s a huge deal for me. Like, if there’s a gun, if the game has good gunplay, that, it’s what makes it fun.
Like I wanna go into making game systems so it’s like shooting models is one of the things you need to deal with.
*THIS IS BASED OFF OBSERVATIONS, NOT ACTUAL IMPRESSIONS OF THE GAMEPLAY*
Because otherwise people are just gonna be like: “So this person thinks that this like actually play this and think this is bad!” And I’m like “No, I have never played it. I have not played it. I WILL play it once it’s on PC."

**RED SCORE: 8**
Because blood. I don’t know.
It’s kind of hard to make a review on a game you’ve never played.

**CARS SCORE: 5**
Because I like cars. BMW F36.

**HORSES SCORE: 9**
Again it’s really realistic, and like, you can actually move around with the horse and it takes a long time to actually train one.
Yeah and apparently, if the weather’s cold, the [male reproductive organs] shrink.

**OVERALL SCORE: 7.43 / 10**

author: SleepingKnight
title: "SHUURE!"
content:
What can I say other than the fact that my husband and I have both really enjoyed playing Red Dead II.

The game is long, the story is thought out, the side stories might even be my favorite as how funny and random some of them are, over all this game has knocked it out of the park. The graphics are fantastic, the scenery breathtaking, the fighting and shooting is pretty straight forward as well. I will say there are a LOT of controls you have to learn but once you get it down, it's all pretty fluid.

Honest to God the biggest downfall of this game is the horse mechanics. I played Zelda Breath of The Wild last year and was amazing at how they went into enough detail with the horse mechanics that if you ran through a forest your horse didn't run STRAIGHT into a tree (like a real horse). But with Red Dead, the horse mechanics are the thing that is most lacking in my personal opinion and the greatest downfall of the game. However, on the flip side of that, it's all the one that make you laugh and yell the most because your horse will do the most craziest sh*t you've ever seen and it's always at a very pivotal moment too.

Do yourself a favor and buy the game, play it, explore, enjoy the characters the story the voice acting, all of it. The game is a work of art and I cannot wait to see what they come up with next.

author: Dailz
title: Game of the Year
content:
Rockstar is the only AAA game company worth pre-ordering at this point. They always seem to deliver.
The story is rich & compelling, along with social commentary & satire.

Is it a perfect game? No. The load screens take a long time, the quirks like taking away your rifles as you dismount into a firefight, unreliable horse A.I., & the drawn out prologue are all weak spots.

But the sheer enormity of the maps, the detail to world-building, the multi-faceted options in free roaming available, & detail to character development more than make up for it. I'm in my 3rd month of playing the game & still haven't grown tired of it. If you're looking for a game to hold your attention, then grab this one & saddle up, cowboy!

author: Steyata
title: Great game, well worth the wait!
content: This is a great game, with a great story that keeps the player immersed and involved in everything. Yes the first few hours are slow paced, but once you get past that and get used to the controls + mechanics it gets much better. Anyone expecting a grand theft auto or action game this won't be for you. Rockstar have really outdone themselves this time around. There is so much to see and do in this world I couldn't help, but get sidetracked by the side activities along with exploring the world. I played it for 8 hours straight, that's pretty rare for me. Anyway if you enjoyed the previous Red dead redemption or you enjoy mature, well done story driven games with choices then you will enjoy this game.

author: A. Tran
title: Good story but ruined by many flaws
content:
I had a blast playing this and the amount of content makes it worth every penny. I was a little scared when people say this game has limited fast travel but after playing for awhile I figured this was a good design. This game has so many things going on that something always pop up when I was riding down the road. There were only a few dull moments but majority of the storyline and sidequests were fantastic.

However, I often found myself wanted to punch the mechanics designer for the following flaws:
1. Arthur always stow his gun away onto the horse that I always go into fights with only my hand guns. Even after specifically setting them into slots in the gunsmith, if I choose to use another weapon or gets a new weapon, the setting resets. And why can't I sell unwanted weapons? I found this supercool shotgun and doesn't need the lower tier anymore but I can't get rid of it, so I have to scroll through a dozen weapons just to find the one I want to use, really?
2. Why can't I run in camp?!?!?
3. Losing honor WAY TOO EASILY! If I kill an innocent bystander then I understand, but how can I lose honor when I loot a dead body in the middle of nowhere?
4.  Crafting was kind of dope but annoying when need to craft multiple of the same items. The advance bullet would be good to use but that requires me to hold onto x forever to craft all of them is insane
5. There's nothing to buy. Money was tight at beginning of game when I tried to upgrade the camp. But 20%ish into it later and finished those upgrades, there's nothing I "can" buy. The stronger weapons are locked until later game and items weren't that expensive.
6. Journal log is a joke since it shows quests that I already finished. As for the quests I want to know more about, it simply provide a short one/two sentence summary. Why does this even exist?
7. Outfits don't give any special bonuses. Even for the outfits you can craft, These things require a shitton of "perfect" pelts with the legendary animal parts only provide additional aesthetics with no extra perks. Why should I bother? Meanwhile the other gears such as the satchel and holster require minimal effort to make and have good bonuses.
8.  Mashing that "x" button just for dashing. For my horse to dash through this vast land, I need to abuse my controller instead of a simple hold to dash.

Do Rockstar developers know the definition of "annoying"?

author: Molly
title: Neat Game, But My Boyfriend Has Turned Into A Cowboy
content: I bought this game for my boyfriend as a surprise since I saw it was the new thing to have! Seems like a cool game with a pretty solid plot about cowboys and the brutal hardships of the Wild West. It has a lot of content, spanning about two discs which both come in the case. Download time is a bit long since it is a very large game, but overall my man seems to be enjoying it...maybe a little too much as he has started to develop some character changes within himself. He has begun speaking in a southern accent, similar to the cowboys in the game, and has started partaking in various hunting trips with his guy friends which he has never done before. He comes back dawned in a cowboy hat, muddy boots with spurs, and a lasso strapped on his belt next to the new pistol he recently went out and bought. I thought he was getting a little carried away, but thought maybe the game had inspired him to try new things. Then I found out that he had invested in a horse...He's begun to use phrases such as, "Howdy", "Git", "Y'all", and has developed a southern dialect all together. He sits and plays the game each night while pouring himself a glass of bourbon. I am unsure of what to do...but I guess that just means it is a really good game y'all. Happy rootin' tootin' shootin'!

author: Particle Ghost
title: A Massive Achievement!
content:
So far, it’s a clever game, with superb cinematics that suck you in with a great first impression, and features very tight and well thought out controls. The world is much larger and more varied than ever before, with thick forests and open fields, great lakes, towns, vast ecosystems and much more. There is so much going on in the games world that there is simply too much to list. It does have a bit of slow start, but a few hours in and things open up like players would come to expect from a open world game.

It feels and plays like its predecessor, but packed with way more layers of interactivity, to the point where if players did go back and play the original game, it would feel more like a demo than the final product. Now sadly, unlike the original, Red Dead Redemption 2 has no difficulty settings, so everyone who plays will be on the same setting, but maybe such a feature will be patched in at a later time.

Combat from horseback also feels better, and the "Dead Eye" returns with a few upgrades this time such as highlights with critical hit areas on a target. There is also a horse bonding system, so how you treat your horse has realistic outcomes. All horses are unique and gives the player a real bond between the two. Your horse can die, and there’s no bringing them back if it happens.

Rockstar has even created over 200 species of animals, all with unique behaviors, every one of them capable of interacting with each other as well as the player. Each region has its own ecosystem, so you will only find animals in their natural habitats and behaving as the species would in the real world. On your travels, you may find a wild horse rolling in mud for fun, down to an alligator dragging a deer into a river, and much, much more.

The A.I is also very impressive, players can speak with any character and select a positive or negative interaction. These play out differently each time, based on your clothes, blood stains, mud, location, what the NPC is doing, your honor rating, how much alcohol you’ve consumed, and much more. There is a broad range of possible interactions. While GTA 5 and the original Red Dead was still top notch, they where both originally created for PS3 and Xbox 360, so the team was very limited by hardware limitations. Now for the first time ever, Rockstar has truly been able create a next gen version of open world games, and it really shows that they used all of the available resources at their disposal.

Graphically, the game looks fantastic, with well lit interiors and fantastic moonlight, down to even being blinded from the sun, and it will all vary depending on the weather. Even the blood smears are thought out, wagons wheels being covered in mud, rust that builds up on firearms, there is simply an outstanding attention to detail. There is so much attention to detail, that the game cannot be held on a dual-layered Blu-ray, it comes on two disks! The installation size is 105GB, and will take around 40 minutes to install each disk.

Final Verdict:

This is a game that packs to much content to go over in a single review, without it becoming a 50 page report. Red Dead Redemption 2 does stand as being one of the greatest games of our modern age. It’s polished beyond expectations with great storytelling, it's fun to play, great controls, tons of content, everything one would come to expect from a Triple-A game. After all, we are talking about Rockstar, and it is obvious by now they are unparalleled in raising the bar for years to come. In this case, make it a decade.....or two.

author: mattman
title: Early bug wasted many hours, still no real fix.
content:
First off, I was so excited for this game. I really enjoyed the first one.
The first few hours of this game are sloooooowwwww.

I played on because I had some friends say it gets better. I kept chugging along in Chapter 2. Did some hunting, did some quests, yadda yadda. It got slightly better, but felt kind of directionless.
Sure there were some quests here and there but there didn't seem to feel like any connectivity between them. It felt a bit too 'open world'.

I read something about fishing and thought to myself, " wow, I haven't gone fishing yet!" Lets try that.

I did a quick search to see how to fish. I thought you just had to find the guy who sold you a pole and away you went.
Nope.
There's a quest, early on in Chapter 2, that unlocks this skill for you.
Ahh no problem, let me go and get that quest.

Well it turns out, the person that gives you the quest is in your camp. Great! Let's go get it.
Nope.
That person is nowhere to be seen.
Quick Google search later...
"RDR2 Has a Deadly Bug That's Easy To Trigger"
Wait, what?

Turns out, there's an early quest in Chapter two “Polite Society, Valentine Style”, that if you screw up, will make several people in your camp not show up.

No big deal you say. I don't care about hearing their stupid dialogue!
Well, those people give you quests, many quests it turns out. Quests that lead to other quests, such as the fishing tutorial quest.

I'm now 20+ hours in, almost finished with Chapter two, and I'm now learning of this HUGE bug.
Rockstar did patch this, but they DID NOT FIX THE ISSUE IF YOU'VE ALREADY TRIGGERED THE F'ING BUG!

That's right. I have to restart the game if I want to see any of those quests.
Yes, the people are back in camp after that patch, but the quests they had are not popping up.

No wonder the game felt directionless. Many of the early quest givers weren't there to give me the quests I needed at the start of the stupid game and now that they're back, they're still not giving me the quests I missed.

Huge disappointment.

author: Joseph D. Land
title: It's alright
content:
I've been playing for about 8 hours now I have a pretty Luke warm reception to this game.  It's not that it's a bad game by any means (it's incredible in many ways) it's just that it isn't really capturing me. The game just isn't that fun and I'm not blow away by the world because I've seen this all before only in MUCH MUCH more interesting scenarios like in Horizon Zero Dawn.

So far the game is a little boring.  A lot of what is dragging down my fun factor is the game play.  Maybe it's a Rockstar thing because I recently replayed GTA5 on the PS4 and I couldn't get through it due to the clunky game play and I kind of feel like it will be the same here.  Everything about the world gameplay wise just feels off to me and poorly thought out.  Moving the character through the world feels like walking through a swimming pool and the standard SLOOOW pace of the movement is beyond irritating just adds to the boring, slow feeling of the opening sections of the game.  I've heard people say "well the slow walking forces you to be immersed in the world", you are immersed in the world simply by playing it if... what developer thought that walking speed was a good idea. Gun play and the cover system just feels clunky and strange (again... to ME personally) and that is a serious bummer because gun fights feel more frustrating than fun. Some might not mind it but it just didn't feel fluid enough for me.

The foundation of ANY game is solid, game play and controls and this is my main issue with the game itself.  When you are playing a game with solid gameplay, you should almost forget you are holding the controller.

It's not like that with this game.  Here you are CONSTANTLY aware of the controller because you will probably still be fumbling with the controls 12 hours in.  Here is a perfect example of the stupid game design. Drawing your weapon and talking to someone is mapped to the SAME BUTTON.  So if your gun is unholstered, you may accidently draw on them when you meant to just talk, which starts a fight.  Now I want realism in games, but I want intelligent realism.  I want the realism of the idea that drawing a gun should be a monumental action in this world that is a matter of life and death and, therefore, it should be next to impossible to accidentally draw your gun once you are aware of the controls.  The develops didn't think of this though, but they DID think to make your horse crap and give each animal it's own skinning animation.  So at least we have that.  Rockstar CLEARLY put all the money into making the world better at the sake of more solid game play and I don't like it.

The game is beautiful and the musical score is stunning but, again, we've been here before over and over again so those things just don't have as much as an impact on me when core game mechanics are lacking. I'm hoping that it has a killer story to kind of save the game for me and I'm not saying this isn't a great game, I'm simply saying that it's "okay" for me hence the three stars.  So far I am connecting with the characters and I am sure the review will go up to at least a 4 but, I'm sorry, there is no way this game is a 10/10

In the end, I am not saying you shouldn't buy this game but I'm just saying I haven't been blown away.  To me that is a testament to how amazing games as a whole have become rather than my disappointment with this particular title.

I did run into some game ending bugs and maybe there will be some patches to improve the experience so, if you aren't playing it by now maybe wait a could weeks for them to patch it up.  In the mean time you can play the Spiderman DLC, which is what I will do and return to RDR in a couple weeks

EDIT: 11/5/18

I've continued to play the game and, story wise, it gets better.... much much better.  Unfortunately it takes about 20-25 hours until you get into the good story material but it is well worth it because you finally get to play through some epic moments in this game. The voice acting and characters are just so phenomenal in this game and I've really grown to love the character of Arthur Morgan even more than John Marston.

I was so impressed with the story that I considered raising my review of this game to four stars and I may end up doing that but for now, for every stupid game mechanic I get used to, another one takes it place. Simple things that could make the game much more convenient to play are overlooked.  Want to clear out your weapon inventory and only carry your favorite weapons?  Sorry, once you pick up a weapon in this game it is your forever, you can't sell it and your can't even drop it.  Why not just equip the weapons you love and be done with it?  Because the developers designed the game so that the game frequently unequips all your two handed guns forcing you to remember to equip  EACH and EVERY TIME and this has been continually frustrating because I'm often stuck in battles with only my pistol rather then my rifle because the game CONSTANTLY does this.  But remember, you have add realism of needing to take a bath, but it's impossible to drop a weapon once you pick it up.

Another thing that's really getting on my nerves is the bounty system.  I won't go into it too much but the game pretty much harshly punishes you for crime, which wouldn't be a big deal if it didn't also punish you for things that are clearly not a crime.  The most annoying thing is riding a horse through town, one mistake of bumping into someone will cause them to run to the cops and cause a chase.  It's beyond annoying.

So again, the game gets better but the stupid game play decisions and bad controls continually make the game less and less fun than it could be.  A reviewer at IGN said it best "RDR2 doesn't care if you are having fun" and I think that perfectly sums it up.  It's sad because this game truly COULD have been amazing if the developers just put more effort into the things of the games that actually matter rather than focusing so much on pointless details.

My recommendation is to WAIT for them to patch this game and then enjoy a better experience than us early adopters had because the story elements of this game are truly spectacular, they are just held back by terrible game play.

author: WRC
title: Feels Like a Film
content:
Where to start?  As a lifelong millennial gamer, I've seen a lot.  Regarding more recent games that require extensive voice-acting, Rockstar has always been a cut above in terms of quality, but this game take it to another level.  While the gameplay is nothing novel for Rockstar compared to GTA and previous Red Deads, the sheer magnitude of literally everything make this game a cut above anything done before.  Some categories where this depth shines:

- Characters.  Each feels unique and is revealed slowly like a film.  The voice acting is nuanced, dynamic, and believable.  You never get the impression that someone was just reading the lines because it's a video game and gamers just want to ride a horse and rob people anyway.  Even the most peripheral, limited use characters are quirky, unique, and memorable.

- Environment.  The size, the detail, the fact that you almost never hear similar side-dialogue over and over again (like in Skyrim from guards and shopkeepers).  Even once you do, it's so high quality that it doesn't feel trite at all.

- Story: captivating, artistic, deep.  Take your time.  You'll choke up.  You'll laugh.  You'll hate, be angry, and regret, love, and feel guilty, on a scale like that of a quality western film.  As someone who has played RPG's and can just want to grind grind grind to get to the next stage, level, etc, this game easily slows you down.  Each time you load in, note the camera angle and lack of interface.  Ahhh.  A freakin' video game can induce this emotion, a video game!  Others have tried, and Rockstar has infinitely succeeded.

These are just some of the standouts.  Go live a classic western now.

author: SourPatchOni
title: The game is fine
content:
Take some of these low star reviews with a grain of salt, while horse travel can be slow there is plenty to do out there while you go from A to B/C/D, to the point where the game generates the content itself in the form of animals to hunt, people to interact with and crazy Easter eggs.

Here are some things you should know before going in.

Travel - there is limited fast travel in the form of trains and carriages in main towns, you cant just press pause or tab and pick a spot you have been to on the map. however every area is accessible right out of chapter 2 with some limited to the brave and foolish.

Narrative - there is a lot and not just in mains story line quests in side quests you will find yourself traveling with a companion to the next job and actually having a chat with them, if narrative is not for you you might find this part "boring and tedious". I myself am a fan of fast paced games but didn't have a problem with this as job are usually located close to the quest start.

Shooting/interacting - it CAN take some getting used to, there were times where a slip of the finger meant I just blew some poor guys head off buy complete accident. Don't go into this expecting it to be some ez-breezy brain dead mechanics shooter. too shoot you need to aim first(R2) or unholster your gun(R1) in most chases and press R1 before talking to anyone friendly to holster your weapons

Side stuff - Again there is A lot of it, but its not always just handed to you, you can fish, hunt, craft, Poker, Dominos, Show girls, collect debts, help random strangers you meet or just go on a mindless rampage.

Morality - There is a morality system, while I have not noticed any differences(mainly because I'm still on the first play through) My guess it if your nice, you get greeted too and people are friendly if your naughty people come after you(a guess).

Hunting - I'm just barley getting my feet wet with this feature but holy crap some of them move fast, especially legendary animals and if they catch you, Oof.

All in all I give it a 4/5, Only because I got the game for online. The game is beautiful, well done with few hiccups and could keep you busy for days if you let it. I don't really know how long I've played this but I've had it for about 4 days and I haven't been able to put it down.

If Online is just as good I'll give it 5 stars.

author: C. Moeller
title: God awful
content:
Do you have too much time on your hands?
Enjoy doing chores?
Really like a buggy game that likes to waste your time?

This game is for you!

This game has so many flaws. From taming horses never working, shooting animals and people in the head multiple times and have them keeping on coming, tripping on an invisible rock on your horse, killing you both, just a blast.

This game does have a large world, and characters that will chat about their daily lives and chores.

But I really wouldn't force my worst enemy to play this for longer than a few minutes. It's really one of the most frustrating, irritating, waste of time 'games'.

I can see how people with no lives, way too much time on their hands, enjoy tedious meaningless chores, don't know about meaningful relationships, dialog, story, gameplay, or the meaning of "fun" might enjoy this game.

But if you enjoy gameplay, story, or a fun game, you're better off spending your time playing one of the million bejeweled clones out there.

I enjoy most games in one way or another, but I'd rather be working, or chores than have to play another minute of this.  I would return it if I could in a heartbeat.

author: Stephen
title: Finally I gave up after finishing 20%.  Totally disappointed !!!
content:
I was so excited to get this game but after over 15 hrs I decided to give up (20% progress). Every time when I thought to give up due to frustration, I told myself maybe I need a little bit more time to get used to it. NOW, I THINK IT IS THE TIME !!!

Pro: pretty good graphics (but not amazing), beautiful landscape.

Con:
1. Boring and tedious. As a game, it is supposed to give gamer fun, right? I played RDR1, GTA5, Horizon zero dawn, assassin creed: origin, the witcher 3: wild hunt. god of war etc and I enjoyed them a lot. But for RDR2, i didn't have that feeling. I lost interest very quickly and I don't even remember when is the last time I had this feeling. It is a Big Failure for RDR2 !
2. Terrible health setting! I need to eat, my horse too, otherwise, the health will go down. Bad ideal ! Not fun!
3. No fast /easy travel, have to ride the horse and go a long distance. Not fun !
4. Clunky movement, especially when you move Arthur in a house or at camp. he moves like a very old man. Not fun!
5. Boring shooting and fighting. Not fun.
6. Boring main missions and side missions. Not fun.

I am glad it decided to give up and now I have time to play others games !!!

author: Cody Meeker
title: Bait and Switch (100+ hours)
content:
If you have to have it for the Story, SAVE OFTEN.
The game steals from you every chance it gets.  Weapons will randomly drop from your hands, food and tinctures vanish from your inventory.  Settings menu is a joke in this era.  Accessibility options only from the colorblind, none for motion sickness.  3 Options in audio menu.

The cinematic mode you're expected to use to get around is used to kill you unexpectedly as often as possible.  With max health and stamina you can be expected to die in less time than the average human reaction speed.  Even in the middle of a city.  By a chaingun.  Everyone already knows the pathing is terrible, reused from GTA without any improvements.

The story works perfectly long enough for professional reviewers to write how good it is... then it's broken.  From randomly equipped weapons to hundreds of dollars of random bounties that are supposed to be prevented by wearing masks.  Some missions don't count as quests at all, going in guns blazing will net you a ton of negative morality and huge bounties OFTEN.  From the hundred hours I've been playing, the mask and face cover have NEVER worked once to prevent bounties.  I have a $125 bounty in a place I haven't been close to in a dozen hours.

The settings menu is from the 90's in it's simplicity.
No tap to aim in a shooter is unheard of today.
Toggle run is a lie.
Turning kill effects off does nothing.
Sound, score, dialogue are the only audio options which is pathetic in a AAA game.
Turning off dynamic kill cam does nothing.
First person horse riding places your vision in the chest so you can't see over the horse's head.
Colorblind mode but no toggle for screen shake so prepare for motion sickness.
Autosave might as well be called "Save once a RL day."

I'm disabled so I've got nothing better to do in the bad times.  Pass on this until it's better.  GTA 5 when it released and today are literally two different games so I expect the same with this.

author: Leonard DeSilvio
title: boring snoozefest with clunky controls
content:
Boring snoozefest with clunky controls
The idea of an open world western sounded like a game I would enjoy but after playing the game for a few days and completing the first chapter and starting the second chapter I just couldn't take it anymore. The game is as slow as molasses you travel slowly on horse back for perform a miniscule chore and repeat. The character you control walks and runs slower then my 95 year old grandfather. Everything you do is slow slow SLOW! When there is some action the controls are borderline unplayable and the layout of controls is so confusing I could not get used to it. You travel on horseback and walk in the snow until the game gives u a bit of action where a couple of wolves attack. The game is just so tedious and slow it tries to be like real life but I play games to have fun not to spend an hour hunting a deer with a bow, shaving eating setting up a campsite etc. And pigging out on baked beans. You'd literally need invest hours on end to progress in this game. I was midway through a quest it wouldn't even let me save it and now I have to start it from the beginning? Not worth my time! Prior to buying the game I read reviews with similar complaints but decided to try iit out any way since it was so highly acclaimed but it was truly a bad decision and I wasted my money I will be trading the game in.

author: King Lerch
title: A 5 star game plagued with overcomplexity
content:
The graphics are amazing, the voice acting is great, the story is good, the game play is sticky at times but still good, the world is well rendered, the quests are fine, some are great...and you really feel like you are there....like too much

Here are some of the things you will have to do as a player (or real person, hard to tell)
- Find food
- Cook food (with recipes/ingredients)
- Eat food (not too much or you get fat)
- Feed your horse
- Feed others in your camp
- Find $
- Donate $ to the camp
- Shave
- Wear hair gel
- Take your gun to get cleaned
- Look through merchandise catalogs page by page
- Go everywhere by foot or horse, no fast travels
- Pick herbs....like stoop down, rip them out, put them in your satchel
- Skin animals (which takes like 30 seconds)
- Sleep

I am not a player that needs all action all the time, but this is overboard. This game is too lifelike and it's chorey. In the next episode we will be paying bills, doing taxes, laundry, and cleaning floors.

There is another issue that made this less fun, and that is it railroads the player. If you are riding the horse and clip a tree or a rock, you are down. Like down, injured, or dead. If you ride too near a NPC they will shoot you. If you walk too close to a NPC, get on the wrong horse for even an instant, make a wrong move or hit a wrong button...you are railroaded to combat or jail. There is no grey area...this is life. If you make a wrong move...that's it!

I think they took making a lifelilke game too far and it overshadows the fun. I am not *that* far along in the game. Maybe 10%, but I am not longing to play like I was with Assassins Creed. When I think of putting Red Dead back on I think of trudging on the horse again for 10 min to get to town, buying the right tonic, wearing the right clothes so I don't get too hot or cold (yes this is a thing).....I don't think of fun, which is a shame really.

The kicker is that despite all that they allow (require) you to do in the virtual world, the one thing they don't allow you to do in the real world is remap your control buttons. In what PS4 game is the left [ ] button jump?! It is almost always X and is hard to get used to, but complexity ended there for this game as there is no way to change the primary button layout.

author: The Wizard
title: First Impressions
content: As a huge fan of the first RDR, I certainly was looking forward to this. I received it from Amazon day of release. First, you have to load a Data Disc, and then more loading with the Play Disc. It took about an hour and a half. First thing I noticed, was there is no difficulty setting. So, I figured I would die a lot. The first couple missions are linear, so it gives you time to learn the numerous controls that you will be utilizing. The detail and scenery are pretty awesome. You finally get to do your own thing, once you get near the town of Valentine in Chapter 2. I managed to kill my horse, which left me on foot for quite a spell! After that, I decided to start the game over, now that I was familiar with the complex controls. Looking forward to exploring more, as the game progresses. Worth playing, but I still have a soft spot for the 1st game so far. 11/6 - After 2 weeks with this game, I am finding it laborious, slow & no incentive to keep playing it. You wander into a mission that triggers automatically, and you cannot leave it, or it ends with Mission Failed. The 1st RDR was so much better designed. I will keep on trying to play & enjoy this game, but the cumbersome controls, the overwhelming vastness of it, and the slow pace, urges me to play Dragon Quest XI for the thrid time instead...

author: Patrick B.
title: Frightningly long game, I felt like I was in Twilight Zone.
content:
Someone needed to tell the developers that a long shell of a game that once existed is not a game. It is no where near as good a original! It is still a well put together game in many respects but it is also a pain in the ass game! This is a very Slow Western, and the storyline took 4× the amount of time to tell a story as the original. Of course I want more of a game that the original, I just thought they went overboard with this one. By the end I was kind of depressed and angry I wasted 100 plus hours on this game.
  The first problem is that the storyline is not that engaging or dynamic. And basically I find Arthur to be a sad sack, a likable character, but his story is a bit detached and depressing for me. Then to switch to JM in the last quarter of game seemed like a cheap move. Arthur deserved better!
  The game can be reduntant. Pretty much most of the missions end with you killing 40 people in the same way, it's kind of boring. They really should have made more story missions that did not end up with a huge shoot out. Maybe some funny or surprising turnout to make the story more fun.  Alot of tasks and  missions are in the task bar something that took me a while to figure out.  Not on the map where they should be so in that case it makes you think their is nothing to do. Also tasks are chorelike, reward not worth it. The story should have ended about 20 hours earlier, this is like a hundred hour plus game the original was like 40-50 hours tops.  The maps like treasure maps pretty much give you a drawing of a area you have to figure out where it is, not an easy task, I think they should have giving you a bubble to search in, far more effective. Because of the little clues you get with treasure or puzzles this could leave a casual game stumped.
  There are some things they missed in this game: a earned fast travel where you get to go any where on map, faster storyline, wagons where you can build and hook your horses up to, prostitutes that put out, a stage coach business, also river boat business, and taking people from camp on missions like Far Cry .

author: Amy Lynette Pounders
title: Slow beginning, but amazing after that
content:
The first couple of hours of this game is basically the tutorial and story layout. You learn characters, the setting, etc. It seems pretty slow, but once the world opens up, it is anything but slow.

Graphics are gorgeous. I absolutely love traveling just for the simple fact that the environment is so pretty.

The amount of detail in this game is mind boggling. Very very immersive. Stranger missions, random encounters, chats with fellow gang members, all of this comes so fluidly and naturally that I forget I'm playing a video game.

The map is huge. Lots and lots of places to explore, not to mention lots of rare animals to hunt.

The dialogue and voice acting are great, controls are good but there's a bit of a learning curve. Get the controls down because if you don't, you'll probably accidentally become wanted for assault..

Overall, 5/5, I've been playing this game for hours. Most likely the people who found it boring only played the beginning. Sadly they're missing out on the most immersive game I've played in a very long time.

author: Mocosonino
title: Masterpiece
content: So... I happen to have a career and a life so it took me a long time to finish the game and give it it's proper praises. I had kept seeing over and over many complaints about it being "slow" "boring" "tedious" and not giving it a chance. I can only attribute this to limited attention spans and the evolution or de-evolution of games. It seems frenetic shooters and cutsie app games have stunted attention spans. Ironically, the realism and added touches that do make the game slower paced is part of what makes this game so great. I really don't think people truly appreciate what a technical marvel this game is... from its ultra-realistic graphics, the realistic motion captures of the people, horses, geez everything living even bugs. The imprints on the mood, the environment changes, gorgeous sunsets, impactful lighting, and thunderstorms on and on and on. But the heart of the game is the STORY. Rockstar has an ability to make Hollywood quality work and seamlessly immerse you from gameplay to story mode without sacrificing gameplay or story. The story is a sort of prequel to red redemption and did an amazing job laying out the groundwork for the first game. The characters are all lovable and you really get attached to them especially when your like for them is tested given they are outlaws. I cannot say enough good things about this game and the level of quality. oh and the music.... jesus amazing high quality. Even though I knew John's fate, the epilogue really fleshed his story making me like him even more despite loving Arthur. Almost two games in one. Amazing work Rockstar. Amazing. I just hope #playerone games like this are not abandoned to crap like fortnite. We all know what happens when quaility produces move to multiplayer (fallout76).

author: TheOwner

author: Odii Gis
title: One of the best games I've ever played...
content:
This is a great game, folks. Maybe for those "older" gamers like me who appreciate a good story to go along with gameplay.  It's slow, yes, and it took me a while to complete it. But it was well worth it. I think the last 20% of actual gameplay went by fairly quick (that is, the last chapter, not the epilogue).
The graphics are outstanding. I wish I could be there at some of those locations listening to the waterfalls, elk bugles, and misty mountain tops. There are some lag and glitch issues. But for a game of this magnitude, I wouldn't doubt it. No game of this nature is ever perfect. I learned to just get used to it.
The voice acting is great and memorable. Arthur is the best.  I wanted so bad to strangle Dutch and his "I. Have. A. Plan" because all their characterizations are excellent.
Combat-wise was just ok. It's not the hardest. But the side missions can be especially the gunslinger ones.
Soundtrack is amazing. Love a lot of the original music especially that last ride.
And for some of those saying there is no fast-travel... YES, THERE IS! Plus you can auto-ride mode and watch the cinematic ride alongs like your watching a movie (and taking a food/bathroom break).
Totally worth the original price. Even better now.  If you have PSPro, be prepared to be blown away at 60 fps on 4K HDR10.
And be prepared to have some tissue paper on hand AND check "old haunts" during the epilogue.  This game is easily in my top 5 as best game of all time.

author: ZoA
title: A TRULY Interactive open world during and after completion of the game. (SPOILER ALERT!!)
content:
I am so impressed.  Over 100GB required to run??  New Austin PLUS New Eastern States?? This time around Rockstar Games doesn't just deliver the usual open world game that they do.  They rethought the open world into perfection.  This time they wanted players to be able to fully enjoy the lively world even after game completion and how so?  Well this time your health matters.  You need to eat, sleep.  Oh Don't be selfish now..  your all time partner (your horse!) also need to be fed and treated well.
JUST TO NAME A FEW NEW THINGS TO DO:
New Hobbies:
Fishing
Dominoes

Old Hobbies (REMADE!)
Hunting (FEELS VERY NEW!)
Fight with a Grizzily Bear - Intense! - When that thing charged at me almost had to change my under pants! I litteraly screamed!  This time around the Griz Bears doesn't play around.  You get hand in hand combat with the G. Bear.  (Black Bears Are back.  They aren't aggressive like the G. Bear and they will run once see you but they will defend themselves if have to!)
About REPUTATION...  I usually play as a good guy but this time around its harder to make money and I find myself drained of cash oftenly..  this forces me to steal, rob..  I had no other choice guys!  I'm truly really a good guy.. Im sorry but I really needed money and can't find any other way to get it fast! :-(

Dozens of Birds, Mammals, Fish to explore!!
Many types of personalities to meet.

GAME OF THE YEAR in my rating..

Thank You Rockstar and Fans who make this dream a reality!

author: Randy R. Koenders
title: Meh.  Just passing the time til my next game.
content:
RDR2 is such a disappointment--I kept thinking what they could've done with this title-- bank robberies, train robberies with ascending difficulties, gang shootouts, robbing other gangs, cruising on riverboats, dealing with indians (altho the pc crowd might've objected), so many many possibilities.
Here I've helped two women get home after their horses fell lame, helped a romeo and juliet couple send messages back and forth to eachother, killed a lot of people who didn't deserve to die.
And then there are the ambushes--periodically you'll be riding along and 6 or 7 thugs start shooting at you.  There's almost no way you can beat them.  They get some money from you and you wake up and its over and you can't ever go back and do it again--its gone.
And the dumb quests that are a setup: Go through the whole setup to raid a gang and get their money and the story line is right after you're done you'll be surrounded by law enforcement and probably die.  You can repeat it if you saved it, but the result will be the same because the storyline is that you must die.
Worst of all is the incessant riding, bouncing up and down for hours and hours.  No real fast travel.  Riding, riding, riding, riding.  Yes, I get it, there was a lot of boredom in the old west.  You can choose a viewpoint where the screen is bouncing up and down forever, or a viewpoint where you're always looking at a horse's rear end--whichever, but that WILL be the standard view for your whole game.
I can still give it a 3--good graphics, some good quests, an interesting storyline.  I passed the time for a while, but I was always thinking what game will I be playing next?

author: K. F Harkin
title: Absolutely phenomenal investment of gaming time
content:
I have been playing this game for weeks since its release and I am only on chapter 2.  If you are looking for continual twitch response gaming this is not for you.  This is a cinematic story you are at the heart of and a world within which you are immersed.

I am 48 years old and have been a gamer since my first Telstar system.  This game is simply incredible.  Last night I found myself simply fishing for half an hour on an picturesque river bend, tonight I plan on robbing a train.  Occasionally I will just sit by the fire with the gang while uncle plays the banjo and others tell stories.  Some members I love, others I can't stand, and I dread playing to the conclusion because it is clear they all are part of a dying breed in this world where their days are numbered.  For some we know the future based on RDR.  For others we do not and I worry about what is coming...  then I remember I am playing a game!

If you want to be immersed and entertained.  If you want to lose yourself in a richly developed world.  If you do not mind strolling slowly through that world and drinking deeply from every river and pool then this is the game for you.

author: David J
title: Slow But Satisfying
content:
I’ll lead with this. Your enjoyment of this game will hinge on whether or not you are okay with some tedium and slower paced games. The payoff is a great story and a uniquely satisfying setting.

The Wild West may not be everyone’s thing in gaming, and there’s a reason it features in so few games. To accurately portray (in a gaming sense) the genre, you have to slow things down. This means traveling by horse takes longer than driving across GTA by car or flying by helicopter (shocker!).

The game adds in more bits like needing to eat, sleep, and bathe, that annoy some folks who just want to jump in and rob trains and blow things up. That’s their prerogative, but skipping this game for the tedious bits means you miss a beautifully set game with a solid story. Some of us even enjoy the more life-like aspects like hunting for food, stopping in at the general store, and greeting passers-by.

The spontaneous interactions are what make this game seem like the most realistic Western sim I’ve ever played. Random encounters galore here.

There are some major issues like the bandana (robbery mask) not working the way you’d think it does- just google it to see the complaints. Bumping people on your horse can start wild gun fights. Even finishing fights that other bandit gangs start with you can get you a bounty. So there are some annoying bits. No game is perfect though!

Overall the story and solid gameplay mechanics have been enough to keep me hooked and coming back for more. Sometimes you just want to ride your horse through the Wild West and bag a Buffalo before heading into the saloon for some poker. This game is great for lazy enjoyment with some thrills and fast paced action thrown in for fun.

content: The game is a little clunky with menus all over - not one menu with tabs so that everything is all together.  One of the family likes to play open world and just experience everything but this game is a bit tedious.  If you need an animal skin, you study the animal, determine if the pelt is the right quality, and then kill it with a specific weapon - more like work.  We enjoyed Witcher 3: Wildhunt, God of War, Horizon: Zero Dawn - even Assassin's Creed: Odyssey for just enjoying the open world game and relaxing for a while.  There is a lot of talking in RDR2 but we haven't been bonding with the characters.  Maybe the game will pick up but we haven't been pulled into the story yet.

author: Jennifer Dileo
title: Do yourself a favor and buy this game
content:
Just finished Red Dead Redemption 2 last night, and I must say. Wow. Every aspect of that game was just oozing with detail, depth, and beauty. The world is a sight to behold. The amount of detail in everything from the animals to the foliage is just outstanding. Rockstar really put there heart and soul into it. Not to mention the absolutely incredible sound design. The sounds of horses trotting, birds whistling, leaves blowing in the wind, Elk shouts in the distance, npc’s conversing in the distance really ties everything in the world together to fully immerse you in this gorgeous world (a good headset really does it justice). The story is one of the most compelling in any game I have ever played. Arthur Morgan’s journey and character development will seriously keep you emotionally invested from start to finish. All the voice acting is second to none. Some of the best performances I’ve ever heard from the medium of gaming. Just to think the amount of hours the voice actors spent recording all these lines is mind blowing! Especially considering how incredible it is. The soundtrack.... oh my god the soundtrack. Without a doubt the best music I’ve ever heard in any video game. All the tracks are spectacular. From badass music that pumps you the hell up in a huge gunfight, to extremely emotional tracks that will really pull on ur heart strings and make ur arm hairs stand up. The way the tracks tie into the cutscenes and gameplay happening on screen is just so perfect.

With all that being said, this game is easily game of 2018, possibly even one of the best games EVER. Rockstar games poured their SOUL into this project and it showed. Without a doubt their best work to date.

author: Jaded
title: Nice Scenery but Boring
content: I tried to like it. But I knew ahead of time that I might not. I bought Red Dead 1 before 2 was available just to maybe see what all the hoopla was about. I found it incredibly boring. But 2 was getting such rave reviews I wanted to try it. Better than 1 by a good bit but after riding the horse a high percentage of the time and wondering where to go a good bit of the time with the occasional gun fight, where you kill good guys, I decided to move on. Now I have to say if you like wandering around and not a lot of action you will probably like this game. But I played Dark Souls 3 and others like it and loved them. Not boring at all. So my suggestion to you is to really think about what type of game play you like. If nice scenery and wandering around sounds good then Red Dead 2 is for you. If not wait a year or so and buy it cheap so you too can see what all the rave reviews are about.

author: Dave
title: King of casual
content:
I found it to be a disappointment. Visually the game is stunning but is held back by frame rate dips(below 30fps). The pacing is God awful. The tutorials don't stop until the 10 hour mark, and up to that point the missions mostly revolve around tedious busy work rather than cool outlaw stuff. Time outside missions will mostly consist of horseback riding. The controls are clunky. Your character has 2 speeds, snail and light jog. I get that they wanted characters to move with a realistic weight to them but it ends up being more monotonous than immersive. Shooting has not changed at all from the first red dead. Lock on makes every combat encounter lack any semblance of challenge. And dead eye is still overpowered. Also the writers felt the need to insert modern day political stances in a game set in 1899. I won't get too much into it but basically "white privelage" is legit something that's talked about. Again the setting is 1899. It's immersion shattering when stuff like this is shoved in just to cater to political correctness. The themes are also the same as the first game except way more blunt. I'm talking dialog like "our way of life is ending" and other time wasting drivel. There is no subtly to anything. Everything has to be spelled out to cater to the widest audience possible. Also there's a morality meter, in a game where you are playing as an OUTLAW WHO MURDERS PEOPLE. Or in other words, this game is a boring slog of tedious activities. Not bad but certainly not the masterpiece critics make it out to be.

Edit: Those frame rate dips are cross platform baby. So if your like me and have a ps4 pro, you can curse into the air at Sony for selling a worthless product. I recommend the Xbox one x version as that has the best performance of the bunch.

author: M. Freeman
title: So much detail, so little time.
content:
This is the first game I got with my PS4 Pro, and I hadn't had a PlayStation since PS2. I've been a Nintendo person, playing Wii sports (not Wii U, never got that one) or DS games like Animal Crossing, Phoenix Wright, Pokemon.

To be honest, I wanted the PS4 Pro and I didn't care that there was a Red Dead edition in celebration of RDR2 coming out; I just figured if this one comes with a game and is $400, and that one doesn't and is still $400, I should get the one with the "free" game. I'm so glad I did!

RDR2 has details etched into its details. Yes, you do have to spend a lot of real time to play a lot of game time, and you will have to do mundane things like pet/wash your horse, clean your guns, eat food and sleep. However, you will be struck by the beauty of the panoramic views while you're taking 5 minutes for a long horse ride across the map. The game beautifully shows starry nights, lightning storms, rainbows, and vast, picturesque views of mountains, hills, plains, desert, snow, forest, you name it!

Personally, I found it frustrating that there are about 10 buttons on the PS4 controller (including both triggers and pressing down on the analog sticks), yet there are about 1,639 commands for in-game play that require combinations of said buttons or reusing the button just in a different situation therefore it does something different. This was a huge learning curve for me, particularly while playing Overwatch wherein one button = one function.

A lot of people don't like how much toil there is in the game, with the horse cleaning and gun cleaning and self-care, but there is immense story to go along with all of that. There are lots of characters in the game, and no two playthroughs will have the same experience. You can play as an honorable outlaw, or kill everyone in sight, honor be damned. You can greet others or antagonize them; fight on the front line or send your team in to do the fighting for you. There are so many "choose your own adventure" lines of play that I think you could play and replay this game with only a framework of similarity.

Recently an online component was added, which can be frustrating to anyone who doesn't like being hogtied and killed within a few minutes of logging in. I think this will change in the future, but we'll see. Some people like that kind of thing, so if that's you, hop in! Just do me a favor and leave me and my character alone- I just want to ride my horse and hunt, and I have nothing of value for you. (I think this goes for a lot of players, FYI.)

However, you don't need to do online to enjoy this game. The standalone, 1 player experience itself will be very satisfying and enjoyable if the game premise appeals to you even a little bit. It is not only beautiful on screen, but the character acting and voiceover work is very well done. The story is pretty well thought out, and I believe you'll bond to the characters and really care about what happens to them as the game goes on.

I give it full stars for sucking me in when I was an unlikely fan. So many aspects of the game are appealing that I just couldn't resist it from the moment I got it installed.

author: David Cabrera
title: For the PS4 Pro you play with an upscaled, pixelated, blurry game
content:
While i am thinking what to put in this review i am realizing that i am trying to force myself to like the game, maybe because i bought a PS4 Pro just to play this, i am perfectly fine with my PC (I play games like GTA V, The Witcher 3, Far Cry 5, Fallout 4 and others with all the settings maxed out, i have fun, looks great).

When i started playing the resolution of the game seemed too blurry and pixelated, it almost looked like a 720p game with some time-blur effect, my TV is an LG 4K OLED, a beautiful piece of technology, so i knew it was not the TVs fault, I started to investigate if there was a 4K patch or some configuration that would fix that crappy look, only to realize later in forums that this game is just an upscale and also to find out that the Xbox one X does manage to have 4K with RDR2 (I thought both platforms where very similar, my bad for not looking for that).

I would love that Rockstar had mentioned the upscale thing on the PS4 version previously, not after some fans/reviewers discovered it. I probably would have bought an Xbox one X with that info, but i would not even need to buy one if Rockstar released it on PC. Why does a big game creator with all the possibilities it has, limits in what platform you can play the game? Rockstar is playing the console manufacturer game and dragging all their marketing politics with them, you can overhype and sell all you want, but you are really selling your soul as a game creator when doing this, and people will realize that. I am trying to enjoy the game (and my console) but the truth is that i already feel scammed.

author: Alex McCool
title: Boring
content:
Pros: Being a cowboy, lots of mini games, Arthur's commentary talking to himself.
Cons: Feels like a re-skin of GTAV. Combat and controls are no different. Constantly mashing x to run or have your horse run gets really old. Lots of random button prompts.  Controls are clunky, I spend 5-10% if my time just wiggling in place, staring at the bottom right edge of the screen waiting for the right button prompt to pop up so I can perform an action.  Extremely slow paced. Controller is mapped to so many controls depending on what you're doing that I end up shooting people I'm trying to talk to. Horse has auto-follow-road, but ends up getting me killed or even a bounty on my head when it crashes into oncoming traffic.
Overall, this game had promise but to me it was just boring and clunky. I end up turning it off after only a little while to play something else. I wish I'd waited until it was cheaper.

content:

The bad: This just wasn’t the game I was hoping for in red dead 2, it’s very VERY slow paced. You’ll spend a majority of your time riding your horse for real-time 10-20 minutes to do a 5 minute mission and then ride back that 10-20 minutes. The aiming system isn’t great. None of the guns are that special.

The good: this is why I give a 2 star instead of zero - the graphics are great and you can talk to / interact with everyone in the game.

Conclusion: I wouldn’t waste your time or money on this game - I bought it after seeing amazing reviews and was very let down. There are better options out there. I’m not sure why this got such great critic reviews - do they even play the games?

author: C0SM0 SIX5
title: So much potential. To much GTA DNA.
content:
This game has been hyped to much for to long. I'm now 51% through the campaign with around 60 hours of playtime.
Gameplay: solid but not polished at all. Horseback controls are beyond bad. Your horse will run into things no horse would run into while your fighting/shooting. There is no way to slow your horse down and running into things will make you a wanted man.
Gunplay' Way to easy with no real upgrades making a difference. The first revolver does same as the (3rd) Schofield. I've killed alligators at distance with the varmint rifle(.22) and regular ammo.
Story and Honor system fallacy.
"My" outlaw is a trying to be as good as possible. I only kill those trying to kill me and they shoot first. I stop and help every npc along the road knowing they may want to rob me. I donate to every homeless person I see. But when a cutscene happens and I need to collect a debt from a family whose matriarch has died my absolute jerk character can't give a crap. Even though I had over 4500 bucks on me I'm not even given the option to pay the debt which I would've.
Law: this is the clincher. This is where the GTA DNA really "shines"..... So running? Don't hit a lawman. They will swarm and kill you like you assaulted them with an auto rifle. There is no way to surrender. Even a $15 bounty is a death sentence. Sure you can fight and escape but all you do is add to your bounty with every single kill. It's quite ridiculous. Skyrim is old as time and their guards even gave you the option to pay your bounty and go on with the game. Unreal.
Fast Travel: AT some point in the game you will unlock fast travel FROM your base camp. That's it though. When you need to get TO your base you'll be galloping every time. This is insane. Sure exploring is fun. For a while then it's time to get the story moving.
There's no way this game is a perfect 10. Reading that is just a joke. My review score is a 6.5. A little polish could've made it an easy 9 or better.

author: ItsMe
title: One of the best games ever made!
content:
Buy this game! If you play video games casually  or haven't really played much over the last few years buy this game! If you think it's not really your type of game because you aren't into the old west or cowboys I still say buy this game!  The amount of work Rockstar has put into this game over the long development cycle is absolutely incredible and I truly hope to spend hundreds of hours playing in this world. I would argue that any one even remotely interested in this game should give it a try because most people will be enthralled with every second of gameplay.  Red Dead makes you want to interact with every character in the world and each interaction helps to shape your characters personality.  The graphics on this game are amazing and Rockstar really seems to be getting all it can out of the PS4 Pro and the XBOX One X.
 I am also hoping they consider a mode to
Incorporate the PSVR at some point in the future which could be incredible.  This game should take you a long time to finish because it's hard not to explore everywhere and do any little side quest. The voice acting is great and the way the world reacts to you or your previous actions is great.  This game is difficult to even walk away from and is the best looking game ever put on the PS4 pro over the amazing God of War in my opinion. Enjoy!

author: Anthony
title: In defense of Red Dead
content:
Most people who don't like this game are claiming it's from the story being too slow/boring. This is true but only halfway. This game is targeted specifically for original Red Dead fans. However, Rockstar did not alienate newcomers by bringing in a new protagonist, Arthur Morgan. Their are two major reasons why this game starts slow. One is because it's a huge game and it's trying to teach you that its not always time for guns blazing action. And two is to enhance the realism of the world you're playing in. This entry is trying to get players to stop and see the sights, not gun down every npc you come acrossed or always expect loot for your effort.
Basically, if you don't want to play a western civilization simulator, don't buy this game.

author: Ray B
title: Ugh.
content:
Over-encumbered- smothering under its own weight. Stop making the game get in its own way, and maybe it'll actually be fun. As is, it's to frustrating for me to willingly waste any more time on.

Stop drooling over multi-player and finish the game I payed you $60 for.

author: Pacal
title: More a boredom simulator, not a game
content: After nearly 5 hours, and recently being engrossed in God of War for over 20 hours, I don't find anything entertaining about RDD2. Riding the horse and hunting doesn't make a story. Picking up some poor dead guy, carrying him to get help, and getting hunted/killed for it without any recourse other than shooting your way out isn't story development either. Adios, RDD2.

author: Some Guy
title: Misleading.
content: This game is highly rated by critics, not players. It is a beautiful game, and beautifully crafted, but the game itself is pretty dull. The story isn't amazing. You travel about as often as you actually play the game. Generally mindless, boring travel, with not much else. I mean, this would be great for a roleplaying experience in a multiplayer setting, but that isn't what this is. Also, the actual gameplay, such as gunplay, is just bad. Same outdated controls as the rest of the Rockstar games. The characters aren't as interesting as the first in the series, and the main character, while very realistic, and well written, is boring, and dull. I cared nothing about anyone in the entire game, and I found myself playing as long as I did, not because I liked the game, but because I was forcing myself, and waiting for it to get better. It never did. Nothing happens in the story outside of the prologue, for about half of the game, other than moving camps three or so times.

author: Ethan
title: Horribly Designed, But Still Playable and Enjoyable
content:
Red Dead Redemption 2 would be a perfect game if it had a better design and infrastructure to the game.  And by "design," I mean everything when it comes to controls, HUD, interface, game logistics/features, and even the experience of saving the game!  I was able to adjust my play style to make it work with this game and ensure I'd still enjoy it, but here are the issues I have with the design (bear in my mind, I'm reviewing the PS4 version):

1. The Controls.  The controls are nonintuitive and clunky.  It almost seems like the designers said "OK, this is what most games use for button assignment and are, likewise, what most gamers are used to.  Let's completely shuffle that and screw that up for everyone."  It makes no sense to me that I have to press the X button to sprint/run, but I have to press the SQUARE button to climb up obstacles.  The buttons to interact with different items change; picking up a weapon off the floor requires pressing R1, yet picking up a hat on the floor requires pressing SQUARE.  Why?  I have no clue.

2. The Gameplay.  The controls also contribute to making the gameplay more boring when it could definitely be more engaging.  Hand to hand combat is button-mashing CIRCLE until you can land the right punch that knocks your opponent out.  The aiming system seems to be quick but makes it difficult to engage moving targets.  The gameplay elements are given ambiguous and vague details and instructions when guiding players, making it difficult to understand how to simply do a quick draw or know what a "Fence" actually does.  All of the guidance tips are tucked at the top left corner of the screen in small text, and show up for a limited time, making it tough to comprehend how to use the gameplay elements at their fullest potential.  Even items and clothes at merchants don't have pictures or previews to know what they look like before purchasing them (at least from my experience when purchasing masks from a fence).

There are scenes in the game that have inevitable outcomes, yet don't become a cut scene.  For example, at the end of one of the side missions (not plot relevant), the target ends up shooting himself.  The game has suggested that you're able to prevent this from happening, either by shooting his gun away or perhaps by using a lasso.  However, trying all of these will not work and it seems like the outcome is meant to be inevitable.  For a game that seems to rely on a morality system and a medal system on missions, this is very frustrating for players who want to lean towards a particular side of the moral compass or get gold on missions.

Also, the missions!  You are awarded gold, silver, or bronze medals upon completion of a mission, depending on how well you performed based on a checklist of standards (finish within 2 minutes, get 12 headshots, etc.).  However, they don't show the checklist to the player until AFTER the mission is done!  Almost every other game featuring a "completion award system" that I've played always has a checklist given before or during the mission, never after.  It's incredibly frustrating for players who want to achieve perfection to play a mission, only to see that they got a silver or a bronze because they missed one requirement for gold that they didn't even know about until after they completed the mission.  Who actually thought that was a good idea?  It doesn't promote replayability, it promotes frustration and discouragement.

3. Saving the game.  You can only save between missions and can never save mid-mission.  This seems like it was a terrible design flaw where the game can't pinpoint your exact location on a map and doesn't bother with saving your progress within a mission.  Even when I'm able to manually save the game (which is when I'm not in the middle of a mission), loading that save takes me to a point on the map that's in the general vicinity of where I had saved the game.  This is very frustrating for someone who may have a play style that prefers not to commit to a full mission in one sitting.

With all this said, I decided I still was going to play this game and overlook these issues.  It's still playable, and I'm actually enjoying myself when it comes to traveling and completing missions.  The story is engaging, the acting is great, the graphics are great, and I'm ultimately living out a cowboy fantasy.  There are highly realistic aspects of the game to help simulate life in the Wild West, such as when it comes to spending money, having bounties on your character, and facing consequences with every little action.

However, this game is not nearly perfect because of the issues I listed above; they greatly diminish the playing experience and make what could have been a great game into a poorly-designed mess.

author: Patricia

author: Daniel Jessen
title: Great game, gameplay kind of sucks though
content: This game excels in a lot of areas: music, voice acting, graphics, detail, and story.  But where it seriously lacks is one of the most imortant things: gameplay.  If youve ever played grand theft auto, just imagine that but set in the 19th century.  It really took some getting used to, like probably 10+ hours of playing, what kept me playing was the story.  The story is emotional and captivating, and it just keeps you sucked in, no matter how hard arthur is to control.  If it werent for the story, I would have sold the game thr same day I bought it.  The story takes a bit to pick up, but it gets really good.  If this were a tv show, I would watch the crap out of it.  Overall, great game, I just wish they would have done a bit better with the controls.

The sequel is a big letdown after the great game story and options. I only bothered because of some bad guys who weren't killed in main story...
