author: Emjay
title: I played the original RDR for years
content:
Let me preface this review by saying, if you get games for the storyline only, this story is smart, but you're going to find that a lot of the time you're holding X to get to where you're going, and listening to a hoard of dialog.  As others have said, great game to look at - most times - but really slow and boring.

But I want to review this game from a different angle.

The release of RDR2 was much anticipated for many of my friends and people we knew in clans (in the original RDR).  So I want to do a bit of a comparison review.

What made the original RDR great in my opinion wasn't the storyline, but multiplayer.  Many people got addicted to shootouts, bag matches, stronghold, coop, etc.  That was the driving force of RDR.  That's evidenced by all the clans that were created.  People wanting to be the most recognized, the best player, and climb the leaderboards.

By comparison, RDR2 did not incorporate clans in any form.  They have free roam posse's with a max of 4 or 7 people.  That's basically so friends have a place to setup camp or so small groups can do things together.  RDR2 also has a honor system, so if you're going to wreak havoc, then you will lose honor.  At this point (12-12-18) the honor system doesn't really mean much.  Some have said it will matter eventually.  Point being, RDR2 is not conducive to clans or even going around and killing people.

They have these competitive series, which is apparently the equivalent of the original game where you could do multiplayer shootouts and such.  In this version you typically use throwing knives or bow/arrow and creep through the woods, and the reaction time of using those weapons is slow.  In other matches, you get more weapons, but again, the accuracy is not great, the speed is slow, methodical, and there's a lot of inaccuracies.  For example, when I use a varmint rifle in free roam, the range is not far, I can barely kill some birds, yet in multiplayer, I'm constantly getting killed by varmint rifles.  When I use a Lancaster, the accuracy isn't as good, so if I take 2-4 shots to kill a guy, he'll turn and shoot me with his varmint.  So I should use and trust the varmint, but it's basically a BB gun and mostly used for --- killing varmint's.  The fact that it's the weapon of choice in multiplayer is an utter joke.

The game really feels a lot more like GTA V than it does RDR, and that's a huge mistake.  Friends who loved the original RDR seem to hate RDR2, because Rockstar has overhauled what made RDR great.  A lot of my clan buddies are calling RDR2 boring and I've seen others playing other games now, and RDR2 is still in its Beta stage.

Essentially, Rockstar has turned RDR2 into a hunting, fishing, and e-commerce game.  You need to earn XP to level up, you have to earn cash to buy weapons, and they're encouraging you to use real money to buy gold so that you can buy virtual stuff in their game, or to get your guns gold.  It's not like the old game where you earn your keep.  Now you buy your keep.

Gone is stronghold, the traditional coop, bag matches, but also gone is prestige and earning mounts (remember the buffalo and zebra?).

I'm telling you, after you get past the graphics and earning a few weapons and better ammo, the euphoria of this game - if there ever was any - wears off.  Last night after doing a mission with my friend we were like, now what.  My friend said he was bored and he's just gonna go.  In the old days, we'd be going to casual games, shootouts, bag matches, something.  Now it's just whatever.

One other thing that makes this game boring is you have to ride everywhere.  And you have to pay to fast travel, so that's discouraged.  Plus, as you're hunting to earn cash, you have to continually watch your character skin every animal.  In the old game you could at least speed it up by standing your horse over the carcass... not anymore.

While people think the map is huge, they have removed the whole southern hemisphere, so there is no El Presidio, Nosalida or any of that.

If you enjoy doing stranger missions, hunting, fishing, and playing multiplayer games in the forest that have the functionality of GTA V, then you may really like this, but my RDR friends are not liking this new version.

The updates Rockstar has provided are for ecommerce and bugs; they're not helping gameplay.  I seriously doubt gameplay is going to improve.  I don't know how it can.  I am doubtful that there's going to be stronghold incorporated and if it is, it'll be so different than the last game that the stronghold loyalists won't care.  It's really disappointing.  It's as if GTA V is rockstar's baby and they decided to make RDR2 a spinoff of that instead of making it more like the original.

BIG NEGATIVE.  If you have been hunting a couple hours, you wander off to pickup some pelts, kill a couple more things, wander a little further, then realize, oh, my horse is out of sight, whistle and when your horse catches up, all your stuff will be gone... you let your horse get too far away and all that work is for not.  Further, if you die, or are killed, the pelts, carcasses, and other things on your horse will either be gone or maybe stolen.

PERSISTENT CAMP NEGATIVES:

1) When you save up to create a persistent camp and choose a location for it, you'll be lucky if your camp is ever in that same location again.  Yet it costs money to move your camp.

2) They hold a max of 7 people, so again, not conducive to clans.

3) If you think you're safe because your white flag is raised, I still got hogtied and dragged away.  All the stuff on my horse was knocked off.  I wonder if I hadn't come back to my game and seen myself being dragged away if I wouldn't have lost everything on my horse.

BIG NEGATIVE:  There are no privates sessions, no private free roam, no private games, and really not much like the old game at all.

BIG NEGATIVE:  While playing, if you get a phone call or have to take a crap, you better be at your camp and open up the box where ammo you purchase goes to, because otherwise it'll time out.  I've tried a rubber band on my controller, but twice my horse has ran into a building and stopped moving its feet and I timed out.  You can't even just sit at your camp.  You'll get a message that you have 13 minutes until the game times out.

NEGATIVE:  There are only a few butchers on the whole map so relating to the issue above, you're going to a butcher across the map, get a phone call, your game becomes inactive, you're booted.

I now hope when the game boots up that my camp will be somewhat close to a butcher and I won't go to a butcher when other people are in the game b/c they'll kill you and take your stuff.  You'll still have things in your satchel, feathers and stuff, but the bigger stuff will be gone.  So I stay active, use my camp as a safety haven, and I go to the butcher when nobody's around.  then go back to my camp, and I hunt and gather close to my camp.

Along with no private free roams, there's no "friendly" ones either.

Rockstar went the extra yard to be as realistic as they can.  IMO, they spent far too much time on that, when they should have focused more on what made RDR great.  RDR remained popular for years because of multiplayer games.  Everyone who was anyone wanted to get 50 kills in shootouts.  Now nobody cares.  Rockstar didn't ask the RDR community what they wanted in a sequel, and now I think they're going to lose a huge chunk of their audience.

Last thing I'll say is about the graphics.  I think anymore these days, everyone expects great graphics, so that really shouldn't be a selling point for RDR2.  The game looks great, but they didn't exceed my expectations.  If anything, the game was pumped up so much and I saw so much in previews and videos that I was disappointed by what I played.  Nothing really knocked my socks off.  I've seen just as good or better graphics in far cry, event horizon and other games.  And the game play (and getting around) in event horizon is far superior to RDR2.  There should be more to a Game of the Year nominee than graphics and storymode.  Because honestly, the storymode aspect of a game is only eye candy.  People loved multiplayer in RDR.  That should be the selling point for RDR2, but it's definitely not.  For that reason, I don't think people will be as into RDR2 as they were RDR, at least for not as long.  RDR would still be somewhat popular if the game weren't hacked.  A lot of people I've spoken with now wish that RDR were remastered.  All the GTA lovers can have RDR2, we just want to get back to the game we loved.  Unfortunately it's gone.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Easy transaction
content: The game was perfect arrived as promised

author: Tim
title: wait for a sale TBH....
content: This game is good, but not the best. From someone who has never played the first game, it is definitely not as fun as Grand Theft Auto or even Bully. The open world is not very engaging, but given that it is largely comprised of wildlife, idk what I expected honestly. Gameplay seems good for the most part, but the on-foot controls definitely could've used some tuning. Given that it is a Rockstar game you should expect the standard travel from A to B type missions, but the characters and story make them worthwhile. If you're into that Wild West setting and a long, interactive movie, then by all means give this game a chance.  It's definitely not the worst thing in the world as some other reviews might suggest, but I would wait for the game to go on sale before purchasing.

author: Shalom Norton
title: BEST GAME THUS FAR!!! NO 🧢
content: Anyone that gives this game anything less than 5stars is looking for attention or trying to get someone to not buy the game for some sick twisted reason. The game is two disc because of all the lovely content and details it has so you’ll need about an hour to download all disc data to your console before playing. The game starts off in the snowy mountains and flows through missions of the first chapter without allowing you to roam free so be patient however you’ll arrive New hanover area where you can interact with your camp and do so many things besides missions. The game has taken realism to a whole another level, if you’ve just shaved your beard clean forget about putting it back like your typical video game but it will grow back in time. You also can buy horses and name them and groom them etc. Hunting is another level compared to GTA V, you can hunt any animal you see , skin it and put it on your hourse to sell or cook etc. There are bar brawls, bounty hunting, dominoes , barbershop visits...oh and did I mention you can gain weight like CJ in GTA san andreas. I’m still playing this game but this is definitely a must have game. After playing GTA V numerous times i must say that I’m enjoying RDR2 and my wife agrees too. The details are just amazing and too numerous to mention. You can interact with others around and have meaningful conversation outside of random lines of conversation in previous GTA games. There is a mission where all you literally do is get drunk and there is also being able to loot and search someone’s pockets after killing them. Rockstar did a TREMENDOUS JOB! I won’t be playing any other game for awhile and that’s including NBA 2k19! I’m gonna go back to play now....so all I’ll say is “HURRY UP AND BUY”!!!! 🤑💪🏽 (PSN : jrnorton8)

author: Jack Dashing
title: Needs More polish and refinements
content: it's annoying holding down Square to grab items. in the very first cabin in the game when you're instructed to loot supplies, if you go up the ladder there are 2 items on the table that have a shimmer (notifying you that you can loot them). i literally had to spend 3 minutes trying to loot those two items, positioning myself in so many ways, including crouching, etc. before the game finally decided i was in the exact right spot/angle to loot them. SO annoying. and the whole weight management system is unnecessary filler and an annoyance; not fun.

author: Thieri
title: Awesome...If you like following people on horses and listening to them gossip
content:
This is the most mundane game ever made. Hours of trailing people on horses listening to them yap about god-knows-what, and in the moments in-between, scintillating activities like: eating food, sleeping, sharing food, trying to mount your horse, walking around like you're waist-deep in molasses, and sleeping some more.

If this game were set in modern times, a mission might go something like this: press triangle to get in your car. Follow Frank to the grocery store. Listen to Frank gossip about Loretta and John. Press triangle to remove food from the shelf. Press square to add food to grocery cart. Decide whether Frank is lying about Loretta. Press square to move can over self-checkout scanner. Press triangle to bag. Press square to take receipt. Press triangle to get in your car. Follow Frank back to apartment. Listen to Frank gossip about John's brother, Jimmy. Press square to sleep.

This game is shockingly dull and inexplicably obsessed with minutiae. My copy is already listed on eBay.

author: Ross
title: Boring Horse Riding Simulator
content: So much uneventful horse riding. Sure, there's cinematic mode, but you still have to hold/tap X to keep your horse going. And the majority of the game is just that. It's bad when I enter a party chat while riding my horse and my friend goes "playing Red Dead? I can hear you tapping x constantly." Fast travel is possible, but still requires you to get to the fast travel points, rather than just opening your map and choosing a destination. The random encounters start to repeat themselves over and over again, so those get boring pretty fast. Most action from random hostiles was in the Murfree Brood section, but dead eye ends those interactions within seconds. The map is beautiful. Lots of animals to kill, but that just becomes a grind after awhile when going for perfect pelts or looking for little birds. The random stranger encounters repeat themselves rather quickly, so not a lot of variety there. Side quests aren't bad and provide some interesting little stories. Some become a grind though when it involves collecting certain things. Only reason this game gets 3 stars is because the story is alright, I enjoyed some of the side quests, and it's a beautiful map with great graphics. Gameplay though is lacking a ton, with no hope of improvement or future content, since they will only focus on their online mode and selling in game currency for a ridiculous amount of $.

author: DE Burke
title: Close to a horse simulation riding game.
content:
The game is a linear story set in an open world, that follows the demise of a gang of outlaws at the turn of the century.
If you spend 50 hours in this game, you will spend 39 hours of it riding a horse from place to place. 1 hour spent shooting. The final 10 hours on cut scenes. It's slow paced. The art work and design of things is beautiful. The world this game inhabits is incredible for it's detail. The game play (shooting, and walking around) is "ok". Other games have better shooting and movement. The avatar you play in this game is quite stiff and walks slowly.
In direct contrast to games with a faster pace (Far Cry 5, Witcher 3, almost any other game) this is a very slow game. And as far as "fun" factor, this slowness makes the game much less fun than other games currently available.
I finished the game and enjoyed the story. But won't replay this one. There were some very fun missions in the game. Train robberies, bank robberies and so on. But it takes a long time to get to them.
Not a bad game. Just not as much fun as you might be hoping for. Since I have limited time, spending so much of this game getting to the "good stuff" was a detraction.

author: Arlene Clark
title: GTA 6 “1899” but loads faster & better. 🎨🎮
content:
Finally a game with a great story, wonderful dialogue, and smooth controls, Rockstar knows what the fans want, and they hit that nail on the head.

((((((((SPOILERS)))))))))))
(((((((((AHEAD))))))))))))))

  Things to do... (thus far) this is the most impressively built game I’ve ever played. The voice acting vocals and music are 💯💯 Well we’re do I begin, you start running away from the police because, as it seems an unknown crime that you, and crew committed, were running to safety, before the game started. Then you notice you’re walking around in 10-12 inches of snow and realize this is the most advanced snow physics up to date, then you jump on your horse for the first time east enough right? No, now it’s gonna tell you that you have to take care of the horse, heal it, feed it, try your best to not kill it. A few missions in i was hooked, actually thought about calling into work, because it impressed me so
Much, you can kill, rob peoples and stores, kidnap, hold people for ransom, fight against the members of the KKK, (Oh Sweet Justice).
  Then you have your guns, gun graphics, addons, special ammo, and dynamite just  Incase you get into a sticky fight,
  One of its greatest feats would be the addition of health, energy and dead eye, also same for your horse.
  The first things I did when I finally downloaded the 92gb ffs on my pro is explore, and IT IS MASSIVE. Always someone asking for help or trying to set you up, I found myself just galloping around for hours and checking out the layout before I hit the SALON: Of course you could just get drunk😪 or you can play a multitude of different types of games, Texas Holdem poker, the “try to cut your fingers off game” blackjack, and so much more. And as always you can take everyone’s Poker chips then kill them all or do it your way.
  That would be my review or this amazingly gorgeous game, can be slow, but I’m this fast paced world how much are we missing because we want “faster”? This is a game that you can play how you wanna play, “KILLEM ALL” or be a gentle cowboy that’s doing his best to survive and keep surving.
  I absolutely cannot wait for the online and single player add ons, Rock ⭐️ Is a fantastic company that doesn’t bicker with other companies, they put what they got on the table and keep doin better and Better. I’m so glad there is finally a company that puts out quality work, not slapping out (re-skinned) games evey year ..... COD🤬🤬🤮
  I’ve honestly played >10 hours and still have yet to find all there is to find, if anything changes I’ll be back to change my review but I’m gonna give this Goregeous game a 10.1/10, simply for the detail alone. Every tree sways in the wind, dynamic movements, great way to spend time on the poker tables, or helping strangers, robbing stage coaches/ trains, and just creating general mayhem if that’s your choice. P.S. You’re choices on the decisions you make will change the game drastically, E.G. rob a salon, next time you go
I’m they instant tell you not to cause anymore trouble and are on more alert.
  Give it a shot, it’s game of the decade at least, and I would put it above gta 5, sorry:/. Hope you all enjoyed, thanks! PS4: DefinitionOfHam

author: Mgopher
title: do not waste 60 dollars on this broken turkey, anything else would be better
content:
Well today highlighted that rockstar/taketwo are bait and deny liars. promised update is a drip feed over a six month time span during which you waste your time on an ever decreasing payout schedule.

Well it has been over a month and my original review was not harsh enough. The game has had no updates and the server problems, griefing, and overall game play is impossible to tolerate for more than the twenty minutes a week I start it to see if it has become worse. It has,

Lets see. Beta must mean, beta for at least three more months according to rockstar tweets. constant disconnects due to rockstar server error. constant griefing, no passive. constant glitches, same error seven different times no reply. Gold bars purchased for items only available through actual real money purchases. Graphics are stunning but a real waste of effort when you get dropped by rockstar server errors every 10 minutes. No enjoyable content. Terrible control setup. No communication from rockstar. Economy is broken, 600 in game dollars or 32 gold bars, actually 32.50 in real money for a gun. 120 real dollars for cosmetic upgrades for a rifle, only purchasable with their gold bars.? Definitely a cash grab for a broken, and seemingly non fixable piece of boring software. If you must available on ebay for 25 dollars sold by people who spent 100 dollars for and gave up on this poc.

author: Bruce Gilbert
title: Biggest disappointment since Atari's E.T.
content:
Easily the most frustrating game I have ever played.  Sloppy controls, frequent server crashes, the tutorial tells you how to play only AFTER you've gotten stuck in a nasty situation, and unless you're playing in a group (online), you will accomplish absolutely nothing.  Here's a list of other problems I encountered, while online:

-Eagle Eye will not always expose every danger in your field of view, thus putting you in dangerous situations despite the caution you've taken.

-The game's economy is severely imbalanced.  "Want your guns upgraded?  Cool...that'll be three hundred dollars.  You have pelts to sell?  Cool...I'll give you three dollars."

-Your position on the map will always be marked for other players, making it impossible for you to hide or escape when you're hopelessly outnumbered.

-Other players can easily take over a town, shoot you dead when they see you coming to visit a store, and suffer no consequence.  Knock an old lady over by mistake, however, and the law is on you.  Either way, this makes it impossible to profit from business with NPC's.

-Animals and NPC's will suddenly appear in front of you, when you're riding at a high speed.  This will result in your horse tossing you off, and trampling you to your death.

-If you get killed...regardless of how...any horse cargo you've acquired will be lost.

I tried the Story mode, and I just can't get into it.  I'm so frustrated with everything else that I just don't care, and it's not the game is trying to win me over, because there are other games out there, with more exciting tasks than 'pick up that cup', 'walk into the barber shop', 'talk to that guy', etc.

I put maybe five hours into it before deleting it off of my PS4.  One can easily read my comments and assume that I hated this game, but it's hard to admit to that, especially after the profound love I had for the original Red Dead Redemption.  I REALLY wanted to love this game, and I'm angered over the fact that I cannot.

PS I changed my rating to one star.  To be fair, it deserves no more than two-and-a-half, but the overall rating for this game is incredibly skewed by mindless bias, and players who aren't being compensated by Rockstar Games should be compelled to offset it, with the publishing of one-star ratings.

UPDATE 2/15/19: I gave the game another shot, and every time I think I can find a way to enjoy it, I'm punished.  I just shot down a highway robber that killed a couple on a stagecoach, and witnesses reported me to the authorities.  Even when you try to do 'the right thing', the game punishes you.

I had to have edited this review a half a dozen times...I hated the game THAT MUCH.

Enough is enough...I sold this overrated piece of garbage to Gamestop.

I've been playing video games for 37 years...this is the first game I ever sold.

author: Romina

author: J. Carr
title: The world is visually appealing, but the game itself isn't fun
content:
I'm finding myself bored to tears with it after 17 hours.  There are tons of things to do from various missions given to you by people you meet, but so far they've all been boring so I'm not inclined to take on many activities outside the main story line.

As others have said, the constant horseback riding is tedious.  Even train, stagecoach, and the very limited camp fast travel are tedious.  Do we really need unskippable cut scenes to travel in ways other than horseback?  Just put us at our destination so we can continue with the game at a faster pace.  The cinematic camera mode + X while horseback riding is convenient, but we still have to sit there staring at it until the horse gets to the destination, hope the horse doesn't run into any bandits, and stop  when it start bucking because it needs to be calmed and fed.  Travel is my biggest complaint in the game.  All means of travel are frustrating in their own way.

As far as the controls, you can accidentally punch someone while trying to mount your horse and get a warrant. You have to be extremely careful when to press which buttons on the controller.  I recommend manual saving often because of issues like this so you can reload your game and try again.  I reload probably 3 or 4 times an hour because of this.

Constantly having to replenish your health/stamina cores and that of your horse makes the pace even slower.  I don't care if you have to eat and sleep in real life.  This isn't real life.  I also have to take a dump IRL and I'm glad they at least left that out.

Overall I'm not sure if I'll be finishing the game.  I'll give it a few more hours and if no change in enjoyment it'll be time to sell.  This feels like a case of the developers trying too hard.  Too bad they tried too hard in some areas no one cares about. Too much pointless filler and fluff. I'm baffled by all the perfect scores it received.  Maybe if you're someone who enjoys spending lots of time doing menial chores at a snail's pace this will be a 10/10.

author: Honest Critic
title: BORING. TEDIOUS. ClUNKY. SLOW. AVOID.
content:
The good. GRAPHICS? Seems like now days thats what makes a good game.
Rockstar is great at adding the realism to their games. But thats their downfall. Its so real its boring. And ironically, the only thing not real is how the cops magically find you in the middle of nowhere. They are relentlessly unrelastic. Go figure? If you defend yourself againts a person you verbally antagonize, that starts to shoot you, the cops Are after you! If you do crimes with a mask on, they still know its you! And Arthur walks like he has butt herpeez. Its like they purposely slow you down to a crawl walk so you can immerse in every piece of scenery. Let me run if I want to dammit! You do chores. Yes. Chores, that will take you about 15 mins to do. I do chores in real life and I despise them. Why would add that to my game? And speaking of game, this is not a game. Its a simulator. ITS THE SIMS., with guns and horsies. Everything is clunky about that game, to riding the horse, shoot outs and fighting. The story is ok, I guess, because this game is a prequel, so we all know what technically happens. If you enjoy playing this snooze fest, you are an idiot with ADHD. I want my money back for this sleeping pill of a game. I am forcing myself to complete the story just so I wont feel like I totallt wasted my money. ROCKSTAR CAN KISS MY POOP SHOOTER. I will never buy another GTA based game again. Goodbye forever

author: William
title: A masterpiece for graphics. That's about it.
content:
I wanted this to be a five star game. I really did. I've been waiting 8 years for another Red Dead, because Red Dead Redemption 1 is one of my favorite games... though, sadly, this is not one. The review that follows contains spoilers. They are criticisms I noted during my time playing this game.

 Hypersensitive trigger happy lawmen. One crime observed = 1 second for a hornets nest of 20 lawmen to appear. And it's not fun.

Civilization with a 6th sense for crime

The epilogue felt more like the beginning of the game than Chapter 1; and it felt like the beginning of a better game than the the main storyline.

300 different weapons? Really? Where exactly are they? Each store sells basically the same ones. Same foods and provisions. Same items to steal. The variety is LACKING.

Nudity is infrequent.

Having a hunting dog as a companion would have been nice. Having anyone or anything as a companion would have been fun too

The hunting the was the best part of the gameplay, which isn't something I'm all that thrilled about (RDR1 ate a wildlife hunting game and Little House on the Prairie.)

Another pretty game that has sacrificed gameplay to graphics. Think Assassins Creed.

Do you enjoy riding on horseback for hours taking to NPCs?

The excitement of helping to build a house: hit X at the right time... ZZZZZ

Lost the quirkiness of the original (the grave digger, the snake oil salesman.) Any razy surprises in the little books and crannies? Nope.

If you're looking for something, no worries. You don't have to look hard. The map highlights it for you. Eagle eye also highlights everything you can take... which doesn't require much guessing, considering most things you can take are tonic bottles.

Like to choose your weapons? Not for many scenes. You're thrown into battle with a repeater...

Enjoy going straight into battle? Not before you follow instructions such as "get into cover." Then move with Sadie, then "kill the sniper."

The snipers scope moves at a snails pace when you are moving it while looking through it.

I got to go on a hot air balloon ride. One ride. Never to be repeated.

The clothes are boring. Nothing scandalous or outrageous.

Out of the hundreds of doors in this game, you're lucky to find a few that you can pass through. Especially in the cities, and entering a cottages is few and far between.

Fully upgraded satchel does not allow you to carry a great number of pocket watches... So frequent trips to the fence are still required in order to make more moneys

Mor wilderness than things to do in it, especially after the Blackwater region opens.

In conclusion: I still love the game, even with all it's shortcomings. But Fall Out 4 and Skyrim are still the best game ever made. If they had RD2's graphics, they would be unbeatable.

author: Cubster59
title: For mature adults to enjoy
content: An engaging game full of detail for "grown ups". This is not a run and gun game. What it is is a well thought out game with plenty of details to keep you engaged. The graphics are beautiful, the music sets the tone. At times it feels as if you are playing a movie. I can tell most of the negative reviews are from kids (and some impatient adults)who expected a fast pace wild west game. That is definitely not this game. It is an unfortunate sign if the times, quick and easy gratification in this too fast world we now live in..But, If you enjoy leisure pace, beautiful scenery, almost limitless environment interaction and a ton of things to do, this is a 5 star game you will certainly enjoy.

author: Quoad Toad
title: I hated the first 15 hours of this game, but then came to love it
content:
It took a long time for me to start enjoying this game.  Part of it is that the game opens in a blizzard and I simply hated that environment.  I was going to give up on the game at that point, but decided to keep playing, despite the very harsh opening, in the hopes that it would improve.  I also needed to get to know the characters.  I was annoyed by them until I got to know them.  I was also very irritated at the controls for the first few hours and the lack of fast travel.  I kept playing because I grew up riding horses and I loved how real the horses were in this game.

I slowly got to know the characters and began to enjoy the environments (outside of the snowy region).  I loved discovering new towns and the various characters I encountered.  I liked a few of my fellow gang members.  I liked Arthur.  I found myself feeling sorry for him when I would make him do something really stupid just to see what would happen.

This game can be frustrating because you know that some of the actions in the main story line are going to only make things worse.  Arthur knows that are going to make things worse, but goes along with it.  It's a weird game dynamic.  In most games, you are trying to make things better.  In this way, the game plays more like a movie than a game.  Characters have depth and make imperfect decisions.  In a way, I felt trapped by the main missions.  I didn't want to put Arthur in danger and I wanted him to make different decisions.

The main missions contrast with the rest of the world.  In the open world, you can make decisions and treat people well or poorly.  You can observe wild animals and just enjoy seeing them or you can hunt them.  You can help various strangers or ignore them.  While the main missions are linear, you can explore the world at your leisure.

There are tons of Easter eggs to discover and I spent hours searching for many of them.  At first, I was annoyed a the limited fast travel options, but I came to enjoy riding around the environment and studying new animals and plants, while encountering strangers.

There are a few parts of this game that really annoyed me.  I am a woman and I didn't want to grow a beard, so I spent many hours returning to camp or going to barbers to shave.  I also disliked bathing, but if you stop bathing, people comment that you smell awful.  Eating was the other thing that annoyed me, but I eventually just stopped eating and dealt with having low health.  There are just too few food options in this game.  I don't enjoy stew or big game meat in real life and I don't want to "eat" those things in the game either.

I recommend this game.  It requires a big time commitment though.  It took me 100+ hours to finish this game over the course of several months.  I would definitely play it again once I start to forget the story more.  I usually trade games in after finishing them, but this one is a keeper.

author: O. Al Hammadi
title: I would buy it again
content:
The game starts slow, but once it puts everything into gears it goes ahead in style, it introduced gameplay and side quests that can be found in the open world in a beautiful tutorial which then lets you go ahead by yourself. After maybe two hours playing you will get the hang of all the games available in the open world, from character side missions, to hunting legendary animals, to small poker games, dominos andf inger fillet.

The game will has so many things to be done, explored and played. As other games where you will have to find your way through boring areas till you get to the next main mission or side mission in the world, in RDR2 you will find you self stolen by other side quests and the normal path that sounds tedious and boring turns out to be filled with events, side quests and other small activities scattered in this world that seems more alive than even a real world itself.

I never did experience a dull moment in RDR2, i was always engaged even in areas where i though i am safe to do my borning stuff like camping, i saw myself raided by a bandit in the world and threatened to move to another area or face the consquences of not adhering to their warning.

The story is also one of the strong areas of the game, I do not wanna go into any details of the story but Rockstar has really came up with a beautiful story for RDR2 and it really showed the climax in the ending of the game. The story should not be missed, and I can safely say that it has nothing repetitive in the story in terms of gameplay, I found myself in areas where i though a gun fire will insue as usual just to be surprised by the events that has unfold and I was left to come up with a different approach than what I had planned, and obviosuly stacked and cleaned my weapons for.

Finally I would highlight the graphics and textures in the game, the game contains a vast areas filled with animals, birds, crawling animals, and vegetation, I found myself wondering how could the PS4 handle such a load of details in the game without crashing. This shows how much effory Rockstar put in optimizing the game for the console. I think this kind of details would likely require a high end pc to run. This if it says anything, it indicate the beautiful world that was created and the amazing game RDR2 is.

I highly recommend this game for everyone with a console. I loved it so much that I am willing to buy it again on PC if it was released (I wanna play it again in FPS using mouse and keyboard).

author: Proto-Ant
title: Incredible Game!
content: All hype aside, this game is worth every penny. The amount of content here is staggering, and it's all weaved together masterfully. It's rare you get a game that has stunning graphics, a cohesive in-depth story, memorable characters, slick combat, and an open world full of content you actually care to explore. RDR II checks every single box and coincidentally sets a standard for the rest of the video game industry.

author: matt
title: What an incredible game
content: Simply put - the most beautiful and alive open world I've ever seen. Expect to get lost for hours just riding around taking in the scenery and interacting with NPCs. I put nearly 16 hours in over the first two days and it didn't feel like enough, there is just so much to do. I think it will go down as one of the best games of this generation. Ignore the 0-3 star reviews. Most likely reviews made by kids who never even played the game and are just mad that it's getting attention over Fortnite.

author: Brandon
title: 8 year development well worth it from Rockstar.
content: I first bought this game on day 1 so I knew I had to buy it for my older sister eventually and sure enough she told me she fell in love with it. The realism and details in Red dead redemption 2 are truly next gen, it actually feels like most characters feel alive and genuine, especially with the voice acting. People often complain about clunky controls but honestly I loved the controls, never felt stiff or clunky. Another complaint from people is the overall story progression being slow, however for me I was completely hooked from the middle to the end, it just kept getting better and better. I 100% recommend this to anyone looking for a truly phenomenal game.

author: Molly Hodgdon
title: I love this game.
content:
First of all, why do people review games after only playing for a few hours? Ridiculous.

Second, people are complaining that it takes "forever" to travel because you have to ride horses everywhere. This is just untrue. There are not one, not two, but THREE fast travel options. A map that you can unlock pretty early on, stagecoaches, and trains. But having said that I personally recommend that you ride whenever possible or you will miss a lot of chance-encounter missions, gorgeous environment, and tons of easter eggs.

For me the action and fighting was fine, nothing mind-blowing, it was the beauty and storytelling that make this game special. There are no crazy weapons or insane combos, it's not God of War, but I've never felt so invested in the characters and story of a video game before. The plot itself was fairly straightforward but the voice acting was great and unlike most video game stories you actually see the characters evolve and change from beginning to end. I don't know what else I can compare it to except maybe Last of Us - but honestly I found Last of Us kind of boring, for me this was meatier and there are a bunch of side missions that all have their own multi-part arcs.

I've finished RDR2 now and have moved on to another game, but I think when I'm finished with it I'm going to go back and play RDR2 again. Maybe try being "bad" this time. I don't know, either way I miss the richness of that world and I'm looking forward to giving it another play through.

author: JD
title: An insult to the original.
content:
The first game has its visual flaws but gameplay was brisk, free, & engaging. Sadly very little of that experience is apparent in RDR2.
For a mere cowboy, be prepared to navigate thru a ridiculous amount of controls for very little gain. They're unnecessarily complicated with few quick switching options. Having to press 2 buttons to reach the map proved to be a pain and worse yet the weapons wheel did whatever it wants especially when on horseback. Good luck to you if you're in dire circumstances n in need of the weapon of your choice.
Not going on & on here but it must be sed this game is boring and a shadow of its predecessor. Seriously if you loved RDR just keep it and skip this game. You'll only come away upset & out $60.
Final grade: D- .

author: C. Roemer
title: Fun, but if depends on your style of gaming
content:
Let me start by stating that I am not done with the game yet, and I'm glad not to be.
I'm a little shocked by the negative reviews, but I understand some of the comments.  The game is gorgeous, especially the environments and scenery.  The map is very large and can take a while to navigate, but there are options.  The animations of the characters seem a little unsophisticated at this point in gaming graphics.
I haven't played GTA in a long time, and I only recently (in the last year) played Red Dead Redemption.  I feel like the characters and horses behave and look very similar to RDR, but up close there are enhancements.  I felt like getting around in RDR, once the game really opened up, was much worse than RDR2.  I honestly am not even sure where I'm at in the main story line.  I happily get distracted taking off for hours at a time hunting, looking for legendary animals/fish, and just poking around.  I don't get to game very often, or for long stretches at a time, so I do enjoy the distractions.  If you are looking to play this game just for the story, then you may not like it.  The gun fights are not terribly hard, but I never felt the combat was the focus in RDR either.
When you do activate a character task or main story line, you do end up riding somewhere next to other NPCs and talking to them.  Just don't mainline the tasks and that won't be a big deal.
Yes the map is large and it may take a long time to get around, but the idea here is an open world environment for a cowboy, what did you expect.  You can fast travel after you upgrade Arthur's campsite, you can ride the train (either legally or illegally), you can ride a coach or you can ride your horse.  In my opinion it is very authentic.
You have to feed yourself or you get too thin, which can impact your stats.  You need to feed and brush your horse, and overall bond with your horse.  Neither of these activities seem to impact the game too much, at least not that I've found, but they do add another level of authenticity to the cowboy experience.
There are tasks and activities to do everywhere.  That to me has been a little overwhelming, but I haven't really focused on anything in particular.  The landscaping is so realistic that I've probably missed many of the objects NPCs have asked me to find (example: dinosaur bones, dream catchers, stone sculptures).  I've only really focused on fishing for the legendary fish.

Cons for me are limited to character movement.  Arthur tires out if you try to run too much.  Doing tasks for the camp are tedious (moving bags, chopping wood, feeding horses).  Yes your horse will tire when running, but take a trip up to the snowy mountains and find a white arabian horse that is on it's own, and you will have a good fast horse.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes to play an experience without wanting to mainline a story.  Maybe I will have a different opinion when I finish, after experiencing more repetition, but I'm having fun so far.  No multiplayer just yet.

author: E. Allan
title: Mixed Feelings - Like, but Don't Love
content:
I like it. I don't love it. Reasons below.

Like:
I like the graphics. I like the immersion and the voice acting. I like how much effort went into creating this game. It is very detailed. It is very immense. It is beautiful. The writing is superb. Every NPC seems to have a story. Every interaction has weight behind it.  It feels like what you do makes a difference to the other people in the game. Once you get to the first town, you can do whatever you want. You can sit and play dominos with an NPC. You can choose from a myriad of quests which turn out to be very narrowly guided interactive stories where you usually end up shooting bad guys.

Dislike: It feels slow. The walking is literally like being overburdened in a Bethesda game, but that's the regular speed of movement.  I understand they do this to help with immersion and to make a player feel invested in the actions occurring in the game, and to make people pay attention to the atmosphere, but it isn't easy to play this way after using characters in other PS4 titles that move so much quicker and easier.

The complexity. I'm a casual gamer, so my view on the complexity is simply that I don't want to invest so much time in learning all of the controls. There are a massive of button combinations and things to remember. When I go on a mission or a quest, I want to feel successful. I often fail the first time, second time, and third time. That makes this game feel like a slog, rather than an enjoyable relaxing adventure I can enjoy during my preciously meager free time.

At this point, I want to go back to playing God of War or Horizon Zero Dawn simply because I felt elation and fun while playing those games. I am really trying to give RD2 my full attention, but I'm not sure it can capture my attention long term. I just don't have the time to walk around slowly and to fail quests multiple times.

author: Tushar
title: The Greatest Game Ever Made (but not for the Impatient)
content:
You must have read a lot of other reviews branding the game as slow and boring. It's because people lack patience nowadays.

The amount of detail which has gone into each and every single aspect of this game truly makes me wonder whether the developers working on this game are superhumans! They must have spent a lot of sleepless nights on this game.

I wasn't a huge fan of RDR1, mainly because the game was limited by the hardware of the last generation of consoles. RDR2 has no such issues. Unlike the GTA series which is usually satirical, RDR2 is an earnest attempt at recreating the world of late 19th century. The story is one of the greatest ever. It could be made into a TV series and would easily trash WestWorld and rival GOT. I haven't met a better bunch of characters since at least MassEffect 2. The gun combat isn't fluid because the weapons of that era weren't great, and the game accurately portrays that.

To give you an example of how detailed the game is, the weapons in the game rust if you don't maintain them and the rust mechanism reflects the real world (I'm a Materials Engineer). If you follow a random NPC in the game for a day, you'll see that they actually live their own lives in the game and aren't just placed there randomly to fill the world.

RDR2 will easily win game of the year, beating God of War (which was the leading contender till now IMO). A game of this caliber comes only once or twice a decade. My advice to you, give the game an honest shot. It's slow to build, but will not let you down.

Every developer at Rockstar Games should be proud of himself/herself.

author: P Myers
title: How do 1 star reviews exist for this game?
content: I really do not see how it's possible for anyone to purchase this game, play it, then proceed to leave a 1 star review.  It's baffling.  Ive been gaming for almost 20 years.  Played everything from sports games to rpgs, to mmogs,  pretty much everything.  This is easily one of the best,  if not the best games i have ever played. I normally do not leave reviews on here for games since i purchase mine digitally through my ps4 or through steam on my pc. But seeing the people leaving these bad reviews just blew my mind.  They either are just terrible at this garne or are just flat out lying. Personally i haven't come across anyone that hasn't loved everything about this garne.  Take it from me, if you own a ps4 or xbox, you must buy this game. It's one of the most beautiful, exciting, amazing, and just flat out fun games ive ever played.

author: JCAdmore
title: It’s Getting Better
content:
EDIT: After a few updates, the game is improving, a lot. But, it still needs to improve. At least, I don’t cuss and throw my controller across the room as much as I used to.

A lot of the things that drove me into a rage aren’t occurring anymore (such as, the random death of a passerby when my horse accidentally bumped them, causing me to have a bounty 40 times higher than wanted criminals; or, being killed by a random cougar every time I went into cinematic mode, and losing the 40 pelts I’d spent 400 hours collecting). OMG, just thinking about how bad it was upon release infuriates me.

But... with each new patch, it gets a little better. So, I’ve raised my score from one star to three. Hopefully, one day, I’ll bump it all the way to five.

GREAT graphics.
HORRIBLE gameplay.

GREAT options.
HORRIBLE controls.

GREAT open world.
BORING open world.

The story is boring.
The main character is boring.
The side characters are boring.
The story characters are boring.
Even the animals are boring.

What’s the best part of the game? The amazing array of chores. I mean, if you enjoy doing chores in a video game.

This game is a massive disappointment.
And, worse: a massive waste of time.

You’d be better off playing the first one.
Cuz this one really missed the mark.

author: D. Brown
title: Sorry but this is a terrible game
content:
To start off this game has spectacular graphics; that being said considering the next gen tech this is like saying your new car has working brakes.

  The story is boring and made worse by being as slow as a sloth taking a nap.  None of the characters are interesting or even noteworthy, especially the main character you play.  For some reason this was made as a game before RDR1 in the timeline and yet despite John being in the game you are not John...which is weird at best and horrible at worst.
  The gameplay itself is clunky and just not fun.  You find so many places and things in the world and yet there is no fun, no excitement, no feel of success as you plod through mindlessly over and over until you die.  The missions are boring as well as kind of stupid and leave a gunfight to end up driving a wagon....that's right; your high octane game has you driving a wagon from one of the world to the other for no reason other than to reduce the fun of this game.  You do jobs with your "gang" (yeah some gang most just sit around and eat eggs) and half the time my character never got my share of the money which does not matter because ALL weapons are locked and cannot be bought.....because why have a gunsmith store if you can actually buy things like in the first game.
  To top all this off the actual game controls and movements are terrible.  I died at least 37 times from being within 20 feet of a cliff because turning around requires a wide circle area for a man on foot and he would fall off he cliff in his convoluted, badly programmed turning mechanic.  Add in the game somehow will constantly reset your default weapon (whichever you used previously) to whatever will be 100% ineffective so that the fun can be reduced further to the programmer's destination of absolute zero.  Horses will leap fences and boulders yet a tiny pebble or a tree branch 50 feet away will send you flying off your horse, 20 feet through the air...to go over a cliff and die.
  The hunting is absolutely crazy.  You need to scan 1,000 animals to find the pristine animal and then you need a perfect shot with that animal's perfect weapon to get anything you can use and if the tiniest thing happens, like wind....trash quality which cannot be used or even sold for decent amount.
  Finally there is no fast travel in this game.  Now some will tell you that yes there is fast travel; No there isn't.  You work your butt off to get a map and you can go to a spot only to find out you are stuck there with no fast travel back.  You can buy train tickets; yet not getting paid and money being low levels means this is not realistic option.  Basically plan on spending, no joke here, literally hours watching your character ride a horse from one place to another.

  Red Dead Redemption 2......It is worse than Godfather 3

author: M. Gentry
title: At Least Now I can Hide the Bodies
content:
As a fan of the original RDR this one's been long overdue. As of my limited playing time on RDR2, one of my only criticisms is that the controls are a little too involved and some of the characters on the game are suffering accidental killings from me getting things crossed up. Some of these folks I only intended to talk to and ended up having to carry their bodies around looking for a nice hiding spot for them.
Some people might enjoy that aspect of the game, shoot first ask questions later. Others probably need to spend more time learning the controls before guessing again which button does what.
I did high center a stagecoach on a log and froze the whole game up, couldn't move forward or backwards. I couldn't even get off the stagecoach. Luckily I was in a mission and it timed out.
Weird bug though.
Only other criticism I have is, I sort of hope the story doesn't get too involved, having to read books along the way and look at photos...talk to certain individuals about something I'll need later down the road. I feel like the controls are complex enough without needing to keep up with everyone's backstory.

author: Matt
title: Outstanding immersive experience BUT not for everyone
content:
Be wary of the poor reviews. RDR2 ain't perfect - far from it - but it's a superb, immersive experience with an outstanding narrative and some of the best written characters ever to be found in video games. It is NOT an action game and that's where the poor reviews are coming from. I get that a slower, more immersive experience isn't for everyone, but that doesn't mean it's poor. Far from it.

I gave it 5 stars but that doesn't mean it's perfect. Here's my Tl;Dr review: RDR2 has an outstanding and ground-breaking game world BUT its systems for how you interact with that world are often mediocre and frequently frustrating.

Yet the game world and the narrative and the immersive aspects of the game are done SO well that it's a can't miss gaming experience for anyone interested in that type of game. The quality of the game world alone, and the awe-inspiring visuals, give me great hope for the future of games.

author: Christopher Kucharik
title: The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly (First Impressions) + Hope
content:
I loved RDR so much, I've been wanting to buy this game for over 2-years.  So I pre-ordered and picked up @Gamestop Launch Night 9PM.  I'm about 3-hours into the game (gotta work today), so here's my quick first impressions.

Conclusion:  It's gorgeous, full of options, and I probably will NOT play this as much as I did RDR (see The Ugly)

***The Good***
* Visuals - amazing graphics, detailed animations, weather, and condition changes to appearances of just about everything
* Content - chock full of everything from looting to hunting to robbery to heisting to gambling to everything else you could imagine
* Pace - much slower than the mad, mad, mad world of most FPS which fits the weapons, time period, and play style well
* Cinematic Camera - creates cut-scene movie in-game so I can avoid manual travel with NPCs

***The Bad***
* Controls - Want a good laugh?  Go to Settings - Controls - First Person Controls (Standard) and watch as your ONE configuration rotates through 3 full controller sets of details (near too fast to read anything btw).  That means your 15-button controller has 45-commands and that's just in First Person view, on Foot.  There's also Third Person view and both views for on foot, in vehicle and on horse.  You'll memorize all that after the 1st camp tutorial, right?

* Install -- 100GB will take 50-minutes (2-blurays) before you can actually play.  Hey Rockstar.  Remember when Blizzard solved that problem on Battle.net when they install the first 10%, then let you play while the remaining 90% continues to install.  Maybe you could learn that lesson.

***The Ugly***
* Tedious -- management of too many status, too much travel, too many details.  Remember when games used to be fun?  I know it's exciting to have the $ and dev teams to create all the glorious details so we experience EVERYTHING, but what you forget is we do NOT want to experience everything.  I do not want to press 7-different buttons to cut back the skin of the ONE animal I just shot (it wasn't that bad, but I need to make a point).  If I want to jump in to fast-travel to a place I've already been to pickup the whatever-I-forgot-and-need, I want to do that from the BEGINNING of the game (I hear it's available later).  Give us the option.  Remember difficulty - Easy-Normal-Hard?  This is NOT a casual pickup & play game.  It's more experiencing the ol'West.  As a result, given my busy REAL-life, I probably won't make it to the end of this one.

***My Hope***
* Gunslinger Gang -- potential in co-op online multiplayer.  I'm looking for a quick & fun, pickup Billy the Kid & gang vs. posse with my bros.  But to make that fun, they will need to turn down the onerousness.  Will see...

author: Jack Varley
title: THE WILD WILD WEST
content:
Do you want to know what it's like living in the wild wild west? Look no further, Red Dead Redemption 2 is a ridiculously detailed simulator of the gun slingin' bank robbin' wild wild west.
The gameplay is very smooth and the story will keep you until the end. Everything about the game from it's lifelike interactions to its Hollywood style gunfights will keep you wanting more. It all just feels REAL, and the smallest details and occurrences do that much more to connect you to the world. Red Dead Redemption 2 has succeeded in everything it's set out to do. Its time you join the action.

author: Christopher
title: What all sequels should be
content:
RDR2 in my personal opinion manages to trump the original in every area.
POSITIVES
1) The game is bigger(which isn’t always better, but in this case it is).
 2) The game is prettier( the enviornments are just gorgeous, and the lighting is some of the best I’ve ever seen in a video game next to Horizon Zero Dawn).
3) Provides the best exploration I’ve ever experienced in a Rockstar game(the game world is full of fun and interesting things to see and do, unlike GTA5’s open world which felt like it was full of things to see, but nothing particularly fun to do outside of the main story and certain stranger missions).
3) The story and dialogue is in a league of its own when it comes to Rockstar titles . It’s easily the most epic( and devastating) tale Rockstar has ever told.
4) Arthur Morgan joins the ranks of fantastic Rockstar protagonists with ease. He’s just as likable as good old John Marston except he’s effortlessly badass and much more flawed. The voice actor is just damn good (all the voice acting is damn good to be honest) and he fills Arthur with a commanding presence that makes every line of dialogue he speaks a pure joy to listen to.
5) The cast is fantastic! I truly came to care for almost every member of the gang(Hosea, Lenny, Charles, and Sadie are absolute stand outs to me for different reasons).
6) The gameplay is mostly superb. Epic gun play, smooth horse riding, and melee combat that is greatly improved over that mess in Red Dead Redemption.
NEGATIVES
1)Gameplay doesn’t always respond the way you want it to
2)Your preferred gun load out will be changed against your will at multiple points in the story.
3)Certain NPC’s are prone to overreact
BOTTOM LINE
Rockstar has outdone themselves. Get this game and experience everything i’ve mentioned and a whole hell of a lot I haven’t for yourself.

author: William Perry
title: Thank you Rockstar for taking the time to do it right.
content:
If you loved Red Dead Redemption , you’ll absolutely love this second version. The developers obviously put a ton of time and love in this version. Sure, there are some valid complaints and annoyances but this version is pretty amazing.

The characters and their interactions are more complex and interesting in this new version. A lot more time was put into the story and the scripted lines. The fight scenes and gun battles seem more realistic and immersive. I have the PS3 first version and this second PS4 version and the graphics are better and I find the AI behavior and movements more natural.
You’ll probably find Arthur Morgan growing on you much like John Marston did in the first version.

I’m not sure why there are some one star reviews unless the buyers were unfamiliar as to what this game is about.

author: Madison
title: Best Game of 2018 Hands Down
content: This game originally consumed my life with its compelling solo story. The openness of the world is perfect for the Wild West atmosphere and the independent environment made it incredibly immersive. My favorite memory was coming across 2 rams butting heads that suddenly stopped when a pack of wolves howled and then chased them away. My favorite feature of all has to be the horses. Their movement is so life-like and coming from an equestrian background it was nice to finally have a game where I felt attached to my horse and was genuinely afraid of losing any of them.  While the end is disappointing it is fitting for the characters. The epilogue however is a total bore!! I barely made it through the first few missions without wanting to walk away. Ultimately the online saves this game with its free roam and fun co-op story missions. Hopefully as the online advances it will continue to fix some various bugs and add more elements to an already fantastic base.

title: A game to add to the pantheon of greats
content: Any negative reviews of this game are from crybaby time. This is a grownup game. People saying it takes long to travel or is boring etc must have played for 5 seconds. This is the greatest rpg since Skyrim to me. The detail is incredible, the interactions with npcs run the gamut from normal to the truly bizarre. It is a western. content: This is one of the best games I’ve ever played. The environment, characters, and story are all an amazing achievement. I literally spent hours riding around admiring the “Wild West.” It’s landscapes are alive, it’s cities bustling, and its venues true to the time period. This is a work of art. Period.

author: Brad
title: Best video game I’ve ever played
content: I don’t even know where to start with reviewing this game.  I’ve been playing video games for over 30 years.  The story on this game is absolutely the best I’ve ever played.  The way the characters are portrayed throughout the story is almost like watching a movie.  The game is so long that it really makes the entire journey through the game enjoyable.  It doesn’t ever get boring or too drawn out.  I didn’t do a lot of the side missions and that could have prolonged the game even more.  The ending was fantastic as well. Really the only negatives to this game is it had to end and I don’t know if I’ll ever play another game that can live up to this one.  It was challenging enough that you die in it but not so hard that it becomes frustrating or so easy that it becomes boring.  I even watched the credits at the end as they periodically show continuations of certain parts of the story, which was a cool touch.  Just a remarkably done game.  I’m a big fan of the Far Cry games but they don’t come close to this one.  I could go on and on, just get it and enjoy it.

author: Fonz
title: A Triumph in Realism and Narration
content:
This game may not be for everybody, but if there was ever a game that fused cinematic storytelling with gaming masterfully, it would be this game.  Not only does it do it brilliantly, but it gives you a whole open world to explore with it and what a sight it is to behold.  You can literally just stare at this game for hours taking in the scenery.  This game in many ways is still very similar to the first game, but with extra added layers and mechanics at play especially with inventory management.  No longer can you carry all your guns like the first game, but have to actually utilize your horse.  Think of your horse as a vehicle with a trunk to store all your gear.  Like in real life, you can’t carry everything so have to manage what to bring or not bring with you into a fight at least when you get off the horse.  This approach to realism is simply the game’s major achievement, but also could be a deterrent for some which is why it may not be everybody.  I’ll give some examples.

What’s great about video games is that they can streamline a lot of monotonous experiences in our lives.  Wouldn’t it be nice to just be able to dress or grab supplies without ever moving a finger?  What if we can just teleport to work on days we don’t feel like driving through traffic?  In games, we have a knack for always looting bodies or buildings because the supplies magically appear in our inventory with the push of a button.  RDR reminds us that life isn’t quite that simple.  If you are accustomed to grabbing or doing everything, you are going to see your character actually do it.  Want to grab a can of food, Arthur will grab it and he grabs them one by one.  Want to loot a body, Arthur will pick up the body and rummage through their pockets.  Want to skin the dead animal you just killed, Arthur will show you his skill with the knife.  If you think you can do this after just robbing a home and killing the folks there, you might just have used valuable time of escaping lawmen or bounty hunters who are coming your way.  There are those and having to eat when Arthur is hungry or showering when he’s dirty.  You don’t just go into the bathroom and he will be clean either.  You will have to scrub him with button prompts or pay someone to do it for you.  You also have to provide for your camp and take care of your horse when it gets dirty or agitated.  If all of these sound intrusive to your gameplay experience, it all depends on you as a gamer.

Keep in mind you are not forced to do any of these, but it's a good idea to do so as it makes the character perform better and the people around you react to you better.  How you deal with the realism in a game depends if you buy into the world and rules it sets which this game does convincingly.  You can go explore and do whatever you please without the worry of a level ranking.  I like this aspect more to my games honestly.  I don’t like to be reminded that games are simply work.  Leveling up can sometimes feel like a grind.  In RDR2, it's all about the narrative and exploring the beautiful, vast world.  It feels like you are playing a real character that truly lives in this world.

The realism gets only more enhanced with how dense the world is.  The unique encounters you find along with the buildings and areas you can enter only immerse you even more.  The weather effects in this game are simply amazing.  This sequel, to me, is doing to the first game what GTA 4 did to all the prior GTA games before it.  Whether you enjoy that experience depends entirely all on you and I'm all for it.

This game is definitely Rockstar’s masterpiece.  I didn’t even mention about the story, but if you played the first game.  You will appreciate what the game delivers in the end.  If you want to see what this game offers, definitely finish it to the end.

author: josh
title: On the run from hospital bill collectors
content:
In RDR2 you play as an 80 year old arthritic who just escaped from the hospital after hip replacement surgery.  The attention to detail in this game is absolutely incredible.  All of you movements seem as painful and labored as they should be for a man in your condition.  Arthur stumbles down slopes just like my grandpa did when I was little and he was chasing after his dog who escaped out the front door.  Just like I would if I were in pain and high on anesthesia, everything Arthur does is slow and with a long delay from the controller input.
Speaking of controller, Rock Star stuck with the same control scheme they've been using since the PS2 days, so you won't be burdened with any unfortunate modern ergonomic improvements.  Remember Super Mario 64?  How stupid was that?  They used a pressure sensitive thumb stick, and you just pushed it forward more to move faster, and less to move slower.  Thankfully, Rockstar doesn't make you endure that.  They understand that run buttons are still the way.  Thankfully too, Arthur has arthritis in both knees, so his top speed isn't too fast to ruin the pacing of the game.

Also the mechanics are trash and the character movement is so unnatural and clunky that it's painful. I hate everything in this game aside from the fishing, that's why it gets two stars.

author: Greg Lasley
title: No fun, my babe, no fun.
content: I always feel self-conscious about being "the emperor wears no clothes" guy; but, happily, this time I don't stand alone.  I haven't read any of the positive reviews of the game but I imagine none of them praise it for it's edge-of-your-seat, adrenaline pumping action or it's smooth and non-repetitive game mechanics.  The negative reviews pretty much hit the nail on the head. I knew I had made a mistake after the hour it took slogging around in the snow and searching a tiny cabin.  I figured once the snow thawed, things would finally pick up.  Nope.  The weather changed but the game just dragged on and on, and on.  It's just not fun.  I never really played the first Red Dead so this can't be chalked up to dashed expectations.  As with so much else in life, it's difficult for me to see how anyone believes this is objectively good.

author: Pookie Beawr
title: Bad control system stops game immersion
content: I really loved the original Red Dead Redemption. Unfortunately this game is not as good. There are enjoyable moments but the control system is so clunky and badly designed it really does ruin a lot of the game play. It takes so long to get anything done that you can’t become fully immersed in the story. I understand that crafting and lifelike maintenance of characters is a really popular thing right now with many players and game companies; with that being said, there’s are good ways of designing it and bad ways of designing it, this game is one of the bad ways. I personally hate being forced to take care of a characters every need. Up until now I haven’t said anything about it because I don’t want to deminish another player’s enjoyment of a game that is designed like that, but this game makes character maintenance so time consuming and minute I feel like I’m at work instead of enjoying a game to relax. If there was an option to turn those things on or off it might be a little better, but it would still leave the terrible control layout and the unbelievable amount of menus and sub menus you have to deal with constantly. I guess if you know someone who really wants the game they have to judge for themselves but personally I’m disappointed in it but am trying to make my way through it. It gets 2 stars for quality of story work, voice acting, and graphics.

Other players have the opportunity to counter our missions and I really enjoy that aspect of the game. Nothing better that fighting another posse over a train or stage coach. As I write this the online is still only a beta, and we are dealing with a lot of glitches and such but even with the problems I love this game. People complain about a broken economy but I believe they just want instant gratification. I personally want to work my way up as I play. If you could start out with all the best guns, gear, food what would motivate you to stay at it and keep playing?

author: Jerry P. Danzig
title: How the West Could Have Been More Fun
content:
Now that I've put in many more hours playing this game, I have warmed up to it. But be prepared for a LONG period of frustration and boredom in the beginning before the game play picks up.

In particular, the save system is the worst I've encountered on any PS4 game, and probably the worst in years.

The game will NOT auto-save -- or let you save -- for stretches of time in excess of a half an hour in places!

This means that unless you are willing to keep your PS4 on overnight, say, you could be forced to replay a good half an hour or more of game play that is often considerably less than enthralling, like watching your protagonist ride a horse and ride a horse and engage in a far-from-memorable conversation.

Further eroding the appeal of this alleged AAA title are some horribly complex and cumbersome controls. Rather than design controls according to accepted industry standards -- or even make sure that the controls are consistent throughout this one game -- it seems as if the developers made up new control routines as they went along, hoping that a brief prompt would help you through a critical moment (and not force you to revisit an excruciatingly long half hour of your life again!)

Yes, the game is a technological wonder, a vivid recreation of a living, breathing, often breathtaking world. But in many sequences this world has been created with too little devotion to the core reason you're playing a game -- to have fun!

I would have thought that the creators of the GTA games would know better by now, but apparently not.

On the positive side, RDR2 gives you hours of "play" for the dollar as most open world games do. But whether you will actually enjoy a lot of the play here is another question. Living in a state where recreational marijuana is legal might help some players through some of the endless slogs on horseback.

Caveat emptor!

UPDATE: I am currently more than 70% through the game. The main story has concluded, and now I am playing a protracted epilogue focused on John Marston and his efforts to become a rancher. Unfortunately, the save points seem to be fewer and further between again, the controls are still wonky in the extreme, and the game has more bugs than a well-populated bee hive.

I have fluctuated between giving this game three and four stars and am now leaning toward three. There are just too many problems on display here. I hope Rockstar will redeem themselves with the next Grand Theft Auto...

UPDATE NUMBER TWO: Well, I have now finished the main story of RDR2. I will say that the ending was very satisfying -- more than most of the game itself!

In fact, I have just started playing yet another open world game, the latest in the Far Cry series, New Dawn, and -- that game is INFINITELY more fun to play than RDR2!!!

So ultimately I believe that Rockstar laid a cow pie with this bloated oater, which is of interest primarily to equestrians and Wild West devotees. Others can find much more enjoyable open world games to play (including the recent Far Cry games, the latest Tomb Raider, and Mad Max).

Next time around, I hope Rockstar will not again opt for quantity over quality...

author: Tom
title: Boring game that does not compare with original
content:
This game is extremely boring...

I was a huge fan of the first rdr and logged over 200 hours in it. However, a little under 20 hours for this sequel and i want to close the game and never come back.

Sure the game is extremely beautiful and is full of intricate details that fascinate you ok how much attention the developers put in, but the story and gameplay is simply not there.

The story is mundane and cliche, gunplay is awkward at best, and many activities feel more like a chore than a game. For example, who thought it was a good idea to make you spend 5 minutes riding back to your camp after every mission? The free roam feature doesn’t seem so free anymore once you realize it is required.

Anyways, i just feel like rdr2 is not nearly worth the perfect scores out there. It feels like either the reviewers were paid off or were playing a completely different game. People who are die hard fans of the first rdr surely do not help with their extremely biased opinions. In general I would avoid this game unless you like playing games like truck simulator or farm simulator.

author: Dan H.
title: Atrocious Controls, Unfun Realism, but It sure is pretty!
content:
The good: The graphics are amazing. The world is beautiful to explore and look at. The story is well told when you're not stuck riding a horse around for ten minutes.

The bad:  The focus on realism is a conscious design choice. Whether you like it or not comes down to what you expect from a game. Do you enjoy micro managing aspects of your day to day life and doing chores? Well this is the game for you.

The ugly: The controls are terrible. A game is meant to be played. I have never played a game with less intuitive controls. If I end up dying or being chased for a crime, it's generally because I accidently drew my gun on little Timmy and his innocent dog. The game feels downright terrible to control. It truly breaks the immersion and leaves a game that would otherwise deserve four stars at a two.

content: Great game, tons of detail, interesting story and missions

author: Zach Herbert
title: Absolutely TERRIBLE storytelling!
content:
Have you ever played an RPG, where the GM insists on playing their OWN NPC hero? And you sit, frustrated, while that hero NPC makes every important decision, steals every spotlight, and ultimately swipes the climax for themselves? This is that game.

It seems like most reviews are from people who haven't finished the game... They either love the visuals and slow burn pacing and rush to a 5 star review. Or they HATE the slow burn pacing and quit with low stars. But for all those people who are on the fence, or slogging through to see the end, here's my advice... Don't bother.

This story is the most bafflingly terrible, LEAST satisfying story I've ever come across. And I personally LOVE the slow burn pacing! (Just know, of that 60 hours of story time, you will spend at least half that riding back and forth through the wilderness on horseback.) The problem is that the writers are not the least bit concerned with YOU, the player. Or with Arthur, the character. The NPCs are the leads in this old west tale.

Over the course of the story, the writers build up all kinds of dramatic tension. And you will be waiting for your chance to step in and make a difference. For you, the PLAYER, to have your moment...

Sorry. It's not going to happen.

This story is about the NPCs. You're just along to watch and run errands. In the end, none of your decisions will have made a difference. None of your actions will carry any consequence. You will never have your moment. None of those equipment upgrades will count. Literally NOTHING you have done, or WANT to do, will matter. It's just one long railroad to the end. Where the writers' favorite NPCs can step in and steal the show. You'll just sit by and watch.

You, the PLAYER, aren't the protagonist. You're the captive audience. Truly disgraceful storytelling.

author: wanda
