author: Biz Person
title: Couldn't get past the slow start
content: Ten hours into this game, it's just dull and slow. Yes the graphics are pretty, the detail extends into breaking down every action into small slices. Even walking across a room is slow. It feels like they want you to invest a hundred hours and absorb this atmosphere like a Zen meditation, however I just don't have enough time in my schedule for that, and in any case, so far it is more tedious than fun.

author: Hailey
title: I don't understand the hype
content: I'll be honest, my main experience with this game was watching someone play it for a few hours. That being said, what I saw of the game was enough to make me think to myself, "Why is this game so beloved??" In my eyes, the game had ugly, poorly rendered graphics, an uninteresting plot, boring characters, slow gameplay, and waaaaaaaay too much open, empty space and no way to fast travel. Note: I was casually playing Zelda: Breath of the Wild on my Switch while also observing this person playing RDR2, and frankly I have to say that Breath of the Wild was doing a way better job of keeping my interest. Every time I looked up at the other game, I noticed again how boring or crude it was. Hey, maybe RDR2 just isn't my type of game, and I can accept that. But still, I honestly don't get the hype, and how people think it's such a beautiful, engaging masterpiece, when all I witnessed was a boring, tedious, ugly, merely average game.

author: tennguy72
title: More movie than game
content:
I have had this game now for about 2 weeks and this is my impression. I played RDR1 when it came out and it was an awesome game, especially for its time. Now, RDR2 have some improvements, especially in the graphics, but this game is more like a movie than a game. I personally feel that the team that made this wanted to tell a story instead of a game. Well here is some hot points:

PROS:
1. The graphics are awesome. Very beautiful work, the animals react life like. Beautiful scenery as well.
2. The map is awesome that it includes the original RDR1 map plus the new addition. That gives you LOTS of room to roam and see what you can get yourself into.
3. You do have plenty of freedom after you complete the story. Have lots of fun being the terror of the west.

CONS:
1. Your horse, it at times can act completely stupid. I do not know who programmed that part, but they have apparently have never been on a horse before if you ask me. Horses do not run into cliffs intentionally.
2. You can go on a crime spree, but do not do it in a city. They never seem to run out of cops and bounty hunters, no matter how many you send off to a dirt nap.
3. When you dismount from your horse, better check your weapons. It seems like anytime you dismount, all your rifles will stay on the horse and you have to go back and get them again.

author: Kevin Crowe
title: Exceptional
content:
I'm not much of a gamer these days, married and with young kids I don't have the time anymore. I grew up playing the original grand theft auto on the PlayStation 1 and the last game I purchased was GTA 5 a few years ago due to nostalgia, but it still delivered, and so does Red Dead Redemption 2.  I remember playing the original Red Dead Redemption back when I was a bachelor and on pre-deployment for Afghanistan in 2010. I spent so many hours on the game and loved every minute. As soon as I heard a new one was coming out I knew I would have to get it.

I've read a variety of reviews and I can see where they are coming from when they say this is boring and slow. You have to immerse yourself in the game to fully enjoy it, its not a game you can turn on to kill 10 minutes or have a quick gunfight. As this is a prequel to the original, it is nice to see the origin of some of these characters.

*Warning, spoilers ahead.*

The main story is amazing and incredibly detailed.
Once you get to chapter 2 the majority of the map opens up to you and you'll be exploring for hours.
The whole world here is incredibly detailed, there so many species of animals to track down and hunt.
I love the fact the original Red Dead Redemption map opens up towards the end of the story, but I wish there was more to do with it. Not much really happens in this area.
The main antagonist, Arthur Morgan, is such a lovable character, whether you play him as a good or a bad outlaw. I really felt like there was something missing after he died when you continue as John Marston. Its a shame once you fully complete the story there is no option to bring him back just to play as.
The gameplay can be frustrating and unforgiving, this can annoy you but adds some realism to the game.
I was expecting a lot more stranger missions and opportunities to pull off epic bank heists, but this may be in development with downloadable content.
I have not experienced this online yet and heard it is still at an immature stage.

author: L. Tan
title: The game takes some patience, but it's great
content: I loved the the first red dead redemption, considered it as one of the best games ever. When rdr2 came out, I bought it right away. It's a different game from the first one, but it's still awesome. It starts out a little slow, but gets better and better as the game goes on. If you have not played rdr games, i suggest playing the second one first, and then play the first one. The story was complex and engaging. The graphics are outstanding.

author: Caitie
title: Great Story!
content: I just finished the main storyline and am now getting into the epilogue chapters. This is by far the best game I have played. The storytelling is phenomenal and the graphics are stunning. The characters are complex and I found myself becoming attached to several of the characters. The only thing I miss from the original Red Dead Redemption is lassoing without dismounting your horse. Other than that, I am extremely impressed with this game and plan to replay it!

If you were a fan of the first RDR, Trevor in GTAV, campy westerns, and anti-heros in general, you might enjoy this game more than I could.

author: Kristin Reger
title: Slow but steady
content:
Honestly the first 10 hours or so I put into this game I probably would have given it 1 star. I was SO disappointed. The speed of movement (in camp, in the first few missions, even travelling across the map on a running HORSE) was so slow I literally fell asleep. But if you have the time to get past this initial giant tutorial, it really opens up. You can ignore things like chores around camp and sleeping/eating/cooking. My experience vastly improved once I realized this. (Not sure who those details are geared towards but I don't need more chores in my life.) The setting is gorgeous. The characters are hilarious (though I got more attached to some of the side quest characters than a lot of the NPCs in camp). There's a lot to do - and if you don't want to do it, for the most part, you don't have to. The absolute worst part for me is that you're penalized for looting corpses and property (of people you weren't penalized for murdering!) in multiple ways - your morality dips (meh) and you can easily fail missions by "abandoning" your side quest buddies walking 5 steps to loot a body. The whole point of almost every mission is the need for more money - you know a quick source of money? The 20+ bodies we just left behind after a shootout at the mansion...

I can't even sort out the good from the bad, but I will definitely keep playing. The longer I've played, the more the good outweighs the bad. Just started Chapter 4 where supposedly the story picks up. I do think the game is overhyped but it's slowly (SLOOOOOWLY) winning me over.

author: E
title: Game of the Decade
content:
While people are stating the controls and gunplay is clunky, I thought that as well, the game kind of has an overwhelming start, but it’s just a learning curve, and once you get into the game, it’s actually really smooth and intuitive. Honestly the people complaining I feel just have a complete lack of patience.

Once you get a hang of the controls and how to play the game though the game is probably the best game of the decade. I haven’t seen better graphics in a game, very few bugs on release - stupidly polished, great soundtrack, plenty of things to do, and it has an amazing story.

You don’t even have to play to enjoy it, husband let me play through it the first time, and he was glued to screen. The story and visuals are enough to hold up on its own.

author: Elijah Fulton
title: Graphics are terrible, seem like last gen!
content:
Please read before you buy, then search for similar issues online...  I just sent this to Rockstar Games...

I just purchased the Ultimate Edition of RDR2 and I'm extremely dissapointed in the graphics of this game.  Had I known the game was going to look like this (not even close to GTA5) I would have never purchased it.  After spending hours trying to get HDR to work, I finally went online and saw the issue isn't isolated to me.  So I followed others advice and disabled HDR in the game.

This did help the game's graphics a little, but it seems like it's blurry, too dark at many times, has a layer of graininess, and the motion blur or whatever that's going on seems to make things worse.

I can't believe the step down from GTA5 graphics.  This game was built for this gen platform yet it seems like many steps backwards.

Are you guys trying to fix this, or is this what I'm stuck with.  The game play seems to be fun, but these graphics literally hinder me from seeing animals, sometimes people, etc. and truly make this a very unpleasant experience.

Edit*
Want to add what I play on.
Playstation 4 PRO with Samsung SSD
Sony Bravia xbr65x850e (less than 2 years old)don't have issues playing any other 4k HDR games
Sony STRDN1080 stereo

So my equipment should not be an issue.  And like I said it works fine with any other 4k HDR game.

The main issue is HDR doesn't work, but when you disable that there is no brightness settings in the game to adjust.  So you have to start adjusting your TV settings which basically messes up all your settings for other games/movies/etc...

author: Beeds
title: Wating For Arthur To... (my suggested new title)
content:
RDR2 has been a huge disappointment for me. It may have the most beautiful scenery of any video game ever, but that is all it has. To put it mildly, it's a poorly written movie posing as a video game. Everything is slow: controls, dialog, aiming, Arthur picking stuff up, putting it down, cut scenes you can skip followed by 3-5 minutes of traveling on your horse/in a carriage with part of the gang while they blab all about the irrelevant backstory. The story is hopelessly redundant: Gang gets in trouble, gang shoots itself out of trouble & gets in more trouble, gang needs to move - rinse and repeat. The script is a magnificent work of masturbatory writing I've ever been forced to listen to and the dialog for the Stranger quests will have you screaming, "Just spit it out!" at the TV too many times for one day. Add all that to the fact there is no real 'game' in this single player, unless you consider having to go back and forth 100 times to achieve 10 things a game (imagine Skyrim or Fallout 4 w/o fast travel, yeah, it's annoying) and all you want to do is melt the disc down so no one else has to suffer like you did. Maybe it'll be worth the 68 bucks once multiplayer is released, but then Rockstar should have let us know that all we were paying for was one long, boring tutorial.

ETA: Just finished and what a total waste of time. Part I of the epilogue has 97% cut scenes, backstory scenes and, believe it or not, the guy working, yes, working. Who at Rockstar thought people would enjoy playing a game that involved actual work on the part of their character? And it's quite obvious Rockstar has some well paid publicists or else we, the consumers, would have known how lame this game, scratch that, this made for Console Movie was before we paid for it.

author: Sam
title: Meh, so far.
content:
First the good:
- Graphics, amazing
- Production value (you could tell from the painstaking detail that the programmers put their everything into this game)

Negative:
- Animations (while they are really detailed, the slowness can get annoying)
- Travel. This is a big one for me. You have to travel LONNNNNNNNNNG distances to get to where you are going and find action in this game. But travelling is not fun. It's very cinematic, it's very pretty, but it's not fun. Horses tire if you run too fast and the map is so big, except that that means there are wide areas of no activity in this wild west setting. Also, if you are galloping too fast and accidentally hit a rock, you will get thrown from your horse and die. Sometimes after travelling for a long distance.
- I swear Dead Eye was a lot easier to execute in RDR1.
- It's easy to accidentally kill NPCs. While that may sound hilarious, it's not. Especially when you are trying to accomplish an objective in the town and they all turn on you because you accidentally brushed an NPC on your horse and they ridiculously died or got hurt enough to qualify as assault. I guess this and the last couple critiques qualify as control issues.

The story itself is okay, so far. I'm about 8 hrs in and its not great, but its not terrible. The voice acting is very good, but a lot of the characters you engage with are not that particularly interesting.

I hope it picks up the more I play, but I am regretting getting the 80.00 version of this game. It takes a lot of time to progress through, and so far the payoff is not quite worth it.
